sessions.intendedAudience: This presentation is targeted towards developers and architects who use messaging within their systems. Participants will get an overview of how ActiveMQ and Kafka work under the covers, and how tradeoffs within these products affects application designs. No experience with messaging is assumed. Some code in slides.
sessions.abstract:
Messaging systems underpin architectures ranging from stream processing, through to event sourcing and communication between loosely-coupled microservices. To most developers the technology is not core to the business they work in, and is often disregarded as “just a pipe” for message distribution. Without understanding their capabilities and underlying design decisions, we tell ourselves myths how these systems “should” work and are frustrated in production by behaviours coming from design trade-offs.

In this session you will learn how to think about messaging as we compare and contrast the approaches taken by two similar but fundamentally different messaging platforms – Apache ActiveMQ and Apache Kafka. We will discuss how their underlying philosophies impact message distribution, reliability, scalability, and performance.

Along the way we will dip into how IOPS, latency and bandwidth affect throughput, why messaging systems do not play nicely with containers, and the unicorn of once-and-only-once delivery in distributed systems.
sessions.title: The Myth of the Magical Messaging Fabric

speakers.name: Jakub Korab
speakers.bio: Jakub Korab is an independent consultant specialising in open source messaging and integration, helping companies to apply Apache ActiveMQ and Apache Kafka. His experience spans everything from architecture to troubleshooting across a number of industries that have included transportation, banking, law enforcement, gambling, logistics, utilities and space exploration. In 2016 he will complete his 100th messaging engagement.

sessions.intendedAudience: Tilhørere bør ha erfaring med smidige prosjekter og kunnskap om rammene og kompromissene som inngår i arkitekturavgjørelser. Løsningsarkitekter og seniorutviklere vil få størst utbytte av presentasjonen.
sessions.abstract:
Presentasjonen går igjennom erfaringer vi har fått underveis i arbeidet med å lage en løsning for å samle inn data om vegtrafikken i Norge. Systemet gir ut høykvalitets informasjon i nær sanntid og er basert på en uvanlig kombinasjon av sensorer, embedded devices, protokoller og programvare.

Gjennom dette arbeidet har vi fått erfaring i å bygge et distribuert system med en arkitektur i stadig endring. Presentasjonen vil ta for seg noen av problemene vi har hatt underveis og samtidig illustrere hvordan vi mener man bør gå fram for å lage løsninger som er mottakelige for forandringer.  

Presentasjonen vil vise at det er mange paralleller mellom det å oppnå smidighet i arkitekturer og det å oppnå god skalerbarhet.

speakers.name: Kristoffer Dyrkorn
speakers.bio: Kristoffer Dyrkorn er teknolog i BEKK. De siste 15 årene har Kristoffer jobbet som utvikler, prosjektleder, løsningsarkitekt og rådgiver på ulike prosjekter i Norge. Han har i løpet av den tiden vært borti mange forskjellige teknologier og løst en god del mystiske problemer. Kristoffer har dyp kompetanse på skalerbarhet og løpende arkitekturutforming og har holdt workshops og presentasjoner om brukervennlighet og arkitektur på konferanser i Norge, Europa og USA.

sessions.intendedAudience: Foredraget krever ingen tidligere erfaring med DDD, men det er fordelaktig om du har kjennskap til de utfordringene prinsippene derfra prøver å løse, enten det er store monolitter som en ønsker å modularisere eller om du sliter med en flokk mikrotjenester som får gjeting av katter til å virke enkelt. Foredraget vil være relevant for både utviklere, arkitekter og produkteiere.
sessions.abstract: Hvor relevant er domene-drevet design (DDD) 13 år etter Eric Evans’ velkjente blå bok kom ut for første gang? Boken og miljøet den vokste ut av var preget av hvordan større virksomheter bygget sine IT-systemer tidlig på 2000-tallet, dominert av de to store og altomfattende plattformene J2EE og .NET, så da er det naturlig å spørre seg hvordan den da kan passe inn i en verden preget av mikrotjenester, smidige metodikker og en myriade av teknologier og plattformer. På mange måter passer sentrale DDD-konsepter som “bounded context”, “core domain”, “ubiquitous language”, “distillation” og “aggregates” enda bedre inn i en slik verden enn i de store monolittene vi slet med den gang. Denne velfylte verktøykassen inneholder teknikker for hvordan vi som teknikere kan komme mye tettere på forretningen for å bedre forstå deres visjoner og behov; prinsipper for hvordan vi bedre kan designe vedlikeholdbare løsninger som er direkte koblet til de individuelle domene i bedriften; og maler for hvordan vi kan bygge autonome komponenter på en smidig måte.
sessions.title: Mikrotjenester uten domenedrevet design er risikosport!

speakers.name: Trond Hjorteland
speakers.bio: Trond er en kodende arkitekt fra konsulentselskapet Scienta og har lang erfaring med store, komplekse og forretningskritiske applikasjoner, primært mellomvare- og backendsystemer. Han har spesialkompetanse innen tjenesteorientering, domene-drevet design og hendelsesdrevet arkitektur.

sessions.intendedAudience: Dette foredraget sikter seg inn på et bredt publikum! Jobber du med IoT/mikrokontrollere, kan dette foredraget by på kunnskap og utfordringer du selv kan komme til å støte på. Ingen forkunnskaper er nødvendig.
sessions.abstract:
Våre oppdragsgivere får ikke alltid den leveransen de forventer – i positiv forstand. Så da de ba oss om 'design til en musematte og en plakat' måtte det bli noe helt annet. Nærmere bestemt en IoT-installasjon som sekunderer et helt kundesenter i hvor gjerrige de greier å være.

I dette foredraget vil du høre om hvordan to programvareutviklere hoppet inn i sitt første kommersielle IoT-prosjekt for en kunde. Hva skjer når du bruker kjente metodikker for programvare i et hardware prosjekt? Hva gjør du når du har veldig dårlig tid til å levere et fysisk produkt? Litervis med vann og elektronikk i samme installasjon kan også by på skumle scenarier.

Vi dro inn flere teknologier i dette prosjektet, blant annet:
- Node-red
- Raspberry Pi
- ESP8266
- Highcharts
- Firebase

Vi går gjennom problemene, utfordringene, gledene og aha-opplevelsene vi støtte på, og disse er godt dokumentert med bilder og video!

speakers.bio:
Utvikler som jobber i Bouvet Norge, hvor jeg startet et internt maker-/hackerspace med gadgets og elektronikk som 3D-printere, mikrokontrollere, verktøy og morsomme dingser. Jeg organiserer også Internet of Things Oslo meetup, hvor folk som er interessert i IoT kan presentere og følge med på prosjekter som blir kjørt rundt omkring i landet.

speakers.name: Martin Gravråk
speakers.bio:
Martin  har jobbet som systemutvikler i 10 år, og har bygget systemer for alt fra bank og forsikring til olje og jernbane.  Elsker konseptet med internet of things, og mener at hvis noe ikke har wifi så er det ikke verdt å eie. Dette har ført til at det meste i hjemmet inkludert tannbørste,  belysning, baderomsvekt, seng,  og kjøleskap er koblet på nett.

sessions.intendedAudience: the participant will enjoy the session more if they have some basic experience of running Kafka and can relate to our mistakes.
sessions.abstract:
Topic: Operations (and development) - how we set up Kafka without really understand our own requirements or how to configure Kafka to fullfill them

**

Kafka was introduced as part of a proof of concept for collecting 20 million click events a day. Other teams started using Kafka for different purposes, but our configuration was still as if it was a prototype. This lead to scaling problems, stability problems, and lost messages. We'll tell you what we did, and how we solved it. Enjoy our mistakes and learn!

**

4 years of using Kafka without really understanding the documentation, has taught us a lot. Join this session, and learn from our suboptimal solutions!

At FINN.no, Norway's biggest online classifieds site, we have been using Kafka since version 0.7 in 2012. Kafka was introduced as part of a proof of concept for collecting click events from our web front end, which had approximately 40 million page views a day. The Kafka cluster became popular, and more and more teams started using it, with our default settings. Still we did not have anyone dedicated to running and configuring Kafka - it was a best effort, and usually the latest person touching the defaults won. As the traffic, number of use cases, and topics grew, we got some scaling problems, stability problems, lost messages and a general feeling among developers that "our kafka cluster was unstable".

In the end we had to put some effort into find out what we ran, which properties we really needed, and get control over the configuration, our library code and how our clients used Kafka. Since August we haven't had a complaint, nor downtime on our Kafka cluster.

As the Germans say "Schadenfreude ist die schönste Freude".

Major points:
- Making our own client library, trying to "simplify" our developers' life
- Using a single cluster, with a single configuration, for vastly different purposes (click event streams and credit card payment)
- Single Zookeeper connection over a load balancer
- 8 Zookeeper nodes and 8 Kafka nodes - on the same 8 servers
- Running Kafka on nodes that already were nearly out of memory
- Arbitrary number of replicas
- Arbitrary number of partitions, default 128
- Auto create of topics
- Unclean leader election for topics requiring strict reliability
- No schema repository
- Layered schemas; single IDL for thrift, java artifacts for mapping
- "What is client rebalance - this has to be a bug"
- Not understanding of how auto commits work

Slides in English, presentation in Norwegian
sessions.title: 101 ways of configuring Kafka - badly  ; Hva FINN.no har lært av å kjøre Kafka

speakers.name: Audun Fauchald Strand
speakers.bio: Audun har jobbet som utvikler og arkitekt i 10 år. Han liker store kompliserte systemer, diskusjoner, og ting som google lager.

sessions.intendedAudience: The talk is intended for people with an interest in performance, especially in the context of applications that run on top of the JVM. There is not much prior knowledge required although it is beneficial to have a very basic understanding of the JVM and the available tooling (e.g. Java Flight Recorder). I intend to show some code snippets on my slides and maybe do a benchmark live demo (but no live coding).
sessions.abstract:
There are lots of pitfalls when creating a benchmark, yet many people just write a simple driver script, run it and use the resulting numbers without any further verification. This can result in bad decisions.

In this talk, we describe how we approached this problem when creating a macrobenchmarking framework for the popular search engine Elasticsearch. Based on this example, we share our experience, show you concrete techniques to spot accidental bottlenecks and other common problems in benchmarks in order to get accurate benchmark results.
sessions.title: Benchmarking Elasticsearch

speakers.name: Daniel Mitterdorfer
speakers.bio: Daniel Mitterdorfer is a software engineer at Elastic working on Elasticsearch. He is interested in CPU architecture, performance in general and concurrency on the JVM.

sessions.intendedAudience: This session is for experienced developers, architects and technical leaders. The talk does contains no code, but addresses the complexity at a design level with regards to services and databases.
sessions.abstract: Experience talk about how architecture and organization come together to address the challenges we face at FINN.no. How we believe decentralised ownership and decision making can help improve development speed and product quality over time. Where we still see complexity in FINN after we started using micro services. And how we try to use the inverse Conway manoeuvre together with DDD to extract the strategic parts of our legacy code. The talk will also address how we currently address data flows across services, and how we are moving in the direction of using events and data streams.
sessions.title: Strategic Design by Architecture and Organisation @ FINN.no

speakers.name: Sebastian Verheughe
speakers.bio: Chief Enterprise Architect @ FINN.no, previously worked at Telenor for 7 years with last responsibility for the service architecture (middleware) for mobile services. Worked with development and architecture professionally for 16 years. Introduced NOSQL graph databases into Telenor some years ago, and in general believes in finding the right tool for the right problem is the correct strategy in any organization. Still codes once in a while...

sessions.intendedAudience:
Developers writing code that touches crypto, e.g. client-side cookies, encrypted storage of files, masked strings sent to the client UI, WS-Security etc.
Some code in slides / live-coding in demos
sessions.abstract: We using an increasing amount of crypto in our code to protect our assets. However we can easily go wrong if we don't know how to use it correctly. In this talk we will look at what can go wrong when crypto is used the wrong way. We will NOT dive into the algorithms themselves, but look at what the different primitives give us and what happens when our expectations are wrong.
sessions.title: Broken crypto is broken

speakers.name: Erlend Oftedal
speakers.bio: Erlend has worked as a developer and security tester for over 10 years. He has built open source security tools, and spoken at national and international developer and security conferences.

sessions.intendedAudience: Anybody developing concurrent programs for the JVM. Code in slides.
sessions.abstract: At first glance, writing concurrent programs in Java seems like a straight-forward task. But the devil is in the detail. Fortunately, these details are strictly regulated by the Java memory model which, roughly speaking, decides what values a program can observe for a field at any given time. Without respecting the memory model, a Java program might behave erratic and yield bugs that only occure on some hardware platforms. This presentation summarizes the guarantees that are given by Java's memory model and teaches how to properly use volatile and final fields or synchronized code blocks. Instead of discussing the model in terms of memory model formalisms, this presentation builds on easy-to follow Java code examples.
sessions.title: The Java memory model made easy

speakers.name: Rafael Winterhalter
speakers.bio: Rafael works as a software consultant in Oslo, Norway. He is a proponent of static typing and a JVM enthusiast with particular interest in code instrumentation, concurrency and functional programming. Rafael blogs about software development, regularly presents at conferences and was pronounced a JavaOne Rock Star. When coding outside of his work place, he contributes to a wide range of open source projects and often works on Byte Buddy, a library for simple runtime code generation for the Java virtual machine. For his work, Rafael received a Duke's Choice award and was elected a Java Champion.

sessions.intendedAudience:
Beginner 
Foredraget er for alle som vil lære litt om maskinlæring. Det vil bli vist kode i presentasjonen, og du kan jaggu kjøre eksemplene selv også ved å klone vårt GitHub repo.
sessions.abstract:
Lyst til å lære om maskinlæring? Interessert i hva du kan bruke det til i ditt prosjekt? 
I dette foredraget går vi gjennom grunnleggende maskinlæringsmetoder. Vi forklarer historien bak maskinlæring og teorien for de ulike metodene. Vi viser deg hvilke Java-biblioteker som kan gjøre jobben for deg, og ikke minst hva du kan bruke maskinlæring til i prosjektet ditt.
For å lage eksempler til de ulike maskinlæringsmetodene har vi tatt utgangspunkt i data om presentasjoner og foredragsholdere på tidligere års JavaZone. Vi analyserer og kategoriserer dataene for å finne nye og ukjente sammenhenger. Hvilke selskaper holder de mest avanserte presentasjonene og hvilke grupper foredragsholdere bruker flest superlativer i beskrivelsen av seg selv?
Til slutt presenter vi det optimale JavaZone-abstractet som er generert helt automatisk fra tidligere abstracts.
sessions.title: Maskinlæring skriver din neste presentasjon!

speakers.bio: Aleksander Bai er seniorforsker hos Norsk Regnesentral. Han har mange års erfaring som både gründer og  IT-konsulent hos store og små aktører, før han fikk sansen for anvendt forskning. Aleksander er en stor tilhenger av open source og maskinlæring, og jobber for tiden med en doktorgrad hvor maskinlæring er sentralt.

Hun har en doktorgrad i matematikk om noe uforståelige greier, og har tidligere jobbet mange år som utvikler i et konsulentfirma. Heidi er interessert i det meste som har med programmering å gjøre, og liker å lære nye ting, som for eksempel maskinlæring.

sessions.intendedAudience: The target audience is experienced Java developers willing to get a detailed overview on how does the security sandbox model of the Java platform work and what are the future directions for extension of that model in new version of the platform.

The utilities that fullfill the security portfolio of the JDK will be discussed briefly along with several guidelines in designing and implementing secure applications by following security best practices.

speakers.name: Martin Toshev
speakers.bio:
Martin is a Java enthusiast and one of the leads of the Bulgarian Java Users group (BG JUG). He is a certified Java professional (SCJP6) and a certified IBM cloud computing solution advisor. His areas of interest include the wide range of Java-related technologies (such as Servlets, JSP, JAXB, JAXP, JMS, JMX, JAX-RS, JAX-WS, Hibernate, Spring Framework, Liferay Portal and Eclipse RCP), cloud computing technologies, cloud-based software architectures, enterprise application integration, relational and NoSQL databases. Spring RabbitMQ (JavaScop 2015, Skopie, Macedonia)
Security Architecture of the Java Platform (JavaDay 2015, Kiev, Ukraine)

sessions.intendedAudience:
This session will be structured around a robust and easily-applied core method, but with most focus on the less-discussed and small-thing-but-large-impact gotchas which we've caught (and failed to catch) over the last two years.  We want to have live demos too time and infrastructure allowing.

The end result should be both educational and entertaining.
sessions.abstract:
We've been working on and incrementally deploying and upgrading a growing set of Microservices for two years now.  They support the website for a UK household-name company, and as such, through testing of every release is vital.

Over this time we've spent more and more time on our performance testing. In this session we'll describe our current approach, illustrated with lashings of war stories:

  * plan - driving all your tests from your requirements, and your greatest fears
  * setup - the importance of being as prod-like as possible, especially when you're not Netflix. Oh, and repeatability
  * perform - where request mix, load profile, duration, network flakiness and failure in its myriad forms are key
  * record - measurement, percentiles, and analysis
  * summarise - pulling out the headlines
  * investigation - when things went a bit weird and you have no idea why
  * improve - not just perf. but also visibility and diagnose-ability
  * automate - because CI/CD pipelines aren't just for functional tests

As an added bonus we've done all this with free tools so you'll get some demos and will then be able to go away and try things out for yourselves.
sessions.title: Distributed Architecture and Design: A Scientific Approach

speakers.name: Andrew Harmel-Law
speakers.bio:
Experienced both across the software development lifecycle and in many sectors, Andrew loves leading teams and building large-scale software solutions. He understands that people, tooling, architecture and process all have key roles to play in achieving this. 

To learn, Andrew tries to share both his experiences and his code as widely as possible. He is Capgemini UK's OSS advocate and recently led the creation of an internal Software Craftsmanship Course to help others adopt XP programming practices. He also set up the Capgemini Engineering Blog. This sharing comes not only from his formal consulting engagements - he also mentors undergraduates, posts blogs, speaks and contributes to open source projects and forums.

speakers.name: Kevin Rudland
speakers.bio: An experienced Senior Software Engineer with Capgemini, having worked on projects across a variety of problem domains and industries. Kevin loves solving big complex problems for clients and strives to find simple elegant solutions. Kevin is passionate about helping junior developers and helps run a variety of Software engineering courses across Capgemini on subjects such as OO, TDD and pair programming.

sessions.intendedAudience: Utviklere med kjennskap til java-syntaks eller funksjonell programmering. Code in slides and live coding.
sessions.abstract: Immutables er et bibliotek for generering av klasser med rik standardfunksjonalitet, både foranderlige og uforanderlige. Javaslang er en erstatning for de innebygde datastrukturene i java.util som tar sikte på renere kode enn Stream-APIet  og utstrakt bruk av uforanderlige datastrukturer og funksjonell programmering. De er begge i versjon 2 nå, betyr det at det er på tide å vurdere å ta dem i bruk?

speakers.name: Axel Wathne
speakers.bio: Begynte å lære Java for 16 år siden og jobber i Webstep

sessions.intendedAudience: Beginners to experts should each be available to take away something from the talk. The audience will get a glimpse into Java-based game development, WORA API design principles, special considerations when doing cross-platform development, and how to manage a popular OSS project. The audience needs to be familiar with basic Java. Code in slides and some very minor live coding.
sessions.abstract: Duke’s Choice Award winner libGDX is an open source cross-platform game development framework enabling its users to target Windows, Linux, Mac OS X, Android, iOS, BlackBerry, Windows Phone 10, and WebGL-enabled browsers with a single codebase. libGDX is used extensively around the world by everyone from indie developers to large studios, demonstrating the validity of Java for game development. This session provides an introduction to libGDX, including a detailed look under the covers and an exploration of the lessons learned during its development. It includes topics such as API design, platform fragmentation, cross-platform build systems, and performance considerations. It also covers aspects of OSS development such as community building and team management.
sessions.title: It’s All Fun and Games: Cross-Platform Game Development with Java and libGDX

speakers.name: Mario Zechner
speakers.bio: Machine learner and middle management in an R&D company in a previous life, now enjoying writing Ahead-of-Time compilers and the tooling around them to get Java onto iOS. Night-time game (middleware) developer and benevolent OSS project dictator at libGDX. Author of best selling book "Beginning Android Games".

sessions.intendedAudience:
Systemeiere, prosjektledere, utviklere
Ingen kode
sessions.abstract: Under utvikling av store komplekse systemer er det ofte stor usikkerhet rundt hvor godt applikasjonen yter. Hvilke tiltak kan gjøres før koden går i prod for å sikre at kapasiteten på servere er tilstrekkelig, uten at det blir overkapasitet. Lyntalen vil gi et overblikk over hvordan dette gjøres i NAV.
sessions.title: Hvordan sikre høy ytelse i komplekse systemer?

speakers.name: Vegar Engen
speakers.bio: Vegar gikk ut fra NTNU i 2014 med en sivilingeniørutdannelse innen datateknologi. Etter endt studie har Vegar jobbet som konsulent for Visma Consulting og har jobbet med ytelsestest på NAV og UDI de siste 2 årene.

sessions.intendedAudience: Every Java web developer should attend this session in order to learn how to create self defending web applications with Java. Code will be shown in slides as well as in the live demo (IDE).
sessions.abstract: One important mitigation to prevent attacks on web applications is secure development. But one layer of security is not enough. So why not develop an application that protects and defends itself? Developers know best what needs to be protected and how to identify unusual behavior. That’s ‘Application Intrusion Detection’. In addition to the subsequent analysis of an attack, it enables the application to detect an ongoing attack itself. And to respond to an attack automatically and in real time with appropriate defense measures – before an attacker gains control of the application. This session will show you how to create more secure Java web applications by adding self-defending capabilities by utilizing ‘Application Intrusion Detection’.
sessions.title: The Web Application Strikes Back

speakers.name: Dominik Schadow
speakers.bio: Dominik Schadow has more than 10 years of experience in Java development and is working as a senior consultant at bridgingIT in Stuttgart (Germany). He is specialized on Java enterprise application architecture and development with Spring and JEE and a strong advocate on the secure development of Java based web applications. He is a regular speaker about various Java security topics at different conferences, author of a German book about the development of secure Java web applications and has written many articles in German IT magazines. In his spare time, he is the lead of the JCrypTool open source project, an extensible cryptography e-learning application.

sessions.intendedAudience:
Anybody wanting to gather data from any source they can think of.
Code in slides
sessions.abstract:
The Elastic Stack is widely used to collect logs with Logstash, analyze and search the data with Elasticsearch, and visualize what is happening in your system with Kibana. Now there is a new platform for shipping many types of operational data: Beats. It can be used to collect, parse, and ship any type of data.
This talk provides an overview of the Beats platform and dives into gathering system metrics, tapping your wire data, and using real-time file analytics.
sessions.title: Collect all the things with Beats

speakers.name: Philipp Krenn
speakers.bio: Philipp is a Developer Advocate at Elastic, spreading the love and knowledge of full-text search, analytics, and real-time data. He is a frequent speaker at conferences and meetups about all things search & analytics, databases, cloud computing, and devops. Philipp lives in Vienna where he enjoys experimenting with software, organizing meetups, and sports.

sessions.intendedAudience:
> Who should attend this session?
Developers, data scientists, everyone who has basic SQL skills

> How will the participants benefit from attending?
90% of the participants will learn things they've never heard before, but which they could use immediately in their projects.

> Explicitly state what your audience needs to know
Basic SQL skills are required. If participants have never worked with SQL, they might be pretty lost.

> To indicate the amount of code in your talk we recommend you use the following phrases
Code in slides
sessions.abstract:
SQL is the winning language of Big Data. Whether you’re running a classic relational database, a column store (“NewSQL”), or a non-relational storage system (“NoSQL”), a powerful, declarative, SQL-based query language makes the difference. The SQL standard has evolved drastically in the past decades, and so have its commercial and open source implementations.

In this fast-paced talk, we’re going to look at very peculiar and interesting data problems and how we can solve them with SQL. We’ll explore common table expressions, hierarchical SQL, table-valued functions, lateral joins, row value expressions, window functions, and advanced data types, such as XML and JSON. And we’ll look at Oracle’s mysterious MODEL and MATCH_RECOGNIZE clauses, devices whose mystery is only exceeded by their power. Most importantly, however, we’re going to learn that everyone can write advanced SQL. Once you learn the basics in these tricks, you’re going to love SQL even more.
sessions.title: 10 SQL Tricks that You Didn't Think Were Possible

speakers.name: Lukas Eder
speakers.bio: Lukas Eder is the founder and CEO of Data Geekery GmbH, located in Zurich, Switzerland. With his company he has been selling database products and services around Java and SQL since 2013. Ever since his Master’s studies at EPFL in 2006, he has been fascinated by the interaction of Java and SQL. Most of this experience he has obtained in the Swiss E-Banking field through various variants (JDBC, Hibernate, mostly with Oracle). As a Java Champion, he is happy to share this knowledge at various conferences, JUGs, in-house presentations and on his blog. Here’s his conference and JUG talk schedule for the most recent time: http://www.jooq.org/news.

sessions.intendedAudience: The talk is for developers and architects who have a basic understanding of functional programming and design patterns described by the Gang of Four.
sessions.abstract:
Reactive Programming is described as the next big thing of a programming paradigm.
The most common thoughts you will read about Reactive Programming is that it makes use of immutable streams and the propagation of change. At first when you hear propagation of change you might think about the observer pattern which will be delimited from what we think of Reactive Programming.
With the help of small examples, modifying arrays, we will get to know lambda expressions, filter expressions and map/reduce. Adding the concept of observables we inspect the subscription to a stream of events which turns the observer pattern the other way around and omits the usage of callbacks.
Of course there is already a manifesto, as for all fresh programming paradigms, you can sign. The manifesto states four principles of Reactive Programming at which we will take a closer look: Reactive systems are responsive, resilient, elastic and message driven.
After this overview on Reactive Programming we ask the following questions:
* Is Reactive Programming new after all?
* How do you test reactive systems?
* Who has control over a reactive system when everything is based on change?
sessions.title: I have a stream - Insights in Reactive Programming

speakers.name: Jan Carsten Lohmüller
speakers.bio: Jan Carsten is a software developer, coffee enthusiast and bearded man. Since doing his studies at university of Bonn and university of Hamburg he has been actively working in the software industry, utilizing various technologies. He has been involved in both start-ups as well as established global organizations and research. Jan is currently working in the software consultancy business with emphasis on C#, Java, architecture and security, functional programming and software craftsmanship.

sessions.intendedAudience: Litt kjennskap til Angular2 . Er nyskjerrig på redux, men erfaring med redux er ikke nødvendig. Code in slides.
sessions.abstract:
Redux er et rammeverk som skal ta hånd om tilstanden til applikasjonen for deg. Ved å flytte tilstanden ut av komponentene kan du lettere lage små komponenter som er lette å gjenbruke. Debuggeren til Redux lar deg også ta en tidsreise gjennom de ulike tilstandene applikasjonen har vært i - og på den måten gjøre deg lett for deg som utvikler å forstå hvordan du endte opp i en bestemt tilstand.

I denne lyntalen vil vi se på hvordan vi kan bruke Redux sammen med Angular2 og hvordan det kan være med på å gjøre dine angular-applikasjoner bedre.
sessions.title: Redux + Angular2 = sant

speakers.name: Steffen Hageland
speakers.bio: Utvikler i BEKK. Jobber i hovedsak på relativt frontend-tunge applikasjoner - hvor de fleste er skrevet i Angular. Men har også jobbet med andre rammeverk som f.eks. React. Har den siste tiden bygget kompetanse på angular2, og sett på hvordan man kan migrere eksisterende angular-applikasjoner over til den nye plattformen.

sessions.intendedAudience:
The presentation is suitable for all Java developers. Attendees should preferably have some experience with debugging. 
The presentation will be based on live debugging.
sessions.abstract:
If you really want to find out what goes on inside your Java application, then the debugger is your best choice. 
Are you aware of all the things modern debuggers can do?
With recent Java language advances such as lambdas, and rapid improvements by the IDE vendors it is a good time to revisit Java debugging.   
We will go through some common use cases and solve them using debugging features and strategies in IntelliJ IDEA and Eclipse:
Smart breakpoints and stepping, lambdas, monitoring classes and instances, concurrency, etc.
So come along for some debugger magic!
sessions.title: Java Debugging Tricks

speakers.name: Martin Skarsaune
speakers.bio: Martin is a passionate software developer working for Kantega AS. His primary interest is the core Java platform and tools.

sessions.intendedAudience: Android-utviklere som ønsker å lage robuste applikasjoner. Noe erfaring med automatisert testing er en fordel. Code in slides.
sessions.abstract: Espresso er et testrammeverk for å enkelt skrive UI-tester for Android-applikasjoner uten for mye boilerplate. Jeg gir en kjapp intro til hvordan du også kan komme i gang med å skrive automatiserte tester for å forhindre uventet oppførsel for brukere av appen din.
sessions.title: UI-testing på Android med Espresso

speakers.name: Sindre Nordbø
speakers.bio:
Systemutvikler og medlem av mobil-faggruppen i BEKK. Lagde sin første Android-app i 2010.

Hvis jeg ikke programmerer er jeg sannsynligvis på en fotballstadion som syngende Rosenborg-supporter.

sessions.intendedAudience:
developers, architects and ops people looking to find pragmatic solutions and inspiration for adopting continuous delivery in a setting where this is difficult.

basic knowledge of infrastructure, network components and java application server deployment logistics is a benefit, but not required. The presentation will contain small parts of code in slides.
sessions.abstract:
The literature and blogosphere around continuous delivery is littered with shining examples describing DevOps teams, container technologies, cloud platforms and green-field implementations. At Storebrand, our challenge was slightly different: We had an existing legacy of monolithic applications, cumbersome platforms, third-party operations teams, ITIL-heavy change processes and heavily orchestrated releases. We wanted something better, but could not throw away what we had and start again. Nor did we have any budgets or executive sponsors.

This talk will relay the story of how we moved into the world of continuous delivery one step at a time, without large rewrites or interruptions of ongoing projects. It will be a story of how ideal solutions seldom match the real-life requirements of an existing architecture, and how these can be overcome if you apply creativity, opportunism and a little bit of patience. We will also demonstrate how a loosely coupled and simplistic architecture can provide more flexibility than relying too much on a single tool or technology.
sessions.title: Continuous Delivery in a 250-year old company

speakers.name: Terje Løken
speakers.bio:
Former C++ developer and chief architect, now unit manager for the Digital & Mobile unit @ Storebrand. I like to figure out how things work, and implement changes rather than talk about them.

I also have a fondness for pragmatic solutions, grassroots activism and incremental change. I consider patience, good timing and judgement equally important as technical mastery when evolving an architecture.

sessions.intendedAudience: This talk in intended for an audience interested in understanding how their application works. As with any other performance related-talk this will be a deep dive in the JVM internals, however there is no prerequisite knowledge required to understand the content. No live coding, only code on slides.
sessions.abstract: The just-in-time compilers Java Virtual Machines make sure that the java code you wrote runs as fast as possible and that the various checks implicitly imposed by the standard do not compromise the performance. Many optimizations are speculative and profile driven. What happens to the code when the assumption becomes incorrect? This talk will cover the lifecycle of a program execution in a JVM, talk specifically about the speculative optimizations and how the JIT compiler “may get it wrong”.
sessions.title: Continuous Java program transformations

speakers.name: Ivan Krylov
speakers.bio: Ivan Krylov is a lead developer at Azul Systems, working on Zing JVM, co-author of the JEP-285 and implementor of the ObjectLayout prototype. Ivan has been in JVM development since 2005. Previous experience includes the Hotspot Runtime development and the JIT compiler work for the HSA/OpenCL stack.

sessions.intendedAudience: This talk is for developers  who prefer static types checking, compiler errors and don't feel good at dynamic languages world. I'll show that there is a way to bring more sanity to Javascript development by introducing Typescript which feels incredibly familiar to Java devs. There will be lot of code samples and some simle live coding.
sessions.abstract: We all at least heard of this language called Javascript, created in mythical 10 days with it's famous  bad and good parts. It usually feels weird and uneasy to seasoned Java/JVM developers if one has to deal with it: no compiler safety-net, no types checking, prototypal inheritance, unexpected runtime errors etc. Truth is these days Javascript is everywhere and it really pays off to be able to work on this platform. But what to do if you  feel really uncomfortable with the language itself? Meet Typescript and feel at home: compiler, types, class-based inheritance, interfaces, generics and other goodies. I'll show and try to convince you that writing client stuff as well as solid backends in Typescript can feel familiar to Java/JVM developers, be productive and fun.
sessions.title: Typescript - now you have no more excuses.

speakers.name: Michał Ostruszka
speakers.bio: Seasoned full-stack developer, in love with building things for web since beginning of his developer career. Coding in Scala, JS/Typescript and Clojure(Script) together with awesome crew at SoftwareMill, learning new things every day. Speaker and active member of local Java/JVM and Javascript groups, conference speaker at Confitura, Geecon, Agile by Example, 4Developers. Founder of Łódź meet.js developers meetups. Privately husband, father of two and amateur runner.

sessions.intendedAudience:
Alle som er interessert i automatisert testing og kodekvalitet.
Ingen kode.
sessions.abstract:
Akademia forsyner industrien med noen unge, håpefulle hvert år. Noen av dem kommer fra Westerdals Oslo ACT. Ved Westerdals innførte vi en endring for et par år siden. Fra å tidligere undervise automatisert testing krever vi nå automatiserte tester til java-koden studentene leverer. Testingen har blitt en naturlig del av vurderingsgrunnlaget.

Hvis vi gir samme oppgave til to grupper studenter, men kun den ene gruppen har krav til testedekning. Hvilke utslag gir det? Det vet vi, for vi har det nødvendige kodegrunnlaget, og vi har analysert koden via SonarQube. Du vet også snart dette, hvis du møter opp på denne lyntalen.
sessions.title: Juniorene kommer!

speakers.name: Per Lauvås
speakers.bio:
Tidligere utvikler (2004-2013). Hovedsakelig Java.
Er nå ansvarlig for programmeringsprogrammet ved Westerdals Oslo ACT, og underviser Java, database og prosjektmetodikk.
Er for tiden veldig interessert i programmeringsdidaktikk og kunnskapsdeling.

sessions.intendedAudience: Utviklere som vil bli bedre på estimater, og alle som vil forstå litt om hvorfor vi så ofte tar feil.
sessions.abstract:
Estimering ER vanskelig. Selv om du sverger til  #noestimates estimerer du alltid noe uansett, og da er det jo bedre om de er litt mer riktige.

Noe av det som gjør det vanskelig er hvordan vi lurer oss selv, men med litt innsikt i hvordan hodene våre virker trenger du ikke å være så lettlurt lengre.

Kom for å få litt innsikt i ditt eget hode og hvordan du kan slutte å lure deg selv, basert på David Kahnemans prisbelønnede bok "Thinking, fast and slow".
sessions.title: "Estimating, fast and slow"

speakers.name: Håvard Wigtil
speakers.bio: Håvard jobber som programvareutvikler i Kantega AS, der han overrasker seg selv ved å treffe på sine egne estimater. Han har også bommet på estimater siden 90-tallet, selv med et halvt årsstudie i psykologi.

sessions.intendedAudience:
Code in slides!
The audience will need to have to past experience with building concurrent apps in Java.
sessions.abstract:
Exploring novel message passing data structures outside the JDK and what they offer in terms of usage patterns, performance and possibilities. We'll be looking at:
* JCTools queues: placing limitations on producer/consumer counts
* Disruptor: building a pipeline of workers on top of a pre-allocated buffer
* Aeron IPC: offheap, cross platform (Java/Native), binary message passing
* JCTools Proxy Channels: Proxy calls to other threads using custom-generated queues
sessions.title: Beyond Qs: Novel Concurrent Message Passing Techniques

speakers.name: Nitsan Wakart
speakers.bio: A blogger and a coder with a pedantic passion for performance. My work has spanned army intelligence systems, dot.com era startups, financial institutions and innovative product companies. The Lead Performance Eng. for Azul Systems by day (working on Zing, best JVM ever :-)), main contributor to lock free data structures library JCTools by night.

sessions.intendedAudience: Dette er presentasjonen for de fleste utviklere som har med frontend å gjøre. Dersom man ikke er oppdatert får man oppfordring til modernisering, dersom man er erfaren og fremoverlent kan man få oppfordring til å tenke seg ekstra godt om. Det inneholder litt kode, men man trenger ikke å forholde seg til det.
sessions.abstract:
Det er lite tvil om at det har skjedd mye i frontend-verden de siste 10 årene. Særlig er dette merkbart i JavaScript. Etter at vi har bevegd oss fra tynne til tykke klienter, har vi gått igjennom en transformering som har betydd høy innovasjon, stor grad av utforsking og iterativt arbeid. Det har virket for mange som det er umulig å følge med i frontend-verden og vanskelig å vite hvilke valg man skal ta.

Denne presentasjonen skal prøve å overbevise deg om at JavaScript-frykt ikke er en ting de fleste burde bekymre seg over. På samme måte som vi har smidig og utforskende arbeid på produkter, har vi det og på utvikling av økosystem og teknologier, og man kan fint få gevinsten av det uten å måtte ofre mye.

Vi vil gå igjennom historie og utviklingen av språket, utviklingen av økosystem og fellesskapet for å skjønne hvordan ting henger sammen og for å se at det ikke nødvendigvis er slik at alle må være med på all utvikling som foregår. Vi vil også se hvordan et moderne prosjekt ser ut i 2016 og hvorfor det ikke trenger å være så skremmende.
sessions.title: Frontend Anno 2016: Exploration and Iteration

speakers.name: Mikael Brevik
speakers.bio: Mikael har hatt en fascinasjon av JavaScript i store deler av sitt voksne liv og er i dag fagleder for frontend i BEKK Trondheim. Han er og en ivrig Open Source-utvikler, Meetup Organizer for BartJS i Trondheim og er i gang med Norges foreløpig eneste månedlige JavaScript Podcast.

sessions.intendedAudience: No code
sessions.abstract:
Det er viktig å ha riktig redskap når en jobb skal utføres.  Likevel selges det stort sett bare tastatur som baserer seg på et over 100 år gammelt design. Et design som var tilpasset skrivemaskiner, og ikke utvikling av programvare i et moderne IDE. 

Jeg vil gå gjennom hva jeg mener er galt med vanlige tastatur, og vise til alternative  tastatur og tastaturoppsett for utviklere.
sessions.title: Alternative tastatur og tastaturoppsett for utviklere

speakers.name: Joar Aurdal
speakers.bio: Joar er en entusiastisk utvikler med 15 års erfaring fra komplekse  javabaserte prosjekter i offentlig og privat sektor. Han har gjennom hele sin karriere hatt et sterkt engasjement for hvordan utviklingen gjøres i prosjektene han har deltatt i, både med tanke på teknologier, verktøy og prosesser.

sessions.intendedAudience: Intermediate, Slides + Live Coding
sessions.abstract:
Generics are one of the most complex features of Java. They are often poorly understood and lead to confusing errors. Unfortunately, it won’t get easier. Java 10, release planned for 2018, extends Generics. It’s now time to understand generics or risk being left behind.

We start by stepping back into the halcyon days of 2004 and explain why generics were introduced in the first place back. We also explain why Java’s implementation is unique compared to similar features in other programming languages.

Then we travel to the present to explaining how to make effective use of Generics. We then explore various entertaining code examples and puzzlers of how Generics are used today.

Finally, this talk sheds light on the planned changes in Java 10 with practical code examples and related ideas from other programming languages. If you ever wanted to understand the buzz around higher kinded types or declaration site variance now is your chance!
sessions.title: Generics: Past, Present and Future

speakers.name: Richard Warburton
speakers.bio: Richard is an empirical technologist and solver of deep-dive technical problems and works independently as a Software Engineer and Trainer. Recently he has written a book on Java 8 Lambdas for O’Reilly and helps developers learn via http://iteratrlearning.com and http://www.pluralsight.com/author/richard-warburton. He’s worked as a developer in diverse areas including Statistical Analytics, Static Analysis, Compilers and Network Protocols. He is a leader in the London Java Community. Richard is also a well known conference speaker, having talked at Devoxx, JavaOne, QCon SF, JFokus, Devoxx UK, Geecon, Oredev, JAX London, JEEConf and Codemotion. He obtained a PhD in Computer Science from The University of Warwick.

sessions.intendedAudience: This talk is intended for developers, however, there is no requirements to watching the talk.
sessions.abstract: We learn and evolve as projects goes on, so does our codestyle and what we view as best practices. It is fairly common to use linters to enforce a certain code style within a project. The problem arises when we want to add a new rule, but the codebase already breaks this in thousands places from before. How do you tackle that? Especially when there is that deadline coming up. This talk proposes a way to use you version control system to help decide which lint errors should be taken into account or not and that way making it possible to gradually evolve your linter rules.
sessions.title: Enforcing codestyle changes over time

speakers.name: Rolf Erik Lekang
speakers.bio: Developer at Itera, works mostly with JavaScript. Enjoying life with good books and great coffee. Also tries to capture great moments with my camera.

sessions.intendedAudience: Denne lyntalen er for for deg som er inspirert til å hjelpe, men synes open source er litt stort og skummelt.
sessions.abstract: "Feel free to submit a pull request". Noen vil kalle det en invitasjon, men for mange er det vanskelig og skummelt. Denne lyntalen vil gi en rask introduksjon til hvor enkelt, ufarlig, og givende kan være å gi tilbake til miljøet.
sessions.title: Din første pull request

speakers.name: Jørgen Aaberg
speakers.bio: Jørgen jobber som konsulent for Iterate. Spesielt interessert i JavaScript og Lean Startup. Ellers glad i løping og en god kopp kaffe.

sessions.intendedAudience: Utviklere. No code.
sessions.abstract: Er byggserveren din full av håndskreven konfigurasjon, manuelt installerte plugins og så høy kompleksitet at bare et fåtall kan administrere den? Hør erfaringene rundt å få Jenkins og slaver til å kjøre på Docker med all konfigurasjon under kildekontroll, hvordan vi åpner opp for alle, spawner nye slaver uten anstrengelse og lar byggserveren redeploye seg selv!
sessions.title: Selvbyggende byggserver med Docker på SpareBank 1

speakers.name: Mads Mobæk
speakers.bio: Mads har en bred interesse for alle aspekter av digitale løsninger, fra strategi til konsept og til hovedtyngden som han har på teknologi. Til daglig jobber han med problemstillinger rundt digitalisering hos BEKK og BEKKs kunder.

sessions.intendedAudience: Utvecklare, no code.
sessions.abstract:
Hvordan utvikler man lokalt på et komplisert distribuert system uten å være avhengig av manuelt konfigurerte testmiljøer.

La frontend-utviklere kode frontend uten å måtte bygge backend-kode. 

Vær fleksibel på hvilke deler av det distribuerte systemet som kjøres lokalt og hvilke som kjører på delte miljøer.

Med en lokal DNS server er det mulig å bruke systemet på flere forskjellige måter - uten å ta noe opp og ned.
I talken ser vi nærmere på hvordan noen enkle Docker image konvensastioner og HAProxy kan realisere og sette opp en komplisert infrastruktur lokalt og på utviklerens arbeidsstasjon.
sessions.title: “Jeg vil bare lage internett!”. Hvordan bruker vi Docker i utviklingsmiljøet hos SpareBank 1 for å kjøre komplisert infrastruktur.

speakers.name: Stian Conradsen
speakers.bio:
Utvikler med stor interesse for koding, automatisering og forenkling. Er også opptatt av å bruke ressursene riktig og at man løser det faktiske problemet. 
Jobber i dag for SpareBank 1 hvor jeg med på å bygge en distribuert arkitektur og bygge opp team. 
Holdt foredraget Breaking the Monolith @ SpareBank 1 på JavaZone i fjor.

sessions.intendedAudience: The target audience is developers who are interested in improving their coding craft and looking to reason more clearly about their coding style and design. There will be code in slides using Java and a few other JVM languages.
sessions.abstract:
It is very easy to get stuck in one way of doing things. This is as true of programming as it is of life. Although a programming paradigm represents a set of stylistic choices, it is much more than this: a programming paradigm also represents a way of thinking. Having only way to think about problems is too limiting. A programming paradigm represents a set of patterns of problem framing and solving and contains the ingredients of software architecture. As Émile Auguste Chartier noted, there is nothing more dangerous than an idea when you have only one idea.

Perhaps even more problematic than being stuck with a narrow view of paradigms, is being stuck with a dysfunctional view of each paradigm. For instance, many developers working in languages and frameworks that support object orientation lack a strong idea of the principles of interaction, data abstraction and granularity that support an effective view of OO, and instead surround themselves with manager objects, singletons and DTOs.

This session explores the strengths and weaknesses of different programming styles, patterns and paradigms in Java and other JVM languages.
sessions.title: Paradigms Lost, Paradigms Regained: Programming with Objects and Functions and More

speakers.name: Kevlin Henney
speakers.bio: Kevlin is an independent consultant, trainer and writer based in the UK. His development interests are in patterns, programming, practice and process. He has been a columnist for various magazines and web sites and is co-author of A Pattern Language for Distributed Computing and On Patterns and Pattern Languages, two volumes in the Pattern-Oriented Software Architecture series. He is also editor of the 97 Things Every Programmer Should Know.

sessions.intendedAudience:
This talk is for a developer with some experience, who has to come up with better ways to solve technical problems. Middle level and up.
The whole talk is live coding
sessions.abstract:
Although the JVM takes care of cleaning up memory for you, it is still your responsibility to clean other types of resources after usage, such as file handlers, open streams, native resources etc. Usually the first cleaning method that comes to mind is the finalization mechanism. But as it often happens, the first thought is a wrong one.

In this talk I will review several methods of cleaning up unused resources: autoclosables, “wrap your lambda”, finalisers, reference queues and Cleaner classes. I will demonstrate how to use all of them and will talk about the pros and cons of each of them.
sessions.title: You use it, you clean it

speakers.name: Nikita Salnikov-Tarnovski
speakers.bio: Nikita is the co-founder of Plumbr, the JVM performance monitoring product, where he now contributes as core developer. Besides his daily technical tasks of solving various problems, he is an active blogger, 3 times JavaOne RockStar and frequent conference speaker  (JavaOne, Devoxx, GeeCON, TopConf, JFokus, GeekOut, Joker, JPoint, Jazoon, JEEConf etc).

sessions.intendedAudience: Developers new to RxJava or having very little experience, but willing to experiment with it. No slides, only live coding.
sessions.abstract:
If you ever approached RxJava before you might come to a conclusion that this library solves problems most of us don't have. Reactively composing streams of data, virtual time, marble diagrams and event-driven programming - where most of our code is pretty much just transferring data from database to presentation layer.

During this live coding session for Rx beginners and intermediates there will not be a single slide, we start with empty IDE to step-by-step implement key constructs in RxJava. Most importantly we will discover how this high-level abstraction can help in existing projects. When to use RxJava, what problems does it solve and when using it is an excess of form over substance.

We will learn how to build highly reliable and concurrent applications, improve throughput and resource utilization without hurting readability and avoiding  complexity.
sessions.title: RxJava in legacy projects

speakers.name: Tomasz Nurkiewicz
speakers.bio:
Spent half of his life on programming, for the last decade professionally in Java land. Loves back-end, tolerates JavaScript. Passionate about alternative JVM languages. Disappointed with the quality of software written these days (so often by himself!), hates long methods and hidden side effects. Interested in charting, data analysis and reporting. Believes that computers were invented so that developers can automate boring and repetitive tasks. Also their own.

On a daily basis works in financial sector. Involved in open-source, DZone’s Most Valuable Blogger, used to be very active on StackOverflow. Author, trainer, conference speaker, technical reviewer, runner. Claims that code not tested automatically is not a feature but just a rumour. Currently writing a book "Reactive Programming with RxJava" for O'Reilly.

sessions.intendedAudience: For utviklere. Kode i slider
sessions.abstract:
Sikkerhet og autentisering er vanskelig å gjøre riktig, og i en moderne verden kanskje viktigere enn noensinne. JSON Web Tokens er en ny teknologi som enkelt lar deg sende informasjon mellom to parter på en sikker og tilstandsløs måte. Informasjonen sendes som en rekke påstander som kan inneholde all nødvendig informasjon  om en bruker, noe som blant annet eliminerer behovet for databaseoppslag.

Jeg har jobbet med JWTer på prosjekt en god periode. Kom og hør hvordan du kan komme i gang og hva jeg har lært.
sessions.title: En introduksjon til JWT

speakers.name: Øyvind Tangen
speakers.bio:
Øyvind er ansatt som utvikler i BEKKs teknologiavdeling og jobber til daglig som konsulent på prosjekt i bank- og forsikringsbransjen.

Han er opptatt av mobilutvikling, personvern og å velge riktig verktøy for jobben som skal gjøres.

sessions.intendedAudience:
No code
No coding experiance required
sessions.abstract:
Have you ever wondered how you can modify your own body with technology? That is, enabling your own body to interact directly with the increasingly modern world? Today, everybody can be a cyborg – this talk will show you how. 

We will take a closer look at biohacking and NFC implants, and demonstrate how easy and cheap it is to get started. We'll also explore some practical use cases for the technology, like authentication and information sharing, with a focus on security and privacy.
sessions.title: Biohacking, hack your body!

speakers.name: Tore Myklebust
speakers.bio: Tore is a full-stack developer at BEKK and has a passion for all kinds of technology. He likes planning  and attending  events involving programming. Tore is co-hosting Pils & Programming Oslo, a meetup which is simply about hacking while enjoying a few beers.

sessions.intendedAudience: Architects, DevOps and developers how are passionate about continuous deployments and zero downtime.
sessions.abstract: The importance of being able to do small and frequent deployments is well understood by most of us. Being able to do those deployments during daytime, without downtime, can typically be solved by so called blue-green deployments. But what if you need to do database changes in addition? Join my talk if you are keen to learn how to manage day time deployments with database changes without causing any interruptions.
sessions.title: Zero downtime continuous deployment architecture

speakers.name: Sebastian Dehne
speakers.bio: I am an enthusiastic programmer who is hopeless at accepting excellent advice from others and always has to discover things for himself first. For 20+ years I have been fascinated by computers and the stuff we can make them do. Especially distributed architectures and concurrent systems interest me the most. I am working as a consultant for Systek and am currently at the norwegian tax office (Skatteetaten), where we built awesome web- and backend applications to make the business of tax administration more efficient.

sessions.intendedAudience: Passer for alle, enten man kjenner til C++ eller ei. For deg som er opptatt av at kode skal være lett å forholde seg til. Code in slides.
sessions.abstract: Som tidligere C++-utvikler var jeg fornøyd da jeg så at Java hadde et final-keyword. Gleden var dog kortvarig da jeg fant ut hvor liten effekt final faktisk har når man jobber i en stor og gammel kodebase. C og C++ er kanskje kjent for segfaults, minnelekasjer og udefinert oppførsel, men noe har de gjort rett. I denne talken introduserer jeg C++ sitt keyword const, hvilket problem dette løser og hvorfor Java burde ha noe tilsvarende.
sessions.title: final? Gi meg const!

speakers.name: Ole Bakstad
speakers.bio: Ole er en faglig engasjert utvikler som interesserer seg for alt fra programmeringspråk til utviklingsprosesser og organisasjonskultur. Spesielt interessert i hvordan tekniske valg påvirker måten man jobber på, jobbhverdagen til de ansatte og evnen til å skape verdi over tid. Jobber i dag som konsulent i Knowit, men har bakgrunn fra embedded programmering og signalbehandling.

sessions.intendedAudience: For alle som er interessert i åpne data og ITS. Og for utviklere som ønsker å berike sine applikasjoner med åpne lokasjonsbestemte data. Litt kode i slides.
sessions.abstract:
ITS, intelligent transport systems, handler om å gjøre transport mer effektivt, sikkert og miljøvennlig. Data fra sensorer langs veien, kombinert med data fra biler og verden rundt, gjør det mulig for deg å bygge nye og spennende tjenester. Det finnes mange datasett med slik data fritt tilgjengelig for deg å bruke.

Statens vegvesen er en av de største leverandørene av åpne lokasjonsbestemte ITS-data. Vi vil vise deg hvordan du gjennom APIer kan få tilgang til data om sanntids trafikkmeldinger, reisetid, bomstasjoner, fartsgrenser, webkameraer og mye mer.

Statens vegvesen har nylig lansert en ny webbasert kartløsning. Vi vil også ta en kikk på denne løsningen, erfaringene og utfordringene fra å utvikle denne, og hvilke datasett som er brukt.
sessions.title: Åpne data i intelligente transportsystemer

speakers.name: Jørgen Abrahamsen
speakers.bio:
Jørgen er en erfaren, entusiastisk og engasjert programvareutvikler med en brennende lidenskap for kvalitet og brukbarhet i håndtverket han utfører til daglig. Å sette sammen åpne data for å lage nyttige applikasjoner har blitt en besettelse for ham.

Jørgen har jobbet med tilgjengeliggjøring og bruk av åpne data for flere virksomheter i offentlig sektor, blant annet Statens vegvesen.

speakers.name: Trond Smaavik
speakers.bio:
Trond er en spesialist på åpne data med spesiell kunnskap om intelligente transportsystemer (ITS) og ITS-data. Er det noe du vil vite om åpne datasett? Sjansene er gode for at han kan gi deg en datakilde eller vet hvem du bør ta kontakt med.

Trond har jobbet med tilgjengeliggjøring og bruk av åpne data for flere virksomheter i offentlig sektor, blant annet Statens vegvesen.

sessions.intendedAudience: Attend this session if you dream about creating persuasive design sketches and maybe want to test out your ideas without any coding.  You're also welcome if you're simply looking to impress your co-workers with some Keynote ninja skills
sessions.abstract:
Keynote is awesome - no wonder Google Venture uses it for prototyping!

Faced with the daunting task of designing a responsive Html5 authoring interface for an Open Source CMS, we had no designers on the team - just a CTO that knew Keynote.

This talk will show you how to create powerful and persuasive webapp  "foilware" with Keynote. How this can be used for basic user tests and finally as input to your developers. You should be able to pick up some ninja tricks on the way.

In the end we'll take you through the various stages of designing and implementing our own application - and finally check out the live result!
sessions.title: Building software with Keynote

speakers.name: Thomas Lund Sigdestad
speakers.bio: CTO and product architect @ Enonic. Father of two, husband of one. Dropped out of university master studies 16 years ago to start my own company, and never looked back!

sessions.intendedAudience: Intended for Devs and/or Ops, or anyone interested in how they can work together. Some Gherkin in sliders.
sessions.abstract:
As one way of bringing the Ops closer to the Devs, we're using Cucumber to describe our systems from an operations perspective. Which application is dependent on which? How are they configured? How should they behave in network outages? It's all in the Gherkin.

This talk summarises what we've learned from doing this, and helps you get started too.
sessions.title: Behaviour-Driven DevOps

speakers.name: Magnus Reftel
speakers.bio: Currently at the Norwegian Tax Office in a DevOpsy role, previously at Spotify and ST-Ericsson. Coder since the '90s. Habitual automator. Cucumber fan.

sessions.intendedAudience:
Både utviklere som har havnet i "testdatagjørma", utviklere som synes at testdata skal håndteres i kode og testere/teknisk testere vil ha utbytte av foredraget. Foredraget vil starte med en introduksjon til Cucumber, slik at også de uten erfaring med rammeverket vil få utbytte.

Alle kodeeksempler vil selvsagt være i Java.
sessions.abstract:
GITT tilstrekkelig mye testdata
OG la de modes godt en god periode
NÅR testdataene så må endres litt
SÅ er det ingen som tør å gjøre det

Har du hørt om Cucumber? Cucumber (https://cucumber.io/) er et testverktøy som eksekverer en spesifikasjon skrevet i et naturlig (f.eks norsk) språk, f.eks slik som over. Cucumber kan hjelpe deg i å etablere et felles språk mellom utviklere, domeneeksperter og testere, og få alle til å skrive spesifikasjoner som du som utvikler kan kjøre for å teste om systemet ditt oppfyller kravene.

Som i alle tester er det noen forutsetninger som må være på plass før testene kan kjøre. Vanligvis løser vi disse forutsetningene enten med mocking eller med testdata. Felles for begge er at det gir oss kontroll på omgivelsene i testen, men erfaringsmessig mister vi fort kontroll på både testdata og mock'er. Testdata ligger i verste fall i sql-filer eller i flate filer, mocker er jo bare "testkode" og mangler både planlegging og struktur.

I dette foredraget vil jeg foreslå en måte hvor Cucumber kan brukes ikke bare til å skrive testene dine, men også hvordan du kan få hjelp til å håndtere testdata vha. Cucumber. Og husk, testdata er ikke bare data for de automatiske testene dine, manuelle tester fortjener minst like god håndtering og kontroll av testdata.
sessions.title: Hva har agurk og testdata til felles?

speakers.name: Torstein Strøm
speakers.bio: Torstein er hands-on arkitekt, innvikler og medeier i Kantega AS, og har 15 års erfaring fra prosjekter fra 1 til 150 personer. Han forsøker å unngå samme feil mer enn to ganger, denne gangen er det testdata som skal til pers.

sessions.intendedAudience: Du kan med fordel ha erfaring fra å lese og kommentere på andres kode, men ledere som tenker at kodegransking er for dyrt oppfordres spesielt til å komme! Det blir vist veldig enkle kodeeksempler.
sessions.abstract: Å granske hverandres kode kan avsløre feil, men jeg vil argumentere for at det er mange flere fordeler. Kunnskapsdeling og felles eierskap er vel så viktig. På 20 minutter vil jeg fortelle hvorfor alle i teamet bør lese alles kode, og hva som skal til for at dette er verdt tidsbruken. Jeg vil ta for meg viktigheten av verktøystøtte, konvensjoner i koden, så vel som kulturelle faktorer for at granskingen blir en konstruktiv dialog.
sessions.title: Tips for knallbra kodegransk

speakers.name: Anders Båtstrand
speakers.bio: Anders er utvikler og med-eier i Kantega AS, og har 7 års erfaring fra mange forskjellige kodebaser og team. Han liker å lese all kode som teamet hans produserer, og har de siste årene erfart at dette er vel anvendt tid.

sessions.intendedAudience:
Alle som ønsker å oppdage bugs så tidlig som mulig. De som brenner for kodekvalitet og ønsker bedre oversikt over kodebasen.

Code in slides.
sessions.abstract:
Til tross for at vi utviklere gjør det beste vi kan når vi skriver kode, sniker det seg inn bugs fra tid til annen. I verste fall kan disse skape problemer i produksjon, så vi ønsker å oppdage og luke dem ut så fort som mulig. Ved bruk av statisk kodeanalyse kan vi gå gjennom kodebasen og finne ting som ser rart, misvisende eller tilogmed riv ruskende feil ut.

SonarQube er et av de mest utbredte verktøyene for statisk kodeanalyse i Java-økosystemet og kan hjelpe oss identifisere en rekke problemer i koden vi har skrevet. Vi tar en titt på noen av disse problemene og hvordan vi raskt kan oppdage og adressere dem.

Vi ser også hvordan du kan definere egne regelsett og få varsel når det blir oppdaget nye problemer i kodebasen.
sessions.title: Finn bugs automatisk med SonarQube

speakers.name: Hans Joachim Desserud
speakers.bio: Java-utvikler og arkitekt hos Sopra Steria.

sessions.intendedAudience: Grunnleggende forståelse av REST API-er. Code in slides.
sessions.abstract: I starten av 2015 viste Facebook fram hvordan de har løst noen av problemene med REST API-er - blant annet mange kall mellom klient og server for kompliserte datastrukturer og henting av datafelter man kanskje ikke trenger. De har utviklet en ny måte å utveksle data mellom klient og server - nemlig med noe som kalles GraphQL. Hva er det? Hvordan fungerer det? Hvilke problemer løser det?
sessions.title: GraphQL > REST API?

speakers.name: Henrik Glasø Skifjeld
speakers.bio: Utvikler i Iterate. Veldig interessert i tech. Liker å holde meg oppdatert, særlig på frontend og JavaScript.

sessions.intendedAudience:
Alle som vil lære seg TypeScript eller Angular2. 
"Live coding"
sessions.abstract:
Har du noen gang tenkt at feilmeldingen kunne vært bedre enn "Undefined is not a function"? Har du savnet god IDE-støtte for frontend-utvikling? Da er denne workshoppen midt i blinken for deg! Kom og se hvordan man lager en komponent-basert Angular 2 applikasjon og hvor bra utvikler-opplevelesen kan bli når du har ordentlig type-system fra TypeScript som IDEen støtter. Vi deler våre egne erfaringer fra prosjekter med TypeScript og Angular 2, viser hvor enkelt det er å komme i gang, og hvordan man unngår de vanligste fellene når kodebasen din vokser.
Veien fra Java til TypeScript er kortere enn du tror!
sessions.title: Angular2 med TypeScript

speakers.name: Simo Martomaa
speakers.bio: Simo er en erfaren arkitekt og utvikler i Kantega. Han har gått hele runden fra statisk typet back-end til dynamisk typet front-end, og tilbake.

speakers.name: Johannes Harestad
speakers.bio: Johannes jobber som iOS- og frontend-utvikler i Kantega. Han er blitt en ivrig pådriver av TypeScript og Angular etter gode erfaringer i prosjekter.

sessions.intendedAudience: Utviklere og tech leads som har litt for enkel tilgang til Elasticsearch og dermed gjerne fikler litt for mye med innholdet slik at de litt fortere enn de aner får bruk for å kjøre restore fra den backupen de burde ha satt opp.
sessions.abstract: Backup av data i Elasticsearch gjøres via snapshot/restore API-et som lover deg inkrementelle backups av dine data. Men hva foregår egentlig i bakgrunnen og hvordan kan du faktisk hente data tilbake igjen fra dine snapshots? Har du noen gang prøvd? Vi ser på Elasticsearchs API for snapshot/restore og viser strategier for å faktisk hente data tilbake igjen når du trenger det - ehh, da vi trengte det - og uten at noen merker noe.
sessions.title: Kan du få data tilbake igjen fra dine Elasticsearch snapshots?

speakers.name: Jan Fredrik Wedén
speakers.bio:
Jan Fredrik jobber som utvikler i BEKK og har over 15 års erfaring innen systemutvikling. Han jobber til daglig med prosjekter som samler inn og behandler store datamengder og benytter Elasticsearch til lagring og analyse av informasjonen.

På fritiden har han stor interesse for bratt friluftsliv og er gjerne å finne på et fjell med ski under bena, klatrende i en fjellvegg eller syklende der motoriserte kjøretøy sjelden kommer frem.

sessions.intendedAudience: This lightning talk is for developers and architects alike. Too often in the field we over complicate our solutions. Simple problems are solved in the most extreme ways that hinder maintenance in the long run. Unnecessary complexity is added to simple domains which creates steep learning curves for new developers and maintainers of code. This lightning talk, in a sarcastic approach, attempts to demonstrate how damaging and destructive overengineering actually is.
sessions.abstract:
Let's use the hottest and greatest technologies. Let's solve a simple problem in the most complex way. Let's add more and more layers to our architecture. Let's call all code which is 3 months or older, legacy. Got domain specific problems? No problem, just throw new tech at it!

Because hey, why not?
sessions.title: Let's overengineer the hell out of this

speakers.name: Sirar Salih
speakers.bio: Sirar Salih is a technical lead working at If P&C Insurance, the largest insurance company in Scandinavia. He is a board member of the Norwegian .NET User Group and the Oslo chapter. He is also co-founder of the AngularJS Oslo user group and organizer of the annual Arctic IoT Challenge in Oslo. Sirar loves holding presentations and has experience from speaking at international conferences such as the Norwegian Developers Conference, JavaZone, Trondheim Developer Conference and HTML5 Developer Conference in San Francisco. He actively contributes to the open source community through his blog; https://sirarsalih.com/ and GitHub; https://github.com/sirarsalih.

sessions.intendedAudience: Software developers that works in teams
sessions.abstract:
Every software team writes code, but some teams produce fewer bugs than others. Every software team creates new features, but some teams develop them faster than others. What do high performance teams do differently, and why are team members more focused, satisfied and relaxed? They truly work together. No 10x rockstar programmer can achieve what a well rounded, enthusiastic team can.
Sven Peters examines how the best software teams set and follow goals, integrate new members fast, ensure diversity, monitor and continually improve team health, embrace transparency, create new processes, use a playbook to guide them through every phase of development and even develop creative & flexible work spaces for multidisciplinary projects. He shares techniques including: sparring, OKRs, feature buddies, open demos, focus weeks and many more that help teams and team members to work more effectively together, and produce awesome results.
sessions.title: The Secret Sauce of Successful Teams

speakers.name: Sven Peters
speakers.bio: Sven is a software geek working as an Evangelist for Atlassian. He started with Java development in 1998 and has been programming for longer that he'd like to admit. Besides coding his passion is getting the right tools into the hands of those who need it to help build fast moving, agile, autonomous teams and getting them to kick-ass. Sven has extensive speaking experience in 25+ countries on myriad topics.

sessions.intendedAudience: Developers and Devops.  This is heavy code.  Docker and internet access is required.
sessions.abstract:
The popularity of Docker as a micro-services tool has many organizations looking to put docker into production. With years of experience working with leading edge organizations, this workshop will not only teach Docker, but will provide real-world advice on how to work with Docker for production.

This session is a workshop and as such you will need to come with a laptop with Docker 1.10+ installed. The training and labs will include:

Docker basics
Container lifecycles
Build files
Working with the Registry
Working with the docker machine
Docker compose 
This will include the dos and don'ts for a production environment.
The session will end with standing up a Mesos / Marathon environment for scaling out a docker instance. Time allowing the bonus lab is standing up Kubernetes to run Docker instances.
sessions.title: Advanced Docker Workshop

speakers.name: Ken Sipe
speakers.bio: Ken Sipe is a Cloud Solution Architect at Mesosphere, focused on helping companies simplify the development and operation of large scale infrastructure and distributed systems with Apache Mesos and the new Datacenter OS.   As a JavaOne Rockstar, Ken is an author and award winning international speaker on the practices of software architecture and engineering, continuous delivery and agile practices.   Ken is also an Apache Mesos contributor and an Apache committer on the Myriad, HDFS, Cassandra and Kafka Apache Mesos framework projects.

sessions.intendedAudience: The exercises material will be available in both Scala and Java.  The attendees should be able to code in either Scala or Java at an intermediate level.
sessions.abstract:
Building mission critical data pipelines provides business with the unique advantage of providing real time analytics of all of the data flowing through the enterprise.  This gives them the ability to get hands on with the data to make more intelligent decisions.

There are several core principles for building data pipelines for mission critical applications.  The first is to to ensure the integrity of the data ingested so that no data is loss.  This ensures that accurate and high quality analytics of that data.    Another core principle is to make the data pipeline resilient to failures and able to adapt to differing volumes of data and user load.  This requires each component of the pipeline be highly available, scalable to changing demands and able to apply back-pressure during peak data loads.

In this workshop we will walk through building this type of large scale, mission critical data pipeline using Kafka, Spark Streaming and Cassandra.   The workshop will start by looking at the individual technologies that make up the data pipeline.  Then we will discuss the overall architecture of the data pipeline and how to address these core principles.  Attendees will get hands on with exercises that walk through each of the pieces of the architecture.   

In the end all attendees will have the good times flowing - with a complete end to end data pipeline!
sessions.title: Let the good times flow!  Building a large scale data pipeline with, Kafka, Spark Streaming and Cassandra

speakers.name: James Ward
speakers.bio: James Ward (www.jamesward.com) is a Principal Platform Evangelist at Salesforce.com. James frequently presents at conferences around the world such as JavaOne, Devoxx, and many other Java get-togethers. Along with Bruce Eckel, James co-authored First Steps in Flex. He has also published numerous screencasts, blogs, and technical articles. Starting with Pascal and Assembly in the 80’s, James found his passion for writing code. Beginning in the 90’s he began doing web development with HTML, Perl/CGI, then Java. After building a Flex and Java based customer service portal in 2004 for Pillar Data Systems he became a Technical Evangelist for Flex at Adobe. In 2011 James became a Principal Developer Evangelist at Salesforce.com where he taught developers how to deploy apps on the cloud with Heroku. From Fall 2012 to Spring 2014 James was a Developer Advocate at Typesafe where he created Typesafe Activator and led the Reactive Software vision. James tweets as @_JamesWard and posts code at github.com/jamesward.

speakers.name: Ryan Knight
speakers.bio: Ryan Knight has 15 years of experience with building distributed systems and large-scale data centric applications with Cassandra, Spark, Java, Scala and Akka. He frequently does training and presentations at conferences around the world, such as JavaOne, Devoxx, Cassandra Summit and many other meetups and has traveled to over 15 countries. He first started Java Consulting in 1999 at the Sun Java Center and has since worked at a wide variety of companies such as Typesafe, Oracle, IBM, Intel, Tomax, Family Search and Riot Games.  He now works as an Enterprise Solution Engineer for DataStax.

sessions.intendedAudience:
Developers working with RDBMS, such as Oracle, and care about performance, should attend this presentation. The only requirement for benefiting from the presentation is that audience believe that performance is a feature, and does not happen by accident. The audience will be introduced to a method showing how to work with performance both in development, test and production.
Amount of code: "Code in slides"
sessions.abstract: Performance is not an attribute of a system, but rather an attribute of an individual user experience. Performance is all about response time, which then again is given by its code path. But how can we possibly follow the code path into the RDBMS database. The JDBC 4.1 specification together with the Oracle end-to-end metrics gives you a method to follow the code path, and to work with performance, down to a single push on a button.
sessions.title: "Performance is a feature: Instrument your code using JDBC features"

speakers.name: Lasse Jenssen
speakers.bio:
I'm an developer and database expert, focusing on performance and scalability. I have worked with database technologies for over 20 years, and I strongly believe in using the right technology for the right purpose. This could be anything from NoSQL databases such as MongoDB, Cassandra and ElasticSearch, or RDBM Systems such as MS SQL Server, PostgresSQL, MySQL, DB2 or Oracle.
