The last year I've also started to look into BigData technologies evolving around the Hadoop framework. 

I strongly believe that performance is a feature, and that programmers and system owners get the systems they deserve.

In 2015 I  became an Oracle ACE Associate, for my knowledge and contributions towards the Oracle communities.

sessions.intendedAudience: Anyone interested in the tradeoffs to consider when writing applications with some degree of concurrency.  There will be code in slides and live coding.
sessions.abstract: All hipsters know that asynchronous non-blocking code is the only way. But what does that really mean? There are many ways of writing concurrent applications. All with different tradeoffs. We wanted to find out what the best approach or approaches were, so we tried the all, so you won't have to.  We will compact our years of toil into an hour of live coding examples for you to enjoy.  Come learn from our mistakes and triumphs.  We will present you with a common problem, and several different ways to solve it.  We'll show you the benefits, the disadvantages and explanations of what is actually going on at a lower level.
sessions.title: 5 approaches to concurrency in Java - which one is the best?

speakers.name: Christin Gorman
speakers.bio: Christin has been working as a software developer for 15 years, mostly backend and mostly java.  This year she has joined the gang at KODEMAKER.  Since 2011 she has been a regular speaker at JavaZone, where her enthusiasm and strong (at times controversial) opinions have landed three of her presentations in the top 20 most viewed list.

speakers.name: Eivind Barstad Waaler
speakers.bio: Eivind has been developing Java- and JVM-based applications for over 15 years. He loves programming and is always looking for new ways to solve problems. Eivind is working as a consultant at Kodemaker and has been speaking at most JavaZone-conferences since 2003.

sessions.intendedAudience: The talk is an experience report focusing on architecture and system design, so there will be no actual code. Attendees should understand the basics of web services, threads, and databases.
sessions.abstract:
Schibsted is a global media and classified ads conglomerate with about
200 million unique users per month. The company is currently being
transformed away from traditional paper media and siloed sites toward
a unified global media giant. To do this, Schibsted needs to collect
data about user behaviour, and process this with machine learning.

This presentation is about we built Schibsted's infrastructure for
receiving and processing this behaviour data, which at the moment
comes to 700 million events per day, or 2 terabytes per day. The
presentation covers the architecture, design of individual services,
monitoring, and challenges in scaling and reliability. It also goes
into the interaction between legal privacy requirements and overall
architecture.

Key technologies used are Amazon Web Services, auto-scaling, Scala,
Datadog, Kinesis/S3, Docker, Mesos, Luigi, and Spark.
sessions.title: Collecting 700 million events a day

speakers.name: Lars Marius Garshol
speakers.bio: Lars Marius is a Staff Software Engineer at Schibsted. He was responsible for building parts of the data collection pipeline and parts of the data analytics platform. Earlier he worked as a public sector consultant at Bouvet, and on developing an enterprise data integration and search platform at Sesam. He's also been an open source developer for many, many years, and for about a decade was editor for a number of ISO standards.

sessions.intendedAudience: Developers, architects
sessions.abstract: For many years, software architecture was described as the “parts that are hard to change later”. But software architecture is the balancing of capabilities versus constraints. If build changeability one of your prime capabilities, evolutionary change becomes easier. The microservice architectural style is quite popular, but it is only one in a family of evolutionary architectures. This session defines the characteristics this family of architectural styles, along with engineering and DevOps practices necessary for implementation. I cover the principles behind evolutionary architectures, the practices needed for success, how organization and team structure affects these architectures, and specific engineer practices that facilitate evolutionary architectures. I also discuss migration strategies from common existing architectural types towards move evolutionary architectures.
sessions.title: Evolutionary Architectures

speakers.name: Neal Ford
speakers.bio: Neal Ford is Director, Software Architect, and Meme Wrangler at ThoughtWorks, a global IT consultancy with an exclusive focus on end-to-end software development and delivery. He is also the designer and developer of applications, magazine articles, video/DVD presentations, and author and/or editor of eight books spanning a variety of subjects and technologies, including the most recent Presentation Patterns and Functional Thinking. He focuses on designing and building of large-scale enterprise applications. He is also an internationally acclaimed speaker, speaking at over 300 developer conferences worldwide, delivering more than 2000 presentations. Check out his web site at nealford.com. He welcomes feedback and can be reached at nford@thoughtworks.com.

sessions.intendedAudience: This talk is suitable for developers curious about machine learning and for anyone considering using machine learning in a production system (including QA people and operations people). Slides will contain some Scala code, but Scala knowledge is not necessary.
sessions.abstract:
Taking a machine learning system from prototype to production requires a lot more than what is typically covered in an introduction to machine learning. In this talk we show how NRK built a recommender system for on-demand video streaming, taking it from an internal prototype to a service running in production. TV viewing habits are changing, and NRK needs a recommender system to stay relevant and get better use out of NRK’s content catalog. In addition to explaining the algorithms we use, we will discuss challenges around data collection, infrastructure, model management and testing.

On to the buzzwords: The system is implemented in Scala using Apache Spark. Training runs in Google Cloud Dataproc with extensive use of Google BigQuery. Recommendations are served through a Play Framework API, deployed as Docker containers running on Mesos in both a public cloud (Microsoft Azure) and a private cloud. 

Tune in to learn how you can make your system smarter by making better use of data you already have.
sessions.title: Machine learning at NRK: From prototype to production

speakers.name: Øyvind Holmstad
speakers.bio: Øyvind Holmstad is a backend developer at the Norwegian Broadcasting Corporation with a background as an IT consultant. His passion for programming comes from a desire to create great and exciting products, and at NRK he has got his wish fulfilled by working on their award-winning on-demand streaming solutions. For the last year he has been immensely enjoying working with Scala and machine learning on NRKs new recommendation system.

speakers.name: Thomas Oldervoll
speakers.bio: Thomas Oldervoll is a partner and senior consultant in Zenior, currently working for NRK as developer, data engineer and machine wrangler on their recommender system. After 7 years of being a Java developer for various customers in the Oslo region he moved to San Francisco to work for Google, where he worked on large machine learning systems for detecting blog spam and fraud. Back in Oslo he continues to learn more about ML and how to apply it to customer problems.

sessions.intendedAudience: Backend developers  that are exposed to relational and non-relational persistence technologies. Live coding.
sessions.abstract: This talk will give a broad overview of the new features introduced in the latest Spring Data release trains. We will cover recent additions and improvements in Spring Data Commons - the module that's shared amongst the store specific ones. We'll then delve into the latest and greatest features of individual store modules, like JPA, MongoDB, Neo4j, Solr and the community ones as well.
sessions.title: What's new in Spring Data?

speakers.name: Oliver Gierke
speakers.bio: Oliver Gierke is the lead of the Spring Data project at Pivotal, formerly known as SpringSource, and member of the JPA expert group. He has been into developing enterprise applications and open source projects for over 10 years now. His working focus is centered around software architecture, DDD, REST, and persistence technologies. He is regularly speaking at German and international conferences and the author of technology articles as well as the first book on Spring Data.

sessions.intendedAudience:
This talk is for anyone doing Web front-end development that is curious about alternatives to JavaScript. A basic understanding of and curiosity towards Functional Programming will probably be helpful.

Plenty of Live coding is to be expected.
sessions.abstract:
Programming a web front-end is getting increasingly more complex. Some people are boldly suggesting that JavaScript is not the ideal language to handle this complexity. A compile step is already part of the workflow for most front-end development projects, so choosing a compile to JS language shouldn't be such a big leap.

One of the many alternative languages available for the front-end that is well worth a look is Elm. Elm is a relatively young compile to JS language that has started to get quite a bit of attention in the front-end community. It is a statically typed functional language that is carefully crafted to be fun, easily approachable yet very powerful. 

In this talk you will get a quick introduction to the Elm language before diving in, to create a small sample application using Functional Reactive Programming principles. By the end of the talk you should have a better understanding of what Elm is  about and why it might be worth considering for your future web front-end projects.
sessions.title: Elm - Awesomesauce or just yet another language for the Front-end ?

speakers.name: Magnus Rundberget
speakers.bio: Magnus is a consultant working for Kodemaker. He has a background from Java, Groovy and JavaScript development. A few years ago he started to develop a keen interest for functional programming and in particular Clojure/ClojureScript. Last year he made a decision to learn more about statically typed functional languages and Elm popped up as the most interesting and approachable candidate to get started with. To get a flying start with Elm, Magnus created an Elm plugin for his favourite editor -  Light Table.  During daytime he is still developing in Groovy, Clojure and JavaScript. Evenings and nights are often spent deep diving into functional programming, blogging and developing on his Oper Source projects.

sessions.intendedAudience: This talk is for developers and architect who are deploying or looking to deploy their applications on the cloud. In this talk you'll learn about immutable infrastructure and how to solve the challenges associated your transition to get there. No code.
sessions.abstract:
The cloud is the new normal and it is time to rethink how we see machines and deployments. We have been piling layer upon layer of complexity for too long. But why should it be this way? It is time to radically simplify all this.

In this talk, we'll throw general-purpose operating systems, snowflake servers and runtime provisioning out the door. Instead you'll see how servers become disposable, how machine images are generated from scratch in seconds and how to achieve perfect environment parity from dev to prod.

This is Immutable Infrastructure. It is a profoundly important change as to how we view and treat our systems. We'll go deep. We'll look at how this affects scaling, logging, sessions, configuration, service discovery and more. We'll also look at how containers and machine images compare and why some things you took for granted may not be necessary anymore.

But beware, neither sacred cows nor kittens will be spared!
sessions.title: Immutable Infrastructure: Rise of the Machine Images

speakers.name: Axel Fontaine
speakers.bio:
Axel Fontaine is the founder and CEO of Boxfuse (boxfuse.com), the easiest way to deploy JVM and Node.js applications to AWS.

Axel is also the creator and project lead of Flyway (flywaydb.org), the open-source tool that makes database migration easy.

He is a Continuous Delivery and Immutable Infrastructure expert, a Java Champion, a JavaOne Rockstar and a regular speaker at many large international conferences including JavaOne, Devoxx, Jfokus, JavaZone, QCon, JAX, ...

You can find him online at axelfontaine.com and on Twitter as @axelfontaine

sessions.intendedAudience: The session is targeting enterprise application developers and architects. There will be a lot of live coding using and comparing different technologies.
sessions.abstract: A long time ago J2EE and especially application servers were considered to be too bloated and "heavyweight". It could be quite tedious and discouraging for developers to use that technology for developing applications. But since the name change to Java EE that assumption is not true anymore. This session shows the benefits developing against a well-established standard has, what makes a framework "lightweight" and how a lightweight yet comprehensive solution for enterprise application could look like. Most of the time will be spent live-coding and comparing different approaches.
sessions.title: Java EE - the most lightweight enterprise framework

speakers.name: Sebastian Daschner
speakers.bio:
Sebastian Daschner is a Java freelancer working as a Consultant / Software Developer / Architect and is enthusiastic about programming and Java (EE).
He is an JCP member, participating in the JSR processes and hacking on various open source projects on Github. He has been working with Java for more than 6 years. Besides Java, Sebastian is also a heavy user of Linux and container technologies like Docker. He evangelizes computer science practices on https://blog.sebastian-daschner.com and on Twitter via @DaschnerS.

sessions.intendedAudience: Denne talken er for dem som er nysgjerrige på maskinlæring og deep learning. Kanskje har man hatt grunnleggende om nevrale nettverk på skolen, evt. bare lest litt om temaet. Kanskje vet man ingenting om dem, men lurer litt på hva som foregår. Ingen kode, men masse bilder og kule eksempler.
sessions.abstract: Etter nylige innovasjoner har interessen og forskning rundt biologisk inspirerte modeller kjent som nevrale nettverk økt kraftig. Teknikkene kalles gjerne deep learning. Gjennombruddet har gitt oss state-of-the-art modeller for tale- og bildeanalyse, med språkforståelse like bak. Gigantene Google, Facebook, Baidu mfl. har hentet inn de mest kjente forskerne innen feltet. nVidia har gått all-inn, og jobber hardt for å levere teknologien som skal drive selvkjørende biler. Google sin AlphaGo har beseiret verdens beste Go-spiller. Problemer som bare mennesker kunne løse blir stadig enklere for maskinene. Jeg skal gi bittelitt historie, vise litt om hvordan disse modellene virker, vise noen kule eksempler og fortelle litt om hva som skjer ved fronten av AI.
sessions.title: Hjælp! Maskiner slår oss nå i brettspillet Go og snart kjører de bilene våre. Hvordan greier de det?

speakers.name: Ole Kristian Braut Grashei
speakers.bio: Ole har en mastergrad i Intelligente Systemer fra NTNU. Til daglig jobber han for Knowit med Java og Android. Det er derimot på kveldene den virkelige magien hender. Da henger han på r/machinelearning mens han trener siste skrik innen maskinlæringsmodeller. Målet er å alltid få litt bedre score i en eller annen maskinlæringskonkurranse på Kaggle.

sessions.intendedAudience: Beginner.  Significantly code and example driven.  All code downloadable and runnable for deeper further study.
sessions.abstract:
Java EE 7 holds two critical gems many developers never employ: CDI Scopes and Java EE Connectors. Do you have any code storing objects in hashmaps? You can kill that code with custom scopes. Need to interact with a system that doesn’t speak HTTP? Stop writing endless wrapping endpoints and just support that protocol natively with Java EE Connectors. We’ll explore both in detail through concrete and runnable code examples that will have you ready to code.

​We'll also explore the role of Functional programming in Java EE. With a mix of usable Java EE 7 and potential Java EE 8 features, we’ll take concepts like @Schedule annotations and Bean Validation and see how they might be fundamentally changed with Java 8 language enhancements like lambdas and method references.
sessions.title: Java EE, Extendable to Functional

speakers.name: David Blevins
speakers.bio: David has cofounded OpenEJB (1999), Geronimo (2003), and TomEE (2011). He is a member of the EJB 3.0, EJB 3.1, EJB 3.2, Java EE 6, Java EE 7, Java EE 8 Expert Groups and a member of the Apache Software Foundation. He is CEO and founder of Tomitribe and a veteran of open source Java EE and has been both implementing and defining Java EE specifications for more than 10 years with a strong drive to see Java EE simple, testable, and as light as Java SE. A contributing author to 'Component-Based Software Engineering: Putting the Pieces Together' (Addison Wesley), Blevins is a regular speaker at JavaOne, Devoxx, ApacheCon, OSCon, JAX and other Java-focused conferences.

sessions.intendedAudience: Audience is expected to be pro efficient in Java and have basic knowledge of Maven.  There will be code in slides and some Live coding/demos.
sessions.abstract:
Async programming is here to stay, it has proven that it can handle the load modern applications demand. Starting with async programming can be a total mind shift, once you add scaling to the equation it can get really complex! But why does it need to be so complicated?

Reactive systems are one answer, however, today we're looking for web-scale, and for this we should consider Vert.x! Vert.x is a toolkit to create distributed reactive applications on the Java Virtual Machine. It lets you build scalable applications transparently distributed in Java, JavaScript, Ruby and Groovy. You don’t have to choose a single language, just mix them!

This session explains how the simple model promoted by Vert.x enables the construction of concurrent, scalable and efficient reactive based applications.
sessions.title: Let's build a scalable async Vert.x app in < 60 min

speakers.name: Paulo Lopes
speakers.bio:
I'm Paulo and I've used my 10+ years of software development experience writing, rewriting, banging my head against the wall, editing and re-editing high-performance web application to make Vert.x an even more awesome framework. I am also the author of "yoke" and other small open source projects. I jump out of bed with a big smile on my face each morning because I know reactive applications are real and will finally put monoliths and big balls of mud to an end.

This is more than a job; I'm on a mission to build fast and faster applications!

sessions.intendedAudience: For deg som har laget et superdupert API men har fått kjeft av kollegaen din fordi han ikke vet hvordan han skal bruke API-et ditt. Code in slides.
sessions.abstract:
Det snakkes mye om API First og at API-er er løsningen på alle dine problemer, men har du noen gang forsøkt å benytte et API som ikke er dokumentert? 
I dette foredraget introduseres du til Swagger og hvordan det kan brukes til å presentere API-ene dine på en god måte. 
Vi tar en titt på Swagger UI, som hjelper deg med å utforske og teste API-ene dine. 
Avslutningsvis kommer du til å se hvordan vi har samlet all dokumentasjon fra alle våre mikrotjenester i én fin innpakning.
sessions.title: Swagger - Vis frem API-ene dine!

speakers.name: Kenneth Stigen
speakers.bio: Kenneth er seniorkonsulent i Knowit Objectnet og har jobbet som programmerer siden 2004. Han trives aller best når han får lage nye ting. Programmerer stort sett i Java, men har de siste par årene også jobbet med Scala og Python.

sessions.intendedAudience:
This presentation is targeted towards those who are in charge of maintaining a system in need of some modernisation but are not sure where to start, as well as those who are starting a new project and are interested in learning what to consider when building the project in a flexible and maintainable manner.

The concepts are programing-language agnostic, however my own experiences are based primarily in the wonderful world of Java (surprise!). There will be some code in slides.
sessions.abstract:
Just getting started with building "cloud native" applications and looking for an outline for doing it in a well structured and scalable way? Or perhaps you've inherited a more mature Web-based system that needs a kick up the bum to get it organised? If you answered yes to any of the above then the 12 Factor app methodology may be for you!

The 12 Factor methodology is a set of best practices first published by one of the founders of Heroku (the popular Platform-as-a-Service platform) covering 12 different aspects of application development that apply throughout the entire life of an application, from initial development to runtime in production. By following these guidelines you will give your application a better chance at the long and happy future that it deserves.

In this talk I will introduce each of these factors and how I have interpreted them in my own experiences developing software throughout the years.

While primarily targeted at applications that will be deployed in a cloud environment, the points covered here can be applied to any software applications which run as a service (regardless of the programming language used).
sessions.title: Give your apps the X(II) factor!

speakers.name: Gareth Western
speakers.bio: Gareth is a developer with over 12 years of experience designing and implementing "enterprise" web applications for companies around the world. He currently lives in Norway, and earns his bread and butter working as a consultant for Bouvet.

sessions.intendedAudience: Anyone interested in using Ceylon to write microservices, or Android apps. Some prior knowledge of the language would be beneficial, but is not essential.
sessions.abstract: Ceylon (http://ceylon-lang.org) is a great language with awesome features and great tooling that lets you focus on getting things done. So we wrote this Android application in Ceylon: You won't believe what happened next... But you'll have to come to the talk to find out. You'll also learn 8 ways Ceylon can help you write great microservices that the government doesn't want you to know about.
sessions.title: The most incredible Ceylon presentation you'll ever see

speakers.name: Tom Bentley
speakers.bio:
Tom has been working on Ceylon since 2011. He focuses mainly on code generation for the JVM, but he's also had a hand in some of the other tools in the distribution and several of the modules in the Ceylon SDK. His interests include programming languages, the JVM and beekeeping.

Tom lives in the UK.

sessions.intendedAudience: Everyone
sessions.abstract:
With the rise of managed services, Containers As A Service, Immutable Infrastructure etc., DevOps as we know it are dying. But it is a slow grinding death. DevOps is still being looked at as the "cool new thing" in many circles, when in fact, DevOps is just another dead end.

Join me for this lightning talk, and let's give a big fat middle finger to provisioning frameworks and server management, and succumb to our new Managed Service and Public Cloud overlords!
sessions.title: DevOps. You're fucking dead to me.

speakers.name: Andreas Heim
speakers.bio: Andreas Heim er VP of Engineering hos Unacast. Der har han ansvar (sammen med resten av utviklerne) for å utvikle og drifte Unacasts dataplatform. Andreas digger data.

sessions.intendedAudience: This session if for Git users who want to improve their productivity and knowledge of the tool.
sessions.abstract:
Many use Git at the most basic level: push, pull, and maybe branch off to isolate feature and bug fix work. But put together a few new and old effective Git commands and one can really increase productivity. Don't resort to XKCD #1597 when facing problems. Efficient, transformative personal Git workflows are not only possible, they are easy to learn. This talk will teach you exactly those.
Do you want spoilers? Think of the new "git worktree" command, think of "--autosquash", think of "subtree", and of few more interesting surprises in the Git toolchain.
sessions.title: Transformative Git practices: new techniques for hyper-productivity

speakers.name: Nicola Paolucci
speakers.bio:
Nicola is an all-round hacker who loves exploring and teaching bleeding
edge technologies. He writes and teaches about Docker, Git, development workflows and code collaboration. 

Prior to his current role as Developer Instigator at Atlassian he lead software teams, built crowd sourcing applications for geo-spacial data, worked on huge e-commerce deployments.

Little known facts about Nicola: he gesticulates a lot while speaking (being Italian), lives in Amsterdam and rides a Ducati.

sessions.intendedAudience:
Er du utvikler eller sysadmin med interesse for sikring av websider ved bruk av SSL, så er Let's Encrypt en nyhet og revolusjon som du bør kjenne til.
Av forkunnskaper er det greit å vite hva et SSL-sertifikat er og hva det brukes til. Du vil også få større utbytte av lyntalen dersom du kjenner deg igjen på en kommandolinje.
sessions.abstract:
Skulle du ønske at SSL-sertifikater var enkelt, gratis og at de fornyet seg selv?
Nå finnes Let's Encrypt! Let's Encrypt gir deg gratis SSL-sertifikater og fornyer disse automatisk når de er i ferd med å utløpe.

Dette er en kort introduksjon til Let's Encrypt, med en demonstrasjon av hvor enkelt det nå er å skaffe seg et SSL-sertifikat og hvordan dette fornyer seg selv.

Let's Encrypt er en åpen sertifikatutsteder, som utvikles og driftes av Internet Security Research Group (ISRG), hvis formål er å redusere de finansielle, teknologiske og kunnskapsmessige barrierene mot sikring av kommunikasjon på Internett.
sessions.title: Let's Encrypt! Endelig er SSL-sertifikater enkelt og gratis!

speakers.name: Jostein Tveit
speakers.bio: Jostein har jobbet med programvareutvikling i over 12 år og har en genuin interesse for sikkerhet i programvare. Han mener at all kommunikasjon på nettet bør krypteres og ved å tilby gratis SSL-sertifikater er Let's Encrypt et stort steg i riktig retning. Jostein ønsker derfor å spre kunnskap om og vise hvordan Let's Encrypt kan tas i bruk. Han er styremedlem i OWASP Norway Chapter og jobber til daglig hos Arkitektum i Bø i Telemark.

sessions.intendedAudience:
Du er interessert i å følge koden din ut i produksjon.  Du trenger innspill og gode ideer til hva og hvordan dette kan overvåkes.
"Code in slides"
sessions.abstract:
I FINN.no har vi de siste årene konvertert en gammel monolitisk applikasjon til over 300 kjørende mikrotjenester.  Denne endringen har store utfordringer rundt feilsøking og oppetid, og krever gode overvåkningsløsninger som tidlig oppdager og varsler om feil.

Søketeamet i FINN har laget en applikasjon som kontinuerlig overvåker ca 200 metrikker og varsler både med GUI, mail, SMS når noe er feil.  Jeg vil gå gjennom tankene bak applikasjonen, vise kodeeksempler på tester vi gjør mot eksterne systemer og vise applikasjonen live.
sessions.title: Øyeblikkelig oversikt over 150 ting som kan gå galt (og gjør det)

speakers.name: Fredrik Rødland
speakers.bio:
Fredrik har over 15 års erfaring med softwareutvikling hvorav 10 med søk. Han var med å starte opp aksjehandelstjenesten Stocknet, jobbet i FAST med implementering hos kunder. Han har tilsammen jobbet med søk i FINN i 7 år, hvor han blant annet brenner for å ha høy oppetid på alle deler av søketjenesten.

Når han ikke jobber med søk liker han å fotografere og bygge (og fly/kondemnere) quadcopters.

sessions.intendedAudience:
This talk is for anyone who wants to learn more about performance tuning their Java code. It's my intention to make my talks as accessible as possible without requiring expert knowledge. I will explain the JIT subsystem and optimisations for beginners but will continue to more advanced topics which will unavoidably be quite pretty complicated!
I will present code in slides showing Java, bytecode, and assembly.
sessions.abstract:
Learn about the Just In Time (JIT) optimisations made by the HotSpot JVM to dynamically optimise the performance of your code at runtime.
Learn about using the free and open-source JITWatch tool to analyse the JIT compiler decisions made by the JVM during the execution of your program.
Discover which of your methods were inlined, which allocations were eliminated through escape analysis, and identify safepoint poll points in your code.
sessions.title: Understanding HotSpot JVM Performance with JITWatch

speakers.name: Chris Newland
speakers.bio: Chris Newland, author of JITWatch. JVM tinkerer, financial software developer (trading systems, market data systems), performance tuning geek.

sessions.intendedAudience:
No prior knowledge is expected or assumed.  This talk will be interesting for anyone who has tried to integrate with physical devices, whether they are an IoT Hipster or a Raspberry PI Hacker.

We'll be focusing on comparing the protocols, so there will be no code.
sessions.abstract:
After HTTP, MQTT and CoAP are perhaps the most commonly used communication protocols for connecting devices to the Internet of Things.  But what are MQTT and CoAP, and what benefits do they provide over plain old HTTP?

In this session we’ll start by looking at the limitations to using HTTP in the IoT world.  We will then introduce MQTT and CoAP, and explain why these can be compelling replacements for HTTP.  By examining the strengths and weaknesses for HTTP, MQTT and CoAP we’ll identify IoT use cases for all three.
sessions.title: MQTT and CoAP for the Java Developer

speakers.name: Mark West
speakers.bio:
Mark is an Englishman living in Oslo where he works at Bouvet, a Norwegian IT Consultancy.  After some years in the management wilderness Mark has recently rediscovered the joy of coding and now spends his evenings experimenting with JavaScript, Robotics and the Internet of Things. 

In his spare time Mark is involved in javaBin (the Norwegian JUG) and helps organise community events such as JavaZone and JavaZone Kids. In the past year Mark has spoken about IoT matters at JavaOne in San Francisco and the IoT Tech Day in Utrecht.

sessions.intendedAudience:
Utviklere, arkitekter og prosjektledere.

Deltakerne vil få dypere forståelse for hva en bør tenke gjennom ved innføring og bruk av Enterprise programvare.

Ingen kode.
sessions.abstract:
Mange av oss fryser på ryggen og får piggene ut bare vi hører ordene Enterprise programvare. - Hvorfor gjør vi det?

Vi har prøvd å innføre noen kommersielle programvarekomponenter  i nettbankarkitekturen vår, som fra før er bygget på open source standardapplikasjoner og biblioteker. Innføringen har gitt oss nye erfaringer.

Kom og hør når vi forteller om utfordringene vi har hatt og hva vi har lært av dette. - Kan det være at det er noe annet enn selve programvaren som er hovedutfordringene til Enterprise programvare?
sessions.title: - Enterprise programvare! Vart du skræmt no?

speakers.name: Vidar Moe
speakers.bio: Arkitekt og utvikler med mange års erfaring fra noen av de største programvareprosjektene i Norge. Brenner for lean og smidige prinsipper, og liker å utfordre både tekniske monolitter og organisatoriske siloer for å kunne levere stadig bedre og raskere.

sessions.intendedAudience:
Utviklere med interesse for frontend og store javascriptkodebaser

Code in slides
sessions.abstract:
Synes du det er vanskelig å holde deg oppdatert på hva som skjer i frontendlandskapet? Er du lei av at det stadig snakkes om nye rammeverk du knapt har hørt om? Lurer du på hva man bør velge for å lage store og komplekse webapplikasjoner i 2016?

Mange mener React og Redux, de siste skuddene på en lang stamme av frontendbuzzwords, er kjempebra greier. Men er det egentlig det? Er det ikke bare... nytt? Hvordan kan vi vite at det ikke bare er nok et blaff i vinden? Kommer det ikke bare noe nytt og enda bedre neste år?

I dette foredraget får du en grundig gjennomgang av React og Redux-arkitekturen. Du vil se hvordan disse kan bidra til å holde store frontendkodebaser ryddige i tiden fremover, uten at vi trenger å være redd for å måtte skrive om alt neste år.
sessions.title: "React og Redux, sier du? Neste år kommer det vel bare enda et rammeverk”

speakers.name: Erik Wendel
speakers.bio:
Erik driver med javascriptutvikling i BEKK Consulting her i Oslo, og elsker funksjonell programmering og å holde foredrag og workshops. Han jobber som fagleder for området frontendarkitektur i BEKK, men jobber til daglig med nettbank- og mobilbankutvikling hos SpareBank1.

Her har han jobbet med storskala javascriptapplikasjoner siden 2012. Det siste året har han jobbet med å koordinere et arbeid for å migrere frontendarkitekturen fra Backbone til React og Redux. Dette arbeidet involverer over femten applikasjoner, femten team og nesten hundre utviklere.

Erik er en erfaren taler, og har holdt foredrag og workshops i både inn- og utland, sist på ForwardJS-konferansen i San Francisco.

sessions.intendedAudience: People that are interested in JVM internals, optimizing native code compilers and who is just curious about alternative JVM implementations may benefit from this talk.  On the other hand, the common knowledge (university level) about JVM and compilers is enough to get the most of the presentation. There is some code in slides but not so much.
sessions.abstract:
Ahead-of-time (AOT) native compilation has been available for .NET for quite some time, whereas Java SE, while being older than .NET, still does not have a standard AOT compiler. Some people ask why, some people think that it could only work for certain limited types of Java applications, some people think that it is not needed.

The truth, however, is that a Java AOT compiler has been available for over a decade, as part of a compliant Java SE implementation called Excelsior JET, and it proved to be useful for many organizations around the world. In this session, I would like to dispel the common myths about Java AOT compilation and show where it has advantages over JIT compilation from the technical point of view.
sessions.title: Java AOT Compilation

speakers.name: Nikita Lipsky
speakers.bio: Nikita Lipsky is an initiator and a team lead of Excelsior JET project – certified Java SE implementation with AOT compiler developed by Excelsior LLC. Working on the project since 1997 he took part in almost every activity of the project from the JVM core to product management and support. Last couple of years, he is experimenting (in a spare time) with open source projects exploring approaches and a concept of the next web.

sessions.intendedAudience:
All audiences. No code. All practical application.
Perfect if you've watched the show “Mr. Robot”.

You will hopefully learn to, as they say, “get your shit together” when it comes to personal security.
sessions.abstract:
You are one of the most significant security threats to your company. We all know we are going to fix better passwords / encryption / firewalls / etc. one day. Getting properly hacked is one of those things that is a lot more comfortable to prevent beforehand than to gather the shattered pieces afterwards. In this talk, we will take a practical approach to good personal digital security. We will start with the easy parts before drilling through the layers of security, down to the parts that are unpredictable and dangerous. Bring your laptop and a tin foil hat.

Topics include: What it's like to get properly hacked. Using password managers. Operating system security. Browser security. Encryption, firewalls, factors, and other means of protection.
sessions.title: Personal security

speakers.name: Michael Johansen
speakers.bio:
A software consultant during the day and a startup founder during the night. At NTNU I studied entrepreneurship, computer science and psychology. During my studies I also took a year off to be a board member at NTNU's Board of Directors. As part of my startup venture I've gotten first-hand experience with the startup scene in both Boston and in Silicon Valley. Humans and machines are the two things that interest me the most. I'm a bit systematic.

I care more than most people about personal security, and it's a topic on which I'd like to share my insights.

CV: michaeljohansen.no -- linkedin.com/in/johansenmichael

sessions.intendedAudience: Little code, However deep details on Cgroups and container configurations.
sessions.abstract:
Whether it is Docker or the Mesos Container running with Apache Mesos means running in a container, but do you really understand cgroups and how they work? Do you understand the difference between CPU Sets and CPU Shares? Many organizations use Java for their application development, but do you understand the consequence of what impact the cgroup constraints have on the JRE? 

This talk starts with a look at the anatomy of a container including control groups (cgroups) and namespaces. Then we will take a deep understand of Java's memory management and GC characteristics and how JRE characteristics change based on core count. The session will detail specifically the difference between CPU sets and CPU shares and memory management. The session will close with a deep understanding of the consequences of running the JRE in a CPU share environment and the potential for pseudo-random behavior of running in a heterogeneous datacenter.
sessions.title: Nobody puts Java in the container

speakers.name: Ken Sipe
speakers.bio: Ken Sipe is a Cloud Solution Architect at Mesosphere, focused on helping companies simplify the development and operation of large scale infrastructure and distributed systems with Apache Mesos and the new Datacenter OS.   As a JavaOne Rockstar, Ken is an author and award winning international speaker on the practices of software architecture and engineering, continuous delivery and agile practices.   Ken is also an Apache Mesos contributor and an Apache committer on the Myriad, HDFS, Cassandra and Kafka Apache Mesos framework projects.

sessions.intendedAudience: The talk is for people in DevOps teams that are involved in how their systems perform in production. It will go into detail about how easy it is to do Chaos Engineering when using the public cloud, with some examples for AWS and Azure, but will also show how you can get started when stuck with a more traditional hosting provider. Code in slides!
sessions.abstract: Our software systems are becoming more complex and more distributed. How do we have confidence in the resilience and redundancy of the systems we put in production? Chaos Engineering is the practice of introducing failures into your system in controlled experiments to learn how your system reacts. In this talk we will look into how to establish the steady state behavior of a system and how to start experimenting to discover if the system can handle spikes in traffic, failures and timeouts.
sessions.title: Lord of Chaos - Becoming a Chaos Engineer

speakers.name: Nikolai Norman Andersen
speakers.bio: Nikolai is a senior consultant and lead developer at BEKK. He is currently working with the The Norwegian Directorate for Education and Training on their systems for digital exams and tests. Nikolai has previously worked as a freelancer, for a small startup and for an advertising agency. His focus is on .NET and DevOps, spending time improving applications and the way they are continuously delivered. He is also a co-organiser of the Oslo F# Meetup and the upcoming DevOpsDays Oslo.

sessions.intendedAudience: Everyone. No Code.
sessions.abstract:
In his book The Rise of Superman, Steven Kotler mentioned computer programming specifically as one of the Flow triggers. Flow is the mental state of operation in which a person performing an activity is fully immersed in a feeling of energized focus, full involvement, and enjoyment in the process of the activity. In essence, flow is characterized by complete absorption in what one does.  Flow is currently studied by, among others, the Flow Genome Project, which is a interdisciplinary, global organization committed to mapping the genome of Flow by 2020 and open sourcing it to everyone. They are a collection of world-class academics, athletes and artists dedicated to taking Flow from the extreme to the mainstream. They advance Flow science and train individuals and organizations to harness Flow in their lives and work.

Flow triggering activities have been used to recover from illnesses. Arguably it is also beneficial to our health and quality of life (happiness?). A healthy and happy coder is most likely to produce a better and sustainable work, both individually as well as a team. 

In this talk I would like to examine the benefits/pitfalls of flow state in a development context. I would also like to present some practical techniques/tools that Flow Genome Project has come up and put them in the software development context.
sessions.title: Code with the Flow - Healthy coding

speakers.name: Irwan Syahrir
speakers.bio: A java programmer. I like learning about almost anything. Fascinated lately about the idea of biohacking and flow state, especially in the context increasing creativity and quality of life.

sessions.intendedAudience: Alle som har vært med i et utviklingsprosjekt. Ingen kode, masse humor!
sessions.abstract: Jeg liker endring. Jeg liker å programmere, og jeg liker å se de store linjene. Det har medført at jeg programmerer på ca annet hvert prosjekt jeg er med på, og er “rådgiver”, arkitekt eller lignende i de resterende. I dette foredraget drar jeg denne to-sidigheten ut i det absurde. Jeg beskriver min indre dialog som en boksekamp mellom Arkitekten med stor A, og programmerer-Trond.  Forhåpentligvis ligger det noen lærdommer og litt forståelse i denne beskrivelsen av min indre dialog, også for deg.
sessions.title: Arkitekt-meg og Progge-meg i bokseringen

speakers.name: Trond Pedersen
speakers.bio: Trond er en engasjert og løsningsorientert utvikler og arkitekt fra Sopra Steria. Han er en ivrig deltager i Oslos utvikler-miljø, og var blant annet med på å etablere  Smidig-Konferansen og XP-meetup. Han har vært en forkjemper for smidig systemutvikling siden 2001 og setter stor pris på gode diskusjoner om alle aspekter ved systemutvikling.

sessions.intendedAudience: Developers and architects on any level. There's code in slides.
sessions.abstract: I have some scary examples for you, gathered throughout many years on maintenance and on large modernization projects. Examples of code so indescribably bad that it's difficult to understand how it came to ever exist. These (anonymized) examples have been analyzed in order to determine how they came to be. Participate in this presentation so that you can avoid making the same mistakes in your next development project. ...or live with the misconception that only bad developers make bad code.
sessions.title: The Uncomfortable Truth of Bad Code

speakers.name: Stian Grenborgen
speakers.bio: Stian Grenborgen is an experienced Java programmer and software architect working for Sopra Steria. He has worked on large and critical systems in the Norwegian government and with infrastructurally crucial systems for the financial sector. He takes a special interest in computer interface design both in his professional capacity and in his spare time.

sessions.intendedAudience: Alle som har noe erfaring med Git. Ingen kode.
sessions.abstract:
I forlengelsen av clean code bør vi også etterstrebe clean Git-historikk. For å oppnå det bruker mange av oss Git rebase, blant annet til å rydde i rotete historikk, redigere tidligere commitmeldinger eller fjerne flaue commits.

Mulighetene er endeløse når man først har lært seg å bruke rebase, men med stor makt følger stort ansvar. Hvor lurt er det egentlig å skrive om historikken i Git? Når bør du gjøre det, og når bør du la være?

Historieforfalskning forsøker vi vanligvis å unngå, men i den digitale verden må det vel være greit? Eller er det andre farer som lurer?
sessions.title: Det er greit å lyve litt, eller?

speakers.name: Fredrik Mørken Valdmanis
speakers.bio: Fredrik har 4 års erfaring som utvikler i BEKK, og har brukt git til stort og smått i 7 år. Han er selverklært git-nerd, og prøver stadig å finne nye og bedre måter å bruke verktøyet på.

sessions.intendedAudience: Frontend devlopers, designers and UX
sessions.abstract:
De siste årene har responsivitet blitt en viktigere del av nettsideutvikling.

W3C har i løpet av den siste tiden jobbet med en ny måte å style layouten på en nettside. Det de har kommet frem til går under navnet Flexbox.

Flexbox er en layout som skal gjøre det lettere å jobbe med responsivitet og dynamiske elementer. Flere har allerede begynt å ta i bruk dette, som for eksempel React Native.

I denne lyntalen skal jeg ta for meg litt av bakgrunnen til Flexbox og hvordan man effektivt kan ta det i bruk i dag.
sessions.title: Flex med bokser

speakers.name: Magnus Dæhlen
speakers.bio:
I am Magnús Dæhlen. I work as a solutions engineer at Iterate AS. My main job is working as an IT consultant and I am currently working with Cisco on some really cool stuff.
I am passionate about web technology and I have held several talks around different web technology, like React, React Native, Flexbox etc. 
On a more personal note, I am very fond of music and I play in a band with several other developers from Finn.no, Start and Iterate.

sessions.intendedAudience: Kom og hør på denne lyntalen dersom du er skallet fordi du har revet av deg alt håret i frustrasjon over at Javascript koden din ikke fungerer.  Og for deg som er ny i Javascript-verden , og ennå ikke har falt i noen feller, men som helst sikkert kommer til å gjøre det når du innser hvor mye som faktisk er lov å gjøre med Javascript.
sessions.abstract: Har du noen gang tenkt på at du skulle ønske Javascript var et sterkt typet språk? Hvor mange ganger trenger man egentlig å bli fortalt at undefined ikke er en funksjon? Dette var også noe av det de ansatte hos Facebook irriterte seg over. Så de satte seg like godt ned og laget Flow - En statisk typesjekker for Javascript.  Etter denne lyntalen trenger du aldri mer å lure på hvorfor Javascript-koden din feiler. Fra nå er Flow din venn. Flow er power!
sessions.title: Flow er power!

speakers.name: Carl Joachim Rørvik
speakers.bio: Full-stack utvikler hos Bekk Consulting. Jobbet mye med React og Redux det siste året. Var tidligere i år med å lage og holde kurs i funksjonell frontendprogrammering for studenter ved UiO og NTNU.

sessions.intendedAudience: Folk som bruker React og gjerne også Flux (helst i form av Redux) som ønsker å få kontroll på og få testet kompliserte flyter i sine apps. God kjennskap til JavaScript og helst nyeste ES6. Kjennskap til generatorfunksjoner er ikke nødvendig, da det blir gjennomgått. En grunnleggende forståelse for Flux-arkitekturen er nødvendig. Nivået er viderekommende til avansert.
sessions.abstract: Ajaxkall er et eksempel på operasjoner som er kjipe å teste. Spesielt hvis du skal reagere på responsen og kanskje gjøre nye kall, håndtere feil eller sette i gang nye operasjoner. Koden blir gjerne spagetti med mange callbacks og bruk av mocking for testing. Redux har blitt det definitive biblioteket for å håndtere oppdatering av data i React-apps, men det mangler en måte å orkestrere kompliserte og asynkrone operasjoner. Redux-saga er en mellomvare til Redux som lar deg samle komplekse flyter og sideeffekter i enkle og testbare generatorfunksjoner - helt uten bruk av mocking og callbacks. Det blir vist kodeeksempler, med full testdekning, på hvordan redux-saga løser praktiske utfordringer vi har hatt på Skatteetaten, bl.a. ajaxkall, feilhåndtering, sekvensielle og parallelle flyter, analytics, throttling og innlogging/oppstart.
sessions.title: 100% testdekning i React-apps

speakers.name: Øystein Strand
speakers.bio: Konsulent i BEKK med interesse for moderne og testbare JavaScript-apps.

sessions.intendedAudience: Ingen kode. Passer både for utviklere og mindre tekniske.
sessions.abstract:
Hackaton er ikke bare en metode for å få utviklere og andre til å jobbe sene kvelder, betalt kun med mat drikke, og muligheten for å vinne heder og kule gadgets. Aller viktigst er det et forum der utviklere og andre kan møtes for idemyldring og samarbeid som er verdifull og gøy for alle som er involvert.

Dagens Næringsliv har begynt å arrangere Hackaton årlig, og her vil jeg si litt om hvor nyttig og gøy dette er. Vi har opplevd originiale idéer fra uventet hold, og får implementert funksjonelle prototyper. Vi så også at utviklere, forretningsutviklere, redaksjon, designere og andre kunne samarbeide akkurat så godt som optimistene hevdet på forhånd.

Etter lyntalen håper jeg du har gode nok argumenter for å overbevise din bedrift om å arrangere dette, så du kan oppleve det selv.
sessions.title: Hacakton i Dagens Næringsliv

speakers.name: Frank Jensen
speakers.bio: Frank har jobbed med Java-basert webutvikling i 10 år, og vært utviklingssjef i ett. Fokus har vært på nettavisene til NHST Media Group, hvor Dagens Næringsliv er den mest kjente. På fritiden prøves gjerne andre språk i andre kontekster.

sessions.intendedAudience: Alle nivåer. Vil være noe kode på slidene.
sessions.abstract:
Har du noen gang refaktorert backendkoden din eller latt være selv om du egentlig har lyst?
Har du noen gang krasjet klientene fordi du ikke sjekket nøye nok at outputen fra endepunktene var lik som før endringen?
Da er denne talken for deg! 

Lær hvordan du kan sammenligne outputen fra før og etter endringene dine for å oppdage utilsiktede bieffekter ved hjelp av verktøyet Diffy fra Twitter.
sessions.title: Diff deg til trygghet!

speakers.name: Anders Ullnæss
speakers.bio:
Fagleder for mobilitet i Mesan. Jobber både med mobil backend, Android og iOS.
Lager for tiden apper og API-er for å se på TV, lese nyheter og sjekke været hos NRK.

sessions.intendedAudience: Developers. Code in slides
sessions.abstract:
Mange moderne IT-organisasjoner har som mål at utviklerne skal ta
ansvar for koden sin helt ut i produksjon. Likevel bruker de
driftsverktøy som er laget for den tradisjonelle modellen hvor
utviklerne leverer koden sin til driftsavdelingen, og de to miljøene
deler relativt lite av både kode og kunnskap.

Istedenfor at utviklerne skriver integrasjonstester som sjekker at
softwaren oppfører seg som den skal før deployment og drift konfigurerer
monitoreringsverktøy som også sjekker at softwaren oppfører seg som
den skal i produksjon, kan vi tenke oss at vi kan gjenbruke denne logikken?
Denne talken vil undersøke fordeler og ulemper ved å bruke tradisjonelle
compile-time tester som en del av runtime-helsesjekker av en applikasjon.
sessions.title: Gjenbruk av software-tester for systemovervåkning

speakers.name: Haakon G. Eriksen
speakers.bio:
Utvikler hos FINN.no, som gjerne blander seg i alt fra apps-utvikling
til konfigurasjon av lastbalanserere.

sessions.intendedAudience: Utviklere, Devops'ere  og andre som ønsker å konfigurere sine kjøremiljøer på en enklere måte... Det blir ikke så mye kode men litt konfigurasjonsfiler.
sessions.abstract:
"Alle" vil i skyen, og "alle" vil kjøre Devops. Det ville vi også i mitt siste prosjekt. Men et skymiljø i f.eks. Amazon AWS inneholder mange bevegelige deler. Så å sette det opp riktig er ikke nødvendigvis trivielt. Og selv når man har fått et miljø som fungerer, er det ikke helt enkelt å duplisere det, slik at testmiljøer og produksjon blir like.

Jeg går igjennom den reisen vi gjorde fra manuell konfigurasjon gjennom flere iterasjoner til dagens løsning. Jeg viser hva som skal til for å sette opp et miljø i AWS, og hvordan dette kan gjøres enklere og mer reproduserbart ved å bruke skripting og Terraform. Og i tillegg deles noen erfaringer på veien.
sessions.title: Hvordan bruke Terraform for å konfigurere Amazon AWS

speakers.name: Rune Storløpa
speakers.bio: Rune jobber i Knowit, og har jobbet 15 år i bransjen som utvikler, arkitekt og teknisk prosjektleder (og av og til noen andre roller også). De siste 6 årene har han jobbet i forskjellige prosjekter som praktiserer DevOps-prinsipper og senest i et prosjekt hvor kjøremiljøet ligger på Amazon AWS.

sessions.intendedAudience: For those interested in video, image stream or audio programming, image or audio composition or just something quite different from other presentations.
sessions.abstract:
Are you a rock star dev? What if the next tech revolution has nerds coding video algorithms and data structures like web apps of the early 2000’s? 

Programmatically editing video is not that difficult. The presentation focuses on the architecture of a server-side app for video-editing - algorithms and data structures for handling image streams.
sessions.title: If coding music videos was easy as algdat and cloud

speakers.name: Stig Lau
speakers.bio: 10 yrs exp in Kringsjå Skolemusikk. DSLR in attic. Have eaten more with javaBin than at home. Made an app for converting XML into music videos.

sessions.intendedAudience: Developers, code in slides
sessions.abstract:
TDD is all good but testing is more than checking that the code does what the requirements says it should do. OK, it might happen that we forget a requirement or two. However, the majority of bugs arrives in situations that are not mentioned in the specfication. How do we discover these situations? Luck? Going back to waterfall and spending months on getting the requirements perfect before we start coding? Performing rigerous manual testing after the development is done?

Exploratory testing is a powerful approach to testing that has been used by the testing community for more than 25 years. It is especially useful when working with complex solutions, incomplete requirements and specifications, and/or time-pressure. Does the situation sounds familiar? 

In this talk we'll look at how to apply the ideas behind exploratory testing and use them to find potential error situations and write more robust code. You might not learn to win the lottery but you'll learn how to find more of the nasty bugs before you commit your code to the repository.
sessions.title: Learn to be Lucky

speakers.name: Cecilie Haugstvedt
speakers.bio: Test lead in Computas with a technical background. Has been working with test in public sector for the last couple of years and is currently spending her time improving testing of legacy and not-so-legacy systems. Believes the quality of the system is the responsibility of the entire team and not something you leave to testers alone. Likes to play with gadgets on her free time.

sessions.intendedAudience: Lyntalen er en introduksjon for alle som er nysgjerrige på IoT, iBeacons og Googles fysiske web.
sessions.abstract: Det har gått over to år siden iBeacon ble nevnt på Apples World Wide Developers Conference. Google sitt prosjekt "Physical Web" ble lansert først i september i fjor. Hva skiller disse to? Hva finnes av applikasjoner og bruksområder? Kom for å høre en introduksjon til teknologiene og en sammenlingning av disse to.
sessions.title: IoT – Googles fysiske web og Apples iBeacon

speakers.name: Anders Hefre
speakers.bio: Jobber til daglig som systemutvikler og fagleder for Java i Bekk. Mine interesser er programmeringsspråk, mobil utvikling og alt av nye teknologier.

sessions.intendedAudience:
Looking into the main Java conferences around the world, you cannot find any Maven related sessions that guide you through the fundamentals. Maybe the community assumes that you should already know them, like the Java language itself. Still, recycling this knowledge could be a win-win situation for everyone. How much time developers waste with not knowing how to deal with Maven particularities?

I wrote a blog post about this: http://www.radcortez.com/maven-common-problems-and-pitfalls/ and the session is going to include most of the post information, plus additional problems and practices that can help developers to be more effective when working with Maven.
sessions.abstract: Love it or hate it (and a lot of people seem to hate it), Maven is a widely used tool. We can consider that Maven has been the de-facto standard build tool for Java over the last 10 years. Most experienced developers already got their share of Maven headaches. Unfortunately, new developers are going through the same hard learning process, because they don't know how to deal with Maven particularities. "Why is this jar in my build?", "I can’t see my changes!", "The jar is not included in the distribution!", "The artifact was not found!" are common problems. Learn to tame the Maven Beast and be in complete control of your build to save you countless hours of pain and frustration.
sessions.title: Maven - Taming the Beast

speakers.name: Roberto Cortez
speakers.bio:
My name is Roberto Cortez and I am a professional Java Developer working in the software development industry, with more than 10 years of experience in business areas like Finance, Insurance and Government.

As a Freelancer / Independent Contractor I travelled around the world to customers, but also to attend Java conferences. The direct contact with the Java community made me want to become an active member in the community itself. For that reason, I have created the Coimbra JUG, started to contribute to Open Source on Github and launched my own blog.

Currently, I’m working with Tomitribe. I’m very excited to work with all the amazing tribers working hard to make TomEE a compelling Java EE server.

sessions.intendedAudience: The talk is for you if you are developing Hibernate/JPA applications and would like to add full-text search functionality. You will learn how easy that task is made via Hibernate Search. You should have an average knowledge of JPA, knowledge of Elasticsearch is not required. There will be code in slides and a small amount of live coding.
sessions.abstract:
A great search experience is a must-have for enterprise applications these days. As full-text search in databases often is limited, Elasticsearch steps in and offers powerful search services through a REST API.

Keeping your domain model and Elasticsearch in sync may seem easy first, but the devil is in the details. What about type conversions, handling of nested entities and associations or the processing of query results?

But no worries, Hibernate Search has got you covered. In this talk you will learn how to index your entity model with the help of a few annotations, let Hibernate Search take care of the database/Elasticsearch synchronization and get back managed objects from full-text queries.

Based on common use cases, you will find out how to prepare your model for indexing, synchronous and asynchronous index updates, different approaches for running searches and more. Be prepared to see code and the great combo of Hibernate Search and Elasticsearch in action.
sessions.title: From Hibernate to Elasticsearch in no time

speakers.name: Gunnar Morling
speakers.bio: Gunnar Morling works as software engineer in the Hibernate team at Red Hat, focusing on Hibernate OGM, Validator, and Search. He is also is serving in the expert group for Bean Validation. In his spare time Gunnar is leading the MapStruct project. Prior to joining Red Hat, Gunnar worked on a wide range of Java EE projects in the logistics and retail industries. He is based in Hamburg, Germany.

sessions.intendedAudience: Utviklere som savner en kreativ outlet. Det blir enklere å følge med hvis du har erfaring med JavaScript, men det er ikke noe must. Ingen forhåndskunnskap om musikkteori er påkrevd. Det blir kode i slides.
sessions.abstract: Nettleseren som musikkinstrument? JavaScript som tangenter i et piano? WebAudio og WebMIDI gjør nettleseren din til det mest portable elektroniske instrumentet til nå, med et par linjer kode har du ditt eget instrument. Kun kreativiteten setter grenser for hva du kan høre av din egen kode!
sessions.title: Nettleseren som musikkinstrument

speakers.name: Stian Veum Møllersen
speakers.bio: Utvikler basert i Oslo. Under gjennomsnittlig god på piano, røver på finger-trommer og skikkelig glad i musikk. Tror alle har en musiker i seg, de har bare ikke funnet rett instrument enda. Fagleder for Webgrensesnitt i BEKK.

sessions.intendedAudience:
This workshop is for developers comfortable with JavaScript. Experience with React and Redux is preferable, but not required.

You'll need to bring your own laptop (Windows/OSX/Linux), ready for React Native development. We'll email you setup instructions a week or two before the conference.
sessions.abstract:
Hands-on introduction to React Native – Facebook's open source library for building cross-platform native mobile apps.  

You'll make a messaging client for a simple chat API. You can choose if you want to develop for Android or iOS (or both!). 

In this workshop you'll gain insight in how you can use your web development skills to create native mobile apps with React Native. You'll see how you can leverage popular JavaScript libraries like React, Redux, fetch, etc., without sacrificing the native look and feel. You'll create the layout using Flexbox, which React Native "borrows" from CSS.
sessions.title: Introduction to React Native

speakers.name: Aleksander Hindenes
speakers.bio: Aleksander is a web developer with an entrepreneurial mind. He has two years experience working for Bekk Consulting AS, building Single Page Apps for a public sector client. As of this fall, he'll be an independent Oslo-based consultant, taking on new and exciting projects.

speakers.name: Markus Nilssen
speakers.bio: Markus is a developer working as a consultant for BEKK in Oslo. Although he deals with every level of the stack, he reserves some extra love for javascript and Single Page Apps. When he is not cranking out code, he enjoys rock climbing and other outdoor activities.

speakers.name: Anum Qudsia
speakers.bio: Developer with experience in various technologies such as Swift, Java, .Net, Xamarin, Javascript, MBaaS (Parse) etc. Anum is very passionate for mobile apps and has spent the last few years developing apps for numerous clients. She has worked on several app projects and released these to the App Store. She has contributed in holding workshops at BEKK and Mobile Meetup in Oslo. In her spare time she enjoys creating novice apps, play music, skydive and travel.

speakers.name: Simen Lomås Johannessen
speakers.bio: Simen is an iOS enthusiast with 4 years’ experience. During the day, he spends his time at SpareBank1 developing Norway’s best mobile bank solution. He spends a lot of his free time investigating the JavaScript world and in particular looking into React ecosystem.

speakers.name: Anders Kristiansen
speakers.bio: Anders is a full-stack developer at BEKK with an extra interest in frontend and mobile apps. He works with cross plattform app development for Android and iOS at a daily basis at his current project. When he is not building software he likes building stuff in and around his house.

sessions.intendedAudience:
Programmers that know Java and maven, and need to create a windows service.

Code level: basic
sessions.abstract:
A task often needed is to make your Java program a Windows Service. This is may be a bump in your project, particularily if you don't know anything about windows services.

This 10 minute demo explains how to overcome this bump by implementing a single interface and adding a little maven magic to create an izpack installer that installs your program as a windows service.
sessions.title: A Java windows service in 10 minutes

speakers.name: Steinar Bang
speakers.bio:
Senior solutions architect at Sopra Steria.

What makes me happy is putting things together from open source and free software out there, and create stuff for others to use.

30 years of experience in programming and electronics.

sessions.intendedAudience: Lyntalen er for alle som er nysgjerrige på opne data, og ønskjer ei kjapp innføring og overblikk. Ingen kode, med unntak av eit par små eksempel på data i JSON-format.
sessions.abstract:
I denne lyntalen får du ein introduksjon til kva opne offentlege data er, og eit overblikk over området.

For eksempel kva opne offentlege data er, kvar du finn data, korleis du går fram for å få tak i data som endå ikkje er publisert, eit par eksempel på korleis opne offentlege data er brukt og siste nytt om opne offentlege data i Norge.

Difi har ansvaret for det nasjonale registeret over opne offentlege data - http://data.norge.no/
Der finn du oversikt over datasett frå offentleg sektor, informasjon og rettleiing, samt døme på bruk av opne offentlege data.
sessions.title: Gratis maskinlesbare data frå offentleg sektor, ja takk!

speakers.name: Livar Bergheim
speakers.bio: Livar har jobba med opne data og informasjonsforvaltning i Difi sidan juni 2015, og med opne data nokre år før det. Utdanninga er informatikk/programvareutvikling. Han jobbar som rådgjevar, men finn stadig anledningar til å få programmert litt i jobben og på fritida. I jobben held han mange foredrag om opne data, og brenn for mulegheitene meir deling av data gir.

sessions.intendedAudience: Utvecklare och testare. No code.
sessions.abstract:
Med Dockers nätverksstöd är det smärtfritt att ta full kontroll över baksystemerna och ersätta länkarna till dessa med mock-containers. Detta gör det möjligt att köra stabila och isolerade end-2-end tester direkt på byggservern!

I talken ser vi nærmare på olika möjligheter för att mocka flera typer baksystemer.
sessions.title: End-2-End testning med Docker: mock it all - or die trying!

speakers.name: Jonas Nordstrand
speakers.bio:
Svensk utvecklare som tillbringat snart tio år i den norska förskingringen med att utveckla nettbank i olika sammanhang. Jobbar idag för SpareBank 1 med att utveckla spännande ting för 750.000 bankkunder - och med att se till tingen kommer på luften snabbare än någonsin. 

Brinner för förenkling, testautomatisering och vikten av att lösa de rätta problemen.

sessions.intendedAudience: Lyntalen er for alle de som er interessert i testautomatisering, både utviklere som har lyst å se noen eksempler på testautomatisering i praksis og de som ønsker en mer overordnet intro til testautomatisering og hva man bør tenke på før man setter i gang med utvikling av slike tester. Presentasjonen har med noen få kodeeksempler.
sessions.abstract:
Denne presentasjonen er en intro til testautomatisering. Hva er det? Når bør vi automatisere våre tester? Hvilke fordeler gir testautomatisering og hvilke utfordringer støter man på ved utvikling av slike tester?

Hvis du i tillegg ønsker å få noen tips i forhold til når det er hensiktsmessig å automatisere en test og hvordan man kan lykkes med testautomatisering, er dette presentasjonen for deg.

Til slutt vil jeg også vise noen eksempler på hvordan testautomatisering kan gjøres i praksis. Her vil jeg vise eksempler fra to ulike prosjekter og med verktøy som Java, Selenium WebDriver, egendefinerte DSL´er, ExtentReports, RSpec, Ruby og Capybara.
sessions.title: Testautomatisering: Hva, når, hvordan?

speakers.name: Hege Hansbakk Huuse
speakers.bio:
Hege jobber som konsulent i Bouvet. Her har hun vært systemutvikler i både små og store smidige prosjekter innenfor Java-miljøet. De siste årene har Hege imidlertid gått fra å være ren utvikler til å spisse sin kompetanse som funksjonell arkitekt og innen fagområdet automatiserte funksjonelle tester.

Tidligere har Hege flere års erfaring som utvikler og drifter på CERN i Sveits. Hun har bakgrunn som sivilingeniør fra NTNU og har nå 13 års erfaring innen IT-bransjen.

sessions.intendedAudience:
> Who should attend this session?
Everyone involved with Software

> How will the participants benefit from attending? 
Receive insight into the business of Open Source from someone living off Open Source

> Explicitly state what your audience needs to know in order to get the most out of your presentation.
No prerequisites, No code
sessions.abstract:
Open Source is ubiquitous. Open Source is inevitable. But why would anyone even engage in Open Source? Does making money with it even work?

Modern Open Source is not Richard Stallman's Open Source anymore. Now that even Microsoft is open sourcing .NET (and possibly: Windows?), we'll need to review our opinions about Open Source.

Large corporations have engaged in commoditising their infrastructure software via Open Source in order to increase demand for their primary offerings: PaaS, SaaS, and IaaS.

And with this new model in mind, we'll have a short look into whether it still makes sense for ISVs to engage in Open Source development, or if we should just enjoy the massive free ride.
sessions.title: This isn't Richard Stallman's Open Source Anymore

speakers.name: Lukas Eder
speakers.bio: Lukas Eder is the founder and CEO of Data Geekery GmbH, located in Zurich, Switzerland. With his company he has been selling database products and services around Java and SQL since 2013. Ever since his Master’s studies at EPFL in 2006, he has been fascinated by the interaction of Java and SQL. Most of this experience he has obtained in the Swiss E-Banking field through various variants (JDBC, Hibernate, mostly with Oracle). As a Java Champion, he is happy to share this knowledge at various conferences, JUGs, in-house presentations and on his blog. Here’s his conference and JUG talk schedule for the most recent time: http://www.jooq.org/news.

sessions.intendedAudience: Denne talken passer for alle som har litt kodeerfaring, men man trenger på ingen måte å være ekspert. Talken vil være på et grunnleggende nivå, men kjennskap til algoritmer og kunstig intelligens vil være en fordel.
sessions.abstract:
Matematikere og programmerere har lenge prøvd å finne optimale løsninger på problemer som ikke lar seg løse direkte ved å bruke algoritmer eller formler. Et eksempel på et slikt problem er The Travelling Salesman Problem. 

I noen tilfeller har man godtatt at det kan være svært vanskelig å finne den aller beste løsningen, og man har i stedet funnet strategier for å komme fram til nesten optimale løsninger. Disse kan i mange tilfeller være svært verdifulle selv om de ikke er helt helt optimale.

I naturen har insekter som maur og bier vist seg ekstremt dyktige til å finne korteste vei mellom to punkter. Dette gjør de ved å dele informasjon og dermed bygge en slags kollektiv intelligens. Basert på denne framgangsmåten har det blitt utformet en modell for kunstig intelligens som kalles "swarm intelligence". Ideen er at man lager systemer som hermer etter hvordan disse insektene kommuniserer med hverandre, for på denne måten å kunne finne tilnærmet korteste vei på en rask måte.

Vi skal se kort på hva swarm intelligence er ved hjelp av praktiske eksempler, og vi skal diskutere hvordan sverminspirerte algoritmer kan brukes på andre problemer - og hvordan dette kan bli mer relevant i fremtiden.
sessions.title: Swarm Intelligence - løsningen på uløselige problemer?

speakers.name: Hanne Gunby
speakers.bio: Utvikler i BEKK Consulting. I mai 2015 leverte jeg en master på NTNU der jeg brukte en Swarm Intelligence-algoritme til å optimalisere bussrute-planlegging.

sessions.intendedAudience: Intermediate - All Code.
sessions.abstract:
Kotlin, a language developed by JetBrains for nearly 5 years is very close to its first release. However, did you know that it's being used in production for over a few years now already? Both inside and outside of JetBrains there are people deploying Kotlin applications for Android platform, for Web Applications and just about any other type of application.
 
Why are people using it instead of Java or some of the other languages out there? Primarily because it provides significant benefits in terms of conciseness, readability and safety, without some of the drawbacks that adopting a new language has such as a higher learning curve or interoperability with existing code and ecosystems. 
 
In this talk we'll cover some aspects of Kotlin that can really help you in your daily development, focusing on solving issues versus highlighting language features.
sessions.title: Kotlin - Ready for Production

speakers.name: Hadi Hariri
speakers.bio: Developer and creator of many things OSS, his passions includes Web Development and Software Architecture. Has authored a couple of books, a few courses and has been speaking at industry events for nearly 15 years. Currently at JetBrains leading the Developer Advocacy team. Spends as much time as he can writing code.

sessions.intendedAudience:
Coding will be done. Experts and beginners may attend, we have tasks ranging from easy to difficult, so there is something for everyone.

You will need to bring your own laptop with:
          * Git 
          * Node.js (4.x.x)
          * Your favorite JavaScript editor
        We know it can be very frustrating if something unexpected happens (during the install or the workshop) so we will bring some macbooks with the software preinstalled and tested.
sessions.abstract:
Have you ever been curious to what IoT is, but never really taken the step to try it out? Then this is the perfect workshop for you!

We will be working together in groups of 2-3 people and explore gadgets, sensors, and connect with the all loving cloud. You will be controlling cool gadgets, reading values from the physical world and cooporate with groups in the room to create exciting integrations.

This is a hands-on workshop and the programming language used is Javascript. The targeted platforms are arduino and photons. The devices will be communicating through Firebase.
sessions.title: Internet of Things for Everyone!

speakers.name: Alexander Svendsen
speakers.bio: Alexander is a full-stack developer at BEKK by day and a crime fighting vigilante by night. When he is not fighting super villains he enjoys learning new things and hacking on different hobby projects in domains like machine-learning, functional programming and IOT.

speakers.name: Snorre Lothar von Gohren Edwin
speakers.bio: Snorre is currently a full stack developer at BEKK and generally is curious about new technology. When IoT entered the tech world, Snorre decided that a workshop would suite perfectly for a platform for all the curious techies. Blockchain is another technology that is on Snorre´s radar now. He loves to discuss these subjects with interested people!

speakers.name: Birgitte Haavardsholm
speakers.bio: Birgitte is a fullstack developer at BEKK. She works mostly with java and javascript. At her spare time she enjoys playing with iot and machine learning.

speakers.name: Vegard Veiset
speakers.bio: Vegard is a senior full-stack developer at BEKK and has a passion for internet of things, gadgets and hacks. He enjoys meeting like-minded people and is one of the founders of Pils & Programming Oslo, a meetup which is simply about hacking together on hobby projects while enjoying a few beers.

sessions.intendedAudience:
This session is suitable for anyone who wants to have fun programming art.  It is also relevant for anyone who wants to teach others how to code.

This presentation will mostly consist of live coding, with only a minimal amount of Powerpoint.
sessions.abstract:
To some, programming is an art form. To others, programming can be used to create Art.

When your daily routine consists of hacking boilerplate code and wading through tons of code to fix incomprehensible bugs, relaxing with some simple creative fun programming is just the ticket to start believing in the good things in life again. 

Processing (https://processing.org) may be just that ticket. Attend this session for a practical introduction to the Processing language
sessions.title: The Art of Processing

speakers.name: Ragnar Aas
speakers.bio: Amateur photographer, java professional, globetrotter, music lover, stargazer. In my professional life, I work as a consultant at Bouvet.

sessions.intendedAudience: Alle som er påvirket av arkitektur i store bedrifter.
sessions.abstract:
Vi lager systemer for store bedrifter. Men som stor bedrift har man et helt økosystem av systemer. Noen systemer er kjøpt fordi man fant en god leverandør. Noen er laget fra grunnen av i for eksempel java, og noen (service busser) er der for å lage arkitekturtegningene vakrere!

Så vi kommer ikke unna at Store Bedrifter trenger Arkitektur. Men trenger vi Arkitekter? Og hvordan kan vi utvikle arkitekturen i en bedrift i riktig retning? I dette foredraget ser vi på hvordan vi som mennesker bygger organisasjoner, som bygger systemer. Det betyr at det ikke nødvendigvis blir slik som Sjefarkitekten vil !.
sessions.title: På tur med Arkitektur i STORE Bedrifter

speakers.name: Trond Pedersen
speakers.bio: Trond er en engasjert og løsningsorientert utvikler og arkitekt fra Sopra Steria. Han er en ivrig deltager i Oslos utvikler-miljø, og var blant annet med på å etablere  Smidig-Konferansen og XP-meetup. Han har vært en forkjemper for smidig systemutvikling siden 2001 og setter stor pris på gode diskusjoner om alle aspekter ved systemutvikling.

sessions.intendedAudience:
Ansvarlige utviklere. Ingen spesifikk forkunnskap kreves.

Code in slides.
sessions.abstract:
Kjære ansvarlige utvikler. Du bryr deg om applikasjonen din. Du bryr deg om hvor mange som bruker den, og hvordan hendelser påvirker den. Har responstiden utviklet seg i positiv eller negativ retning i det siste? Den ytelsesforbedringen du gjorde - halverte du virkelig minnebruken slik du trodde, eller økte den i stedet med 10%? Vi mener at de valgene du tar for applikasjonen bør være basert på fakta, og at disse skal være lett tilgjengelig for deg hele veien fra utvikling til produksjon. Denne informasjonen består også av mer enn disk-, minne- og cpu-bruk. Standardmetrikker er vel og bra, men det er først når du kobler disse dataene med informasjon og hendelser som er unike for akkurat din applikasjon at monitoreringsløsningen blir uunnværlig.

Vi vil i løpet av dette fordraget gi deg kunnskapen og verktøyene for å sette opp en skalerbar, robust og åpen monitoreringsløsning med bruk av InfluxDB, Grafana og Sensu, og grave dypere i de tekniske og filosofiske detaljene rundt monitorering. Vi vil også vise hvordan vi har satt opp denne løsningen for over 3000 servere, som til sammen genererer ~1 millard datapunkter per døgn.
sessions.title: Continious Monitoring

speakers.name: Truls Jørgensen
speakers.bio: Blir ofte kalt arkitekt, men kaller seg selv utvikler. 10 års erfaring. Fersk ansatt i NAV. Elsker kode, kaffe og Pearl Jam.

speakers.name: Johnny Horvi
speakers.bio: Engasjert fullstack utviklerfyr med 6 års erfaring. Drikker kulturmelk på daglig basis.

sessions.intendedAudience:
No code. 

For alle som er interessert i å levere store systemer
sessions.abstract:
... produksjonssatte ett år tidligere enn planlagt.

SOFUS-prosjektet hos Skatteetaten lanserte ny plattform for forskuddsberegning ett år før opprinnelig plan. Det inkluderte ny infrastruktur, ny sluttbrukerflate, ny saksbehandlingsløsning og ny beregningsplattform.

Hvordan er det mulig? Svaret får du her.
sessions.title: Offentlig IT-prosjekt bommet på tiden ...

speakers.name: Jørn Ola Birkeland
