speakers.bio: Prosjektleder, arkitekt og utvikler i 20 år, siste 5 år i Skatteetaten i MAG/EDAG og SOFUS.

sessions.intendedAudience: People looking to use Kubernetes in production. Experience with Kubernetes is not requried, but being familiar with containers is assumed.
sessions.abstract:
Kubernetes is a great tool to run (Docker) containers in a clustered production environment. When deploying often to production we need fully automated blue-green deployments, which makes it possible to deploy without any downtime. We also need to handle external HTTP requests and SSL offloading. This requires integration with a load balancer like Ha-Proxy. Another concern is (semi) auto scaling of the Kubernetes cluster itself when running in a cloud environment. E.g.  partially scale down the cluster at night.

In this technical deep dive you will learn how to setup Kubernetes together with other open source components to achieve  a production ready environment that takes code from git commit to production without downtime.
sessions.title: Kubernetes automation in production

speakers.name: Paul Bakker
speakers.bio:
Paul is working as a software architect for Luminis Technologies, where he's currently leading the team that develops the CloudRTI; a Kubernetes/Docker based service that takes care of DevOps tasks like blue/green deployment, failover, centralised logging and monitoring. He is the author of “Building Modular Cloud Apps With OSGi” published by O'Reilly and an advocate for modularity in software. He is currently writing his second book for O'Reilly "Java 9 Modularity" which is expected early 2017.

He's also deeply involved in Amdatu, an open source library for highly modular OSGi components, and several other open source projects. He's a regular speaker on conferences speaking both about modularity/OSGi related topics, and topics related to Kubernetes and cloud architecture in general.

sessions.intendedAudience: Java-utviklere som har begynte å bevege seg inn i verdenen med Java 8 og funksjonell programmering. Kode i slides.
sessions.abstract:
Java 8 åpnet slusene for funksjonell programmering (FP) i Java, men verktøykassen som følger med JDKen er ganske mangelfull. Man har ingen støtte for immutable objekter og datastrukturer, som er helt essensielt innen FP og hjelper deg å fjerne en rekke typer kodefeil. I tillegg mangler for eksempel mer høynivå mekanismer for parallellisering av oppgaver.

I dette foredraget vil vi gå igjennom et utvalg av tredjepartsbiblioteker som du kan ta i bruk for å bøte på disse problemene og gjøre Java-koden din ennå mer sikker og funksjonell!
sessions.title: Hjelp, vi skal kode funksjonelt i Java!

speakers.name: Fredrik Vraalsen
speakers.bio: Fredrik works as a software developer and consultant at Iterate. His main interest the past couple of years has been functional programming and in particluar how to apply this in his daily job as a Java developer. Recently he has started writing Scala for a living and is trying his best to catch up. He's held training courses in Scala and Java 8 and dabbled in Clojure, and likes to speak at conferences.

sessions.intendedAudience: Code in slides, major benefits for Developers and DevOps guys.
sessions.abstract:
Jenkins Pipeline is a game changing way to write automation jobs with Jenkins. Pipeline supports from simple one-step hello-world type jobs to the most complex parallel pipelines or Docker operations like creation or publication of images. Best of all, they support manual/automated intervention and also an extension mechanism to avoid the DRY effect on your build pipeline. Combining Jenkins Pipeline with Docker can seriously reduce friction in your DevOps efforts. 

But Jenkins Pipeline is not the only new thing that are in Jenkins 2.0, there is also UX improvements better out-of-the-box experience and a new website.

Come to this session to learn what’s new in Jenkins 2.0 and how you can improve your Continuous Delivery Pipeline with Jenkins Pipeline as well as see what is coming after Jenkins 2.0.
sessions.title: Jenkins Pipeline, Jenkins 2.0 and Beyond

speakers.name: Alex Soto
speakers.bio:
Alex is a software engineer at Red Hat. He is a passionate of Java world, software automation and he believes in the open source software model.

Alex is the creator of NoSQLUnit project and team member of Arquillian, Asciidoctor and Apache TomEE projects. He is a member of JSR374 (Java API for JSON Processing) Expert Group and coordinator at Barcelona JUG. Currently Alex is co-writing Arquillian in Action book for Manning and he is an international speaker presenting his talks at software conferences like Devoxx, JavaOne, JavaZone or JavaLand.

sessions.intendedAudience: People that are fed up with the BS of our industry!
sessions.abstract:
We love our silver bullets don’t we? Constantly chasing the dream that the next big thing will solve all our past problems. It doesn’t matter if it’s a language, framework, platform or library, we’re out there chasing it. Why? Well because it’s going to solve our needs, it’s going to solve the business needs. Well supposedly it will. And how much is it going to cost? Not that much, especially if we’re not the ones paying the bills. 

It’s about time we look at the hard facts and ask those difficult questions. Are we really looking for a silver bullet?  Why are we constantly riding the technology bandwagon? Where is the churn going to take us? And at what cost?
sessions.title: The Silver Bullet Syndrome

speakers.name: Hadi Hariri
speakers.bio: Developer and creator of many things OSS, his passions includes Web Development and Software Architecture. Has authored a couple of books, a few courses and has been speaking at industry events for nearly 15 years. Currently at JetBrains leading the Developer Advocacy team. Spends as much time as he can writing code.

sessions.intendedAudience: No code
sessions.abstract:
I det siste har brukersentrert design og UX blitt det hotteste hotte som er på alles lepper.  Men hvis vi bare gjør som kunden sier, glemmer vi at en viktig del av rollen vår som eksperter, er å stille spørsmål ved ønskene som strømmer på.

I denne lyntalen ser vi på hvorfor det lønner seg å ikke gjøre som kunden sier. Vi ser på noen skrekk-eksempler hvor kunden fikk bestemme litt for mye, og tilfeller av det motsatte - hvor løsningen ble mye bedre av å ignorere brukernes ønsker.
sessions.title: Ikke gjør som kunden din sier!

speakers.name: Anne Landro
speakers.bio: Anne Landro har jobbet med systemutvikling i mange år. Den siste tiden har hun hatt mest fokus på det funksjonelle aspektet av det å lage gode systemer. Hun liker godt å prøve forskjellige roller, og trives best når hun kan få en god forståelse av helheten og behovene bak et system.

sessions.intendedAudience: Utviklere som vil ha kode sikkert og raskt ut i produksjon. Live koding med eksempler i Java og Groovy.
sessions.abstract:
Da FINN Reise lagde sin nye plattform i 2013, var det en forutsetning at kode skulle rulles ut kontinuerlig. For å få til dette, var vi avhengige av at ny kode som traff produksjon oppførte seg som den skulle og ikke klusset det til for allerede eksisterende funksjonalitet. 

Dette er historien om hvordan Continous Integration og Continous Delivery er en naturlig del av en utviklers hverdag i FINN Reise.  Vi viser hvordan tester hjelper oss på vei, hvordan utviklernes rolle har forandret seg og tar et dykk inn i FINNs interne infrastruktur.
sessions.title: Hvordan FINN Reise ruller ut kode i produksjon 42 ganger om dagen

speakers.name: Per Jørgen Walstrøm
speakers.bio: Per Jørgen Walstrøm er Team Lead på FINN Reise. Han har  jobbet som utvikler siden dot.com-bølgen på slutten av 90-tallet og finner fortsatt motivasjon og indre glede i en test som lyser grønt.

speakers.name: Stig Kleppe-Jørgensen
speakers.bio: Stig Kleppe-Jørgensen er Lead Developer på FINN Reise. Han har jobbet som utvikler fra midten av 90-åra og levd med for lav testdekning og tilhørende smerte, da det til slutt ble ny jobb og grønne bygg hos FINN. Han er stadig på utkikk etter nye bibliotek/verktøy som kan gjøre hverdagen lettere for utviklerne i teamet. Ikke minst for at veien for å få kode ut i produksjon blir så sikker og rask som mulig.

sessions.intendedAudience: This talk is aimed at programmers interested in advanced concurrency who want to develop algorithms with predictable response times at all levels of throughput which push our modern CPUs to the limit.
sessions.abstract:
Concurrent programming with locks is hard. Concurrent programming without using locks can be really hard. Concurrent programming with relaxed memory ordering and predictable latency semantics is said to be only for wizards. This talk focuses on a decade long quest to discover algorithms and data structures that provide very high throughput while keeping latency low and predictable. Additionally, data structures need to provide real-time telemetry on how a system is performing via non-blocking operations.

We will cover some fundamental theory of concurrency and then compare various approaches to the same problem so that we can measure the impact on latency. We'll also show how some of these algorithm implementations get more interesting given the new features in Java 8.
sessions.title: A quest for predictable latency with Java concurrency

speakers.name: Martin Thompson
speakers.bio:
Martin is a Java Champion with over 2 decades of experience building complex and high-performance computing systems. He is most recently known for his work on Aeron and SBE. Previously at LMAX he was the co-founder and CTO when he created the Disruptor. Prior to LMAX Martin worked for Betfair, three different content companies wrestling with the world largest product catalogues, and was a lead on some of the most significant C++ and Java systems of the 1990s in the automotive and finance domains.

He blogs at mechanical-sympathy.blogspot.com, and can be found giving training courses on performance and concurrency when he is not cutting code to make systems better.

sessions.intendedAudience: Anybody who needs to make a choice on a database
sessions.abstract:
In hardly any other area we’ve had as much change and improvement as in the field of databases. Just a few years ago everyone had “their” database that was used for each project. Today you are confronted with a variety of approaches and implementations.

We start off with a brief look at the theoretical background of distributed systems and databases in particular. After that, we discuss possible scenarios as well as the advantages and disadvantages of several databases:

* Why SQL is in fashion (again). 
* Why MongoDB’s document structure fits object-oriented programming so well. 
* How you can capture visitor hits with Redis efficiently. 
* Why Cassandra is so scalable and fail-safe. 
* How full-text search works with Elasticsearch.

The right choice of database(s) hasn’t become easier through the wide range of possibilities, but all the more interesting!
sessions.title: Databases — the choice is yours

speakers.name: Philipp Krenn
speakers.bio: Philipp is a Developer Advocate at Elastic, spreading the love and knowledge of full-text search, analytics, and real-time data. He is a frequent speaker at conferences and meetups about all things search & analytics, databases, cloud computing, and devops. Philipp lives in Vienna where he enjoys experimenting with software, organizing meetups, and sports.

sessions.intendedAudience: The talk will switch between presenting the functional aspects of the prototype as well as showing how the functionality materializes by showing code in slides and code in an IDE.
sessions.abstract:
"Hendelsesregistrering" (Event Registration) is a prototype developed for the police in Norway, focusing on assisting crime investigations and analysis by being able to detect phenomena and patterns in crime. The aim is to give the police the information they need at the right time to make better decisions, support crime investigations, see connections between events, and identify phenomena and patterns in crime. 

The prototype is based on semantic web technologies, and adopts the Apache Jena framework for semantic web programming with Java. This presentation will go through the functional aspect of the solution, with a closer look at how the Apache Jena framework for Java supports the entire back-end stack.
sessions.title: Disclosing patterns and phenomena in crime with semantic Java

speakers.name: Magnus Stuhr
speakers.bio:
I am senior developer working for Computas, and have been in the industry for five years. I have been involved in several projects, both for the industry and academia, and for the private and public sectors.

I am passionate about Java, best-practices and testing of code, and semantic web technologies. My main focus has always been on how semantic web technologies can be incorporated with Java, where I have also conducted a bit of research, resulting in two journal publications.

sessions.intendedAudience: Dette foredraget er for alle de som er litt nysgjerrige på funksjonell programmering og om java8 er veien å gå fremover. Utviklere, prosjektledere, arkitekter, alle er velkomne. Det vil være kodeeksempler i både Java og Scala, men ikke veldig avanserte.
sessions.abstract:
Mange har forsøkt reisen fra javaland til Scalaland, noen har fått oppholdstilatelse mens andre fikk sin søknad avslått og måtte returnere til Javaland. Dette er en annen historie. Hvordan er det for en fastboende i Scalaland i mange år å returnere til javaland etter java8-regimet har åpnet for retur av funksjonelle programmerere?

Dette er et erfaringsforedrag om hvordan dette, nå et år senere, har gått. 
Hvordan fungerer java til funksjonell programmering nå? 
Hva er det beste med å komme tilbake, og hva er det verste?
Har oppholdet i Scalaland endret hvordan jeg skriver Javakode?
sessions.title: En Scalaflyktning i Javaland

speakers.name: Kaare Nilsen
speakers.bio: En lidenskapelig programmerer med mer enn 15 års erfaring fra prosjekter i forskjellige bransjer hos både private og offentlige kunder.  Kaare er ikke redd for å heve stemmen og snakker ofte om tema relatert til programmering og open source på meetups og konferanser.

sessions.intendedAudience: You need a basic understanding of test automation and performance testing to make the most out of this session. The talk will be a combination of slides and live coding.
sessions.abstract:
Performance testing is traditionally a task for specialists that takes place at the very end of the software delivery life cycle. But how does this fit in with a DevOps way of working, where continuous feedback is one of the key points? It doesn't. In a world where scalability and performance are just as important as delivering new features, you need to embed performance testing in your daily development workflow: it needs to become a natural part of development. And this is where Gatling comes in: an open source load testing framework based on Scala, Akka and Netty. In this session, you will learn how to use Gatling to incorporate performance testing in development and how to provide your team with continuous feedback on your application's performance.
Subjects include an introduction to Gatling, automated recording and processing of performance tests with the Gatling Scala DSL and integration with Jenkins for automated execution, bench marking and reporting of load tests.
sessions.title: Continuous performance: load testing for developers with Gatling

speakers.name: Bert Jan Schrijver
speakers.bio: Bert Jan is a Software craftsman at JPoint in the Netherlands and Java User Group leader for NLJUG, the Dutch Java User Group. His focus is on Java, Continuous Delivery and DevOps. He loves to share his experience by speaking at conferences, writing for the Dutch Java magazine and helping out Devoxx4Kids with teaching kids how to code.

sessions.intendedAudience: Alle som bruker en smarttelefon og ikke blir vippet av pinnen når de hører om bluetoothteknologi. Presentasjonen kan inneholde spor av kode.
sessions.abstract:
I Giant Leap er vi i gang med to spennende beaconprosjekter. Det ene er et pilotprosjekt for en stor norsk matvarekjede, og i det andre bruker vi beacons til betaling.  Matvarekjeden vil bruke beacons for å gi kunder en bedre handleopplevelse. I det prosjektet er vi i ferd med å utvikle en app som skal gi kunder riktig tilbud til riktig tid. I utvikling av betalingsløsningen er vi helt nede på jernet. Bruk av beacons er nybrottsarbeid, og i kjølvannet det følger det er en rekke spennende utfordringer. I matvareprosjektet må vi ta stilling til en rekke motsetninger; vi må ta hensyn til personvern, og samtidig gi en personlig tilpasset kjøpsopplevelse. Vi vil gi god informasjon, uten å irritere kundene. 
I betalingsprosjektet er en av de største utfordringene hvordan vi utnytter IP6-protokoll maksimalt.

I dette foredraget vil vi gjerne fortelle hva vi har lært om bruk av beacons, så langt; Mobil- og Javautvikling kan vi, men beacons er litt nytt for oss ennå. Vi vil fortelle om hvilke utfordringer vi har møtt på og hvordan vi har gått frem for å løse dem, både konseptuelt og teknisk, med vår beacons - mobil - Java- stack. 
Vi har snublet litt underveis, men kom vi i mål? Kom, så skal du få høre.


Giant Leap Technologies er Norges fremste kompetansemiljø innen mobil tjenesteutvikling. http://www.giantleap.no/
sessions.title: En suksesshistorie om Java, mobil og beacons (og litt om hva som gikk galt)

speakers.name: Arne Jervell
speakers.bio: Arne Jervell har vært CTO i Giant Leap Technologies i 5 år. Han gikk ut fra Datateknikk på NTNU i 2002, etter å ha spesialisert seg på grafikk og algoritmer. Han brenner for mobilutvikling, personvern, pizzabaking og alt som er kult.

speakers.name: Kari Bergh Schjønsby
speakers.bio: Kari kommer fra BEKK Consulting, og er nå et av de nyeste tilskuddene til Giant Leap. Hun var klassekamerat med Arne på NTNU, og har også mer enn 14 år i IT-bransjen. Kari kan gire seg opp over det meste som er gjennomtenkt, lekkert og går fort.

sessions.intendedAudience: This talk is for everyone who generate data, and has an interest in open data. There will be some RDF code in slides, but no knowledge of the W3C standards is needed. Although, some general knowledge of RDF is a bonus.
sessions.abstract:
On a web where huge amount of data is available at all time, everywhere, there is a growing need for data consistency and data integrity. When we talk about data, we talk about all things that we may say something about. By following some simple rules about naming things you may achieve consistency and integrity by providing context to your open data. In the Semantic Web we call this data 5-starred data. 

I will explain what 5-starred data is, why it is important, and how you may make your data 5-starred. We will dip into the Linked Open Data Cloud and look at how the data are structured using W3C standards and find out what makes data in the web, rather than just on the web.
sessions.title: Is your data 5-starred?

speakers.name: Veronika Heimsbakk
speakers.bio:
I work as a Java developer at Acando in Oslo. I recently ended my studies in the wonders of programming and problem solving at the University of Oslo, where I fell in love with the Semantic Web and logic. For the past year I've been working with semantic technologies in several in-house and external projects. I've been a part of the "semantic revolution" at Acando, by writing blog posts and throwing several talks on the subject.

Other than worshiping Linked Open Data, I enjoy Turing machines, circuit electronics, brewing beer and hunting.

sessions.intendedAudience: Lyntalen er for alle utviklere som frontend.  Lyntalen tar for seg hvordan man kan behandle statisk data  i en single page application.  Det vil være kode-eksempler i slides. Krever ingen forkunnskaper om React eller relativitetsteorien.
sessions.abstract: I denne lyntalen skal vi se på hvordan vi brukte fossefall, parallelitet og relativitet til å håndtere statiske data i vår applikasjon. I tillegg skal vi forsøke å besvare de store spørsmålene her i livet: Kan statisk data aldri endre seg? Hvor skal den statiske dataen leve?
sessions.title: Hva er egentlig statisk data?

speakers.name: Emil Staurset
speakers.bio: Emil har jobbet som utvikler i BEKK siden 2015. Har en mastergrad i datateknikk fra NTNU, og han er mer enn gjennomsnittlig interessert i funksjonell programmering og statisk data

sessions.intendedAudience: Utviklarar. Prosjektledarar. Arkitektar. IT-ledarar. Null kode.
sessions.abstract:
... for til og med me i smidige vesle javaBin sliter.

Sidan DevOps byrja å bli hot for ein 4-5 år sidan har bransjen sett ein bråte med DevOps-initiativ rundt omkring, men meir enn ein gong har ein starta forbetringane i feil ende. Når du høyrer på folk prata om DevOps og Kontinuerlige leveransar får du fort inntrykk av at alt har ei teknisk løysning. I så fall har du bomma ... kraftig. Gløym teknologien. Start med det mjuke.

Kom og høyr ein desillusjonert utviklar prata om kva Kodesmia i javaBin har til felles med store offentlige IT-prosjekt, korleis me automatiserte alt og samstundes gjorde alle redde for å ta på ting og kvifor eg endte opp som ein seig driftar.
sessions.title: DevOps e' grisevanskelig

speakers.name: Sveinung Dalatun
speakers.bio: Aktiv i Kodesmia i javaBin. Fagledar for Kontinuerlige leveransar og DevOps i BEKK.

sessions.intendedAudience: Developers that want to level up from TDD and static code analysis
sessions.abstract:
Mutation testing is the true test for whether or not your source code does the right thing, and whether it's properly tested by your unit tests. But while we're on a killing spree against the mutants of our source code, let's reflect a bit on what these mutants really represent, and why we want to include the unit tests that kill them in our test suite.

What's the real point of boundary testing? Do we really need every statement in the source code? Have we tested all calculations? How do we know that we got all the access modifiers on our methods right? These are some of the questions that we would like to reflect on for a moment.

We'll start this talk with a short introduction to mutation testing, but only to set the stage. The core of this talk consists of a walk-through of Java code and unit tests, and a reflection on TDD and the quality of our unit tests. At the end of this talk you should be more suspicious about both your source code and your unit tests.
sessions.title: Dial M for Mutation

speakers.name: Filip van Laenen
speakers.bio: Filip van Laenen is a Chief Architect at the Norwegian software company Computas AS, which supplies IT solutions to the public and the private sector in Norway. He has almost twenty years of experience in the software industry, from being a developer in both small and large teams to being the lead developer and competency leader for security and software engineering for the whole company. During the last years, he has spent some time using mutation testing, which has given him a number of aha! moments he would like to share with other developers.

sessions.intendedAudience: No experience with machine learning needed.
sessions.abstract:
What is Machine Learning as a Service? Which do I choose? How can I use it in my application?

Machine learning has long been a somewhat academic discipline, its practitioners highly specialized. But with the advent of a new class of commoditized machine learning platforms, MLaaS, Machine Learning as a Service, is now available to all developers.

MLaaS can be treated as a black box, giving developers the opportunity to dive into machine learning head first. Supply your own data, build a model using tools supported by your chosen MLaaS platform and train it using the well tested algorithms offered. When ready to dig deeper into the world of machine learning, most MLaaS platforms enables us to develop our own algorithms even better tailored to our data and models.

This talk will show you the state of the art of MLaaS, what the different vendors offer, and where you best can put it to use in your applications.
sessions.title: MLaaS - Machine Learning for the rest of us

speakers.name: Anders Breivik
speakers.bio: Anders is a fallen mathematician with over 10 years of experience from his backup plan as a software developer. As a consultant with the Nordic consultancy Knowit, Anders enjoys working with both large critical enterprise systems and small scale mobile solutions. Currently Anders is passionate about IoT, iBeacons and mini drones.

sessions.intendedAudience: This talk is suitable for everyone with reasonable experience in software development. Since this session is more about people and process than about code, there'll be (almost) no code in this talk.
sessions.abstract:
DevOps is the new black. You need DevOps. Right now.   
What? You're not doing DevOps yet? Hurry! You're going to miss the boat!  

Sounds familiar? The same thing happened with Agile a while ago. Coined as a solution for all your problems, companies rushed to implement this 'next big thing', only to realize a few years later that they got most of it wrong by failing to understand the concepts behind it well enough in the first place.  

Don't make the same mistake again. Getting DevOps right isn't easy. It's downright hard. In this talk, I'm not going to explain how to 'do' DevOps in your organisation, since there is not just one 'right' way to do it. What I can show you however, is how NOT to do DevOps.  
This session shares 15 common misconceptions, call them anti-patterns, of DevOps. I'll talk from my own experiences in getting things wrong, explain why they are wrong and prevent you from making the same mistakes. You'll leave this session with a basic understanding of how (not) to fail at DevOps and hopefully, a smile on your face ;-)
sessions.title: The DevOps disaster: 15 ways to fail at DevOps

speakers.name: Bert Jan Schrijver
speakers.bio: Bert Jan is a Software craftsman at JPoint in the Netherlands and Java User Group leader for NLJUG, the Dutch Java User Group. His focus is on Java, Continuous Delivery and DevOps. He loves to share his experience by speaking at conferences, writing for the Dutch Java magazine and helping out Devoxx4Kids with teaching kids how to code.

sessions.intendedAudience: Some code is shown for both android phone(java/xml) and server(golang). The talk is intended for people who are aware of or should be aware of the possible security flaw of bluetooth enabled wearables.
sessions.abstract: You want push messages every time your neighbour comes home? How about location of every time your neighbour is in the nearabouts of a phone with your app on it?  All kinds of wearable devices are enabled with bluetooth and emits signals that everyone can read. Listening for these signals with a simple smartphone and logging it to a server makes a possible illegal but very effective surveillance system network.  This talk is a demonstration of how easy it is to build a full fledged surveillance system with just an app and a server.
sessions.title: Tracking location of your neighbours wearable with Android

speakers.name: Nils Larsgård
speakers.bio: Senior developer with experience from backend, frontend and app development. Love to learn new stuff and have tons of side-projects. Currently working as a consultant for my own company, bytecode.no .

sessions.intendedAudience:
Primarily intended for the seasoned developer who want to write secure code, but who also has realised that the day-to-day development work does not leave room for thinking “security” all the time. You probably carry roles as system architect or lead developer, or have informal roles as goto-guy/gal.
There will be code in slides and the discussion will be about principles for how to write code.
sessions.abstract:
We all know we have Anonymous, LulzSec, and NSA around. With this in mind, isn’t it time to think about the security of our systems? Well, of course. In this talk, we’ll show how Domain Driven Design is used to counteract security weaknesses without one thinking “security” all the time. So, if you’re interested in learning how to design secure software, then this session is for you.
Business and technical attacks are two kinds of attacks, where the latter is most famous, e g SQL Injection & XSS. But it doesn’t mean business attacks are less harmful. On the contrary, they tend to be extremely sophisticated and powerful as they often leave infrastructure intact without firing alarms. Domain Driven Security is the field that counteracts both categories by using tools and mindsets from DDD.
sessions.title: Your Business is under Attack; Arm yourself with Domain Driven Security

speakers.name: Dan Bergh Johnsson
speakers.bio: Agile aficionado; Domain Driven Design enthusiast; code quality craftsman, with a long time interest in security. The combination made Dan use quality practices from DDD to address application security issues - thus coining "Domain Driven Security" together with John Wilander around 2009. Has spoken on similar topics at numerous renown conferences including JavaZone, Devoxx, Jfokus, QCon etc

speakers.name: Daniel Deogun
speakers.bio: Coder and Quality defender; brings order to a chaotic world of bits and bytes through good design and clean code; fights security trolls on a daily basis using magic spells from DDD and an overall security mindset. Daniel's extensive experience ranges from patient critical pacemaker systems to web applications to high performant software in the gaming industry. Combining this with his passion for agile and tech has made him a frequent speaker at international conferences.

sessions.intendedAudience: Utviklere som er nysgjerrige på hvordan man kan bruke mikrotjenester også til frontend.
sessions.abstract:
Amedia har i vår skrevet om hele arkitekturen for å rendre forsiden for nettavisene fra å være en Java-Monolitt til en mikrotjenestearkitektur med små node.js-applikasjoner som kjører i docker.

Jeg vil gå igjennom hvorfor vi gjorde dette, hvilke valg vi gjorde, og hvordan dette har gitt en mer robust arkitektur, en bedre hverdag for utviklerne og avisene mer spillerom til hvordan de vil ha sin egen forside.
sessions.title: Bruk av node og esi i en mikrotjenestearkitektur for å rendre forsiden til halvparten av norske lokalaviser

speakers.name: Sindre Ilebekk Johansen
speakers.bio: Utvikler og Devopser som er nysgjerrig av natur.

sessions.intendedAudience: Utviklere som ønsker å utvikle noe utenom sin "day job". No code.
sessions.abstract: Har du fått en ide til noe du vil lage? Et produkt du har lyst til å utvikle, men ikke nok til at du vil si opp jobben eller sette igang en startup? Christian utviklet på fritiden gjennom flere år appen "Oslo i gamle dager", som blant annet ble omtalt i Aftenposten (http://www.osloby.no/nyheter/Her-er-appen-som-tar-deg-tilbake-til-det-gamle-Oslo-8169441.html). Appen er  en ios-app som benytter en javabasert server i Googles cloud. Basert på sine erfaringer fra denne prosessen, vil han motivere til hobbyprosjekter og gi nyttige råd og tips til hvordan slike prosjekter kan gjennomføres.
sessions.title: Not ready to quit your day job? Hvordan lykkes med hobbyprosjekter?

speakers.name: Christian Aamodt
speakers.bio: Christian er en erfaren utvikler, og har jobbet som konsulent med javabaserte webprosjekter siden 1998. Han har utviklet apper siden 2010, blant annet den prisbelønte appen "Kubbe lager skyggeteater" fra 2013 og appen "Oslo i gamle dager". Christian jobber nå som konsulent for Bouvet Norge.

sessions.intendedAudience: The talk is intended for intermediate or advanced developers familiar with either Java or Scala. The audience is expected to previously have seen basic functional constructs, such as lambdas. We will present working code examples in Java and Scala. We will perform little live coding, but use IntelliJ as our presentation medium and primarily show code on screen. I.e. “Code in slides”.
sessions.abstract: Functional programming constructs have risen in popularity in recent years, driven by the Big Data hype.  The object-oriented paradigm is likely to remain dominant, but there is opportunity to enrich our toolboxes by picking up some instruments from the functional world. We will present a set of functional constructs applicable for asynchronous programming, error handling, and data processing. We will skip past basic and now well-known functional constructs, such as lambdas, streams, map, and reduce, and focus on techniques that are not yet part of most object-oriented programmers’ toolboxes: reactive patterns, currying, disjunctions, lenses, and more. The constructs presented will be applicable in familiar, object-oriented contexts, and not require a functional mindset.
sessions.title: Functional patterns for object-oriented minds

speakers.name: Lars Albertsson
speakers.bio: Lars Albertsson has worked with data-intensive and scalable applications throughout his corporate career - at Google, natural language processing startup Recorded Future, and with stock exchange systems. He rolled out the current data processing infrastructure at Spotify, and moved on to be architect for data processing infrastructure and user modelling for the new central technology organisation at Schibsted Media Group. He is now an independent consultant, helping companies build scalable data processing solutions.

sessions.intendedAudience: De fleste som er involvert i en systemutviklingsprosess kan ha nytte av denne lyntalen. Spesielt utviklere, arkitekter, testere og prosjektledere eller produkteiere. De fleste vil kjenne igjen problemstillingene vi ser på, og få en aha-opplevelse om hva slags avhengigheter og bindinger som kan spille inn i en systemutviklingsprosess og hvilken konsekvens de kan ha. Lite kode i slidene.
sessions.abstract:
Ved utvikling av IT-systemer oppstår mange typer avhengigheter og bindinger. De kan vise seg på ulike nivåer og i ulike faser i løpet av en utviklingsprosess, men  har til felles at de medfører kostnader. Og noen koster mer enn andre.

Hvilke avhengigheter har vi, hva koster de, og kan de unngås? Og hvilke bryr vi oss egentlig mest om? La oss gå igjennom noen typiske avhengigheter både av teknisk, testmessig og leveransemessig art og se litt nærmere på hva de medfører!
sessions.title: Avhengighetens pris

speakers.name: Torstein Gjengedal
speakers.bio: Torstein har jobbet i 15 år med utvikling, arkitektur og rådgivning. Han er vant til sammensatte systemporteføljer, har erfaring med både tekniske perspektiver, kvalitetssikring og leveranseprosesser og søker alltid etter enkle løsninger.

sessions.intendedAudience: For de som tror de driver med DevOps, synes DevOps høres kult ut, eller bare har lyst på en kjapp innføring i DevOps. Ingen kode!
sessions.abstract: Du driver ikke med DevOps selv om du har en byggserver som bygger på push til master! Du driver ikke med DevOps selv om du har tatt i bruk PaaS tjenester i skyen! Du driver ikke med DevOps selv om du deployer Docker containere med Mesos! Du driver ikke med DevOps før du har tatt inn over deg hva DevOps faktisk er. Så la meg forklare deg DevOps!
sessions.title: Du tror du driver med DevOps du..

speakers.name: David Kai Christen Kristensen
speakers.bio: Til daglig jobber David som systemkonsulent i Mesan AS hvor han også er leder for faggruppen for Cloud & DevOps. Han er lidenskapelig opptatt av distribuerte systemer, fra skytjenester til mesh-nettverk. Han hater idiotiske administrative hindringer i utviklingsprosessen, og er ikke redd for å fortelle deg hvor han mener skapet burde stå!

sessions.intendedAudience: Anyone interested in continuous learning and improvement. Anyone who believes developers should take responsibility for how their code behaves in production.
sessions.abstract:
All systems fail. In the aftermath it can be easy to point fingers and assign blame, but this can obscure important lessons and opportunities to learn. In this talk, I'll explain what a blameless post mortem is and share some experience about how our team applies them to learn from downtime and bugs. I'll also cover why it's an important activity for both developers and operators.

After this talk you will have the tools to immediately get started with blameless post mortems and a list of resources gaining a deeper understanding of how and why they work.
sessions.title: The road to nines is paved with war stories

speakers.name: Andreas Jacobsen
speakers.bio: Andreas Jacobsen is tech lead for Web Solutions at Posten. He enjoys programming and self-referential jokes. He does not enjoy writing about himself in the third person.

sessions.intendedAudience: Er en ny måte å gjøre innlogging på interessant eller synes det er gøy med nye teknologier er dette noe for deg. Passer for alle og det blir ingen kode.
sessions.abstract:
Brukernavn og passord er en ut datert og usikker måte å gjøre logg-inn på. Vi bør begynne å se på alternativer som er sikrere og kanskje enklere. 

Et av alternativene er SQRL det eliminerer mange problemer som finnes ved tradisjonell innlogging. 
Jeg snakket om det samme i fjor, men nå er det endelig ferdig spesifisert og det burde være mulig å se hvordan det kan gjøres.
sessions.title: Så enkelt kan innlogging være

speakers.name: Liv Kolås
speakers.bio: Liv Kolås jobber som konsulent(i EVRY) og utvikler fordi hun liker å lage ting og kunne se resultatet av det hun gjør på slutten av dagen. I tillegg setter hun pris på en utfordring og det å tenke ut gode løsninger. På fritiden driver Liv med håndarbeid (mye strikking). I tillegg er hun interessert i sikkerhet og prøver og holde seg litt oppdatert på dette området.

sessions.intendedAudience: Utviklere med kjennskap til Javascript. Alle som vurderer å lage eller få utviklet en løsning med offline støtte.
sessions.abstract:
For å støtte offline datahåndtering med bakgrunnssynkronisering måtte man før utvikle native-applikasjoner. Nå har dette blitt mulig i nettleseren!

I denne lyntalen vil vi se nærmere på teknologier som blant annet LocalStorage, IndexedDB, NetworkInformation og Service Workers background sync API som gjør det mulig å lagre data offline som synkroniseres automatisk når brukeren er på nett selv om brukeren har lukket nettsiden. Og dette er mulig helt uten å bruke en spesialtilpasset nettleser eller andre rammeverk som Cordova.

Basert på praktisk erfaringer vil du få en oversikt over hvilke muligheter og begrensninger som finnes per i dag.
sessions.title: Offline webapps med bakgrunnsynkronisering

speakers.name: Anders Skar
speakers.bio: Anders har mange års erfaring med utvikling av komplekse web- og native applikasjoner, deriblant forretningskritiske applikasjoner med krav offline lagring. Alltid nysgjerrig på å teste ut det siste innen teknologi og dingser.

sessions.intendedAudience: Ingen forkunnskap om maskinlæring er nødvendig. Kode vil bli vist i slidene.
sessions.abstract:
Maskinlæring er godt på vei fra hype til mainstream og kommersialiseres allerede gjennom tjenester fra Azure, Amazon og Google. Det som før måtte programmeres med biblioteker og krevde domenekunnskap, kan nå settes sammen som legoklosser med svært få, eller ingen linjer med kode.

Få en intro til maskinlæring og hva sky-tjenestene for maskinlæring har å tilby. Kodeekspempler vil vise hvordan du kan bruke disse tjenestene eller skape et eget API basert på åpne biblioteker.
sessions.title: Kom i gang med maskinlæring i skyen!

speakers.name: Simen Skogen
speakers.bio: Simen er utdannet sivilingeniør i datateknikk fra NTNU, med en fordypning innen kunstig intelligens og maskinlæring. Han har jobbet i 2 år hos Capgemini, og jobber for tiden med både backend og frontend til utvikling av nettbank. Simen har en spesiell interesse for 'smarte' algoritmer, visualisering og fine brukergrensesnitt.

sessions.intendedAudience:
Participants will learn:

* how to quickly and effectively build edge services
* how to integrate edge services with existing services
* how to optimize for mobile devices
* how to leverage edge services securely

Knowledge of microservices and/or Java is helpful, but not required.

(Live coding)
sessions.abstract:
Devices (phones, tablets, etc.) already consume most services/data, but they have to get those services somewhere! In this session, learn how to use proven patterns & open source software to quickly and effectively build edge services - API gateways - that marshal & streamline communication between your key services and end-users with devices in hand. This session addresses vital points such as:

* Leveraging OAuth2 for service security
* Configuration services
* Microservice registration and discovery
* Circuit breakers for graceful degradation

Additional topics discussed include logging & tracing, testing approaches, and migration patterns.

The presenter will demonstrate how to develop & manage microservices & expose them via an edge service, securely, using OSS tools employed by Netflix to keep movies streaming globally 24x7.
sessions.title: Living on the Edge (Service): Bundling Microservices to Optimize for Devices

speakers.name: Mark Heckler
speakers.bio:
Mark Heckler is a Pivotal Principal Technologist & Developer Advocate, conference speaker, and published author focusing upon software development for the Internet of Things and the Cloud. He has worked with key players in the manufacturing, retail, medical, scientific, telecom, and financial industries and various public sector organizations to develop and deliver critical capabilities on time and on budget. Mark is an open source contributor and author/curator of a developer-focused blog (http://www.thehecklers.org) and an occasionally interesting Twitter account (@MkHeck).

Mark lives with his very understanding wife in St. Louis, MO USA.

sessions.intendedAudience:
Developers, testers and anyone else working on solutions that users are interacting with. 

There will be plenty of code in slides, but the talk should be possible to follow for anyone. We will start off on a basic level, and we will work our way up to a more advanced level together.
sessions.abstract:
Since July 1st 2014, all IT solutions in Norway are bound by law to follow the requirements of WCAG 2.0 including level AA. A lot of people seem to think this is so that blind people can use websites. They are not wrong, but still it is so much more. Implemented correctly, a universally designed solution will benefit all of us, and the target groups include many others, like older-, drunk- and sunbathing users. 

In this talk I will give some insights into what kind of users to think about when designing, implementing and testing IT solutions, as well as what you should think about with regards to the different user groups.

I will also present tips and methods on how to implement a solution conforming to the WCAG 2.0 AA requirements and alert you to some of the normal pitfalls. We will be looking at plenty of code examples, showing both good and bad implementations.

After listening to this talk, you will have a much better understanding of why and how to implement a universal design, and hopefully be motivated to go back to work and convince your coworkers to get on bord too!
sessions.title: Implement universally designed solutions or your drunk grandma will suffer for it!

speakers.name: Vegard Haugstvedt
speakers.bio:
Vegard is a color-blind, full-stack developer (alternating between Java and frontend-code) and has been trained in Universal Design. He worked on one of the first major projects going live after the law of Universal Design went into effect, and draws a lot of experience from that. 

There are few better ways of getting him riled up than arguing that Universal Design is not neccessary, and he dreams about the day Universal Design is as much of a given as writing unit tests.

sessions.intendedAudience: Live coding. Well, we'll browse through the code rather than write it on the spot. But there are pre-created code snippets we'll use.
sessions.abstract:
In this session we'll create a new programming language! We'll construct its grammar, semantics, operations and the interpreter for the language. Additionally, we'll learn about parsers and how to perform simple optimizations, both at compile time and otherwise. Most importantly we'll tackle the interoperability problem with the underlying platform, which in our case is the JVM.

This session will briefly discuss type systems, optimizations, memory management and concurrency issues that programming languages all encounter. Have you ever wanted to create a programming language of your own? After this session you will have seen all the tools you need to do so and will understand more about how are programming languages work including the challenges you’ll face.
sessions.title: How to Create a New JVM Language in Under an Hour

speakers.name: Oleg Šelajev
speakers.bio: Oleg Šelajev is an engineer, author, speaker, lecturer and advocate at ZeroTurnaround. He spends his time testing, coding, writing, giving conference talks, crafting blogposts and reports. He is pursuing a PhD on Dynamic System updates and code evolution. Oleg is a part-time lecturer at the University of Tartu and enjoys speaking and participating in Java/JVM development conferences such as JavaOne, JavaZone, JFokus and others.

sessions.intendedAudience: This talk is for people interested in the details of the HotSpot Virtual Machine implementation. The audience should have a general understanding of VM technology or at least be interested in learning about it. We will do some "Live coding" during this session up to the native level.
sessions.abstract:
By definition, intrinsics are functions which are handled specially by the compiler or the VM. The HotSpot virtual machine supports intrinsics for specific API functions in the interpreter as well as in the C1 and C2 JIT compilers. In general, intrinsics are a great possibility for optimization. But they also come at a certain cost. First of all, they are inherently platform and implementation dependent. If available, they can lead to consistency problems if they are implemented differently in the interpreter and the JIT compilers. Finally, they can change the program control (e.g. safepoint behavior) and observability (e.g. profiling, instrumentation) in subtle ways.

This talk will give you a short deep dive into the HotSpot Virtual Machine using the example of HotSpot intrinsics. It will explain how they are implemented and the implications this has for the Java VM. Finally, it will demonstrate how you can add a new intrinsic for your favourite Java method.
sessions.title: HotSpot Intrinsics

speakers.name: Volker Simonis
speakers.bio: Volker Simonis works for SAP in the SAP JVM Technology group. He is an OpenJDK contributor from the very beginning and helped SAP and the SAP JVM team engage in the OpenJDK project. He's the project lead of the OpenJDK PowerPC/AIX porting project, a JDK9 reviewer and a JCP Executive Committee representative for SAP.

sessions.intendedAudience:
Utviklere som er nysgjerrig på hvordan parallelle streams faktisk fungerer.

"Code in slides"
sessions.abstract:
Java 8 kom med et nytt og spennende streams API, som gir oss Java-utviklere helt nye muligheter for prosessering av data. I tillegg kan man enkelt velge om operasjoner på en stream skal utføres sekvensielt eller i parallell.

Det å kjøre stream-operasjoner i parallell kan ved første øyekast virke enkelt og ufarlig, men er det egentlig så lurt? Vi gjør et kort dypdykk i hvordan parallelle streams faktisk fungerer, når man bør bruke de, og ikke minst om man bør bruke de i det hele tatt.
sessions.title: (Når) bør man bruke parallelle streams?

speakers.name: Henrik Wingerei
speakers.bio: Henrik Wingerei jobber som seniorkonsulent i BEKK hvor han har jobbet som fullstack utvikler i 4 år. Henrik er interessert i teknologi, alternative språk og paradigmer, og alt som rører seg rundt en applikasjon. Henrik har tidligere holdt foredrag på både JavaZone og meetups.

sessions.intendedAudience:
Developers interested in functional programming

Code demo and in slides
sessions.abstract:
The arrival of Java 8 has made it possible to make better APIs.
I have made a new JSON library for Java 8, which encodes the RFC
using functional programming style.

In this talk I will walk you through how I did this, using 
concepts as Algebraic Data Types (ADTs) and other useful functional
programming patterns like Isomorphisms and Functor and CoFunctors.

I will describe a way of using fold as the basic building block for 
expressing your api, and as the most powerful tool in the ADT.

Lastly I will explain how we can use these techniques to 
do decoding and encoding of JSON without using reflection in Java 8.
sessions.title: Functional JSON in Java 8

speakers.name: Erlend Hamnaberg
speakers.bio: Erlend is a consultant working for Arktekk. He is very interested in function programming and spends quite a bit of his free time developing more or less useful libraries. He is a former chairman of javaBin and has been active in the community for a long time. The main language of choice is Scala, but since a lot of clients still use Java, we need to build useful libraries there as well.

sessions.intendedAudience: Alle!
sessions.abstract: Vi har fått over 76 kodeklubber i Norge, og nesten 50.000 barn var med på kodetimen i 2015. Imidlertid er det lenge til vi har nådd målet om ha undervisning i informatikk i skolen. Jeg vil gi deg litt ammunisjon du kan bruke overfor skolen og skole-eiere, og håper jeg kan gi deg noen råd dersom du vil sette i gang med kodeklubb eller hjelpe den lokale skolen. Om vi lærer kidsa koding sikrer vi Norge i fremtiden!
sessions.title: Lær Kidsa Koding! slik kan du bidra

speakers.name: Line Moseng
speakers.bio: Line ble ferdig med mastergrad i informatikk ved Universitetet i Oslo i 2015. Nå jobber hun som utvikler i Ciber. Hun har engasjert seg i Lær Kidsa Koding siden 2013 med ønske om at at barna som nå vokser opp skal få mulighet til å være skapere og ikke bare forbrukere av digital teknologi.

sessions.intendedAudience:
This presentation is relevant for any Java developer that has ever worked with JPA and Hibernate. That being said, it's best to have some prior knowledge of JPA and/or JDBC.

This presentation aims to offer a different perspective to JPA and Hibernate because it's focused on high-performance features.

No code
sessions.abstract:
Hibernate is the most popular JPA provider and knowing its inner-workings can make the difference between a high-performance enterprise application and one that barely crawls.  

This presentation goes through the most common performance bottlenecks issues like exotic mappings, too much flushing, inappropriate queries, JDBC batch updates misuse, and suboptimal result set fetching.

Aside from common anti-patterns, I will also present some very useful Hibernate features like the enhanced identifier generators, locking-likelihood reduction, caching strategies and bytecode enhancements.
sessions.title: High-Performance Hibernate

speakers.name: Vlad Mihalcea
speakers.bio:
I work as a Developer Advocate for the Hibernate project. I answered more than 1000 Hibernate questions on StackOverflow and wrote over 70 articles about Hibernate.

I'm currently writing a book entitled​ High-Performance Java Persistence ( https://leanpub.com/high-performance-java-persistence ).

sessions.intendedAudience: Intermediate Java level knowledge necessary, there will be code in slides and live coding.
sessions.abstract:
With Java 9, modularity comes to your doorstep (whether you ordered it or not). This isn't your average language feature: making the most out of it may involve rewiring your brain. In this session we explore the benefits of a modular codebase using Java 9 modules. Because who doesn’t like more reliable and secure applications, meanwhile killing the dreaded classpath?

After reviewing the basic concepts of modules, we'll explore modularity patterns that enhance your design and development skills. We all have existing software, so migration of codebases to a modular world is an important topic as well. Automatic modules, the 'unnamed' module and other new concepts are added to your toolbox to this end.

Want examples? We've got plenty in this practical and code-driven talk. Even if you intend to use Java 9 without modules, this talk helps you prevent common issues. You'll be ready for Java 9 before you know it.  

Both speakers are currently writing “Java 9 Modularity” for O’Reilly, expected early 2017. They have extensive experience under the belt already with the Java 9 Jigsaw early access builds.
sessions.title: Java 9 Modularity in Action

speakers.name: Paul Bakker
speakers.bio:
Paul is working as a software architect for Luminis Technologies, where he's currently leading the team that develops the CloudRTI; a Kubernetes/Docker based service that takes care of DevOps tasks like blue/green deployment, failover, centralised logging and monitoring. He is the author of “Building Modular Cloud Apps With OSGi” published by O'Reilly and an advocate for modularity in software. He is currently writing his second book for O'Reilly "Java 9 Modularity" which is expected early 2017.

He's also deeply involved in Amdatu, an open source library for highly modular OSGi components, and several other open source projects. He's a regular speaker on conferences speaking both about modularity/OSGi related topics, and topics related to Kubernetes and cloud architecture in general.

speakers.name: Sander Mak
speakers.bio: Sander crafts scalable software at Luminis Technologies. With almost a decade of experience on the JVM platform, he specializes in modular Java and JavaScript development. Additionally, data analysis and machine learning are part of his ever growing list of interests. Sander loves sharing knowledge, for example through his blog at http://branchandbound.net. He is currently writing 'Java 9 Modularity' for O'Reilly, expected release early 2017. Furthermore he speaks regularly at international developer conferences, sharing his passion for Java, alternative JVM languages and related technologies.

sessions.intendedAudience: For Java-utvikleren som er interessert i å høre om et nytt programmeringsspråk. Det vil være kodeeksempler i presentasjonen.
sessions.abstract:
En introduksjon til Kotlin, et Java-aktig programmeringsspråk som kjører på JVM. Kotlin har verktøyene som trengs for å skrive sikre og robuste applikasjoner med færre kodelinjer takket være en streng kompilator og pragmatisk språkdesign.

Lær det du trenger å vite for å komme i gang med Kotlin. Forstå hvilke fordeler Kotlin kan gi innenfor sikkerhet og kortfattethet. Bruk det i ditt neste prosjekt eller introduser det i en eksisterende Java-kodebase.
sessions.title: Kotlin: Pragmatisk programmering på JVM

speakers.name: Erlend Åmdal
speakers.bio: Erlend Åmdal er en master-student på Datateknologilinjen på NTNU. Til tross for begrenset akademisk bakgrunn har han bygd opp mye erfaring innenfor diverse software-utvikling og en brennende lidenskap for programmering. Jack of all trades, med fokus på både klient- og serversiden på web, Java-miljøet og Minecraft-modding.

sessions.intendedAudience: If you're interested in software defined infrastructure, IT-automation, cloud or devops, this presentation is for you. Expect lots and lots of live coding.
sessions.abstract:
Terraform is a tool for defining, creating and changing versioned infrastructure in a safe and efficient way. The tool lets you define infrastructure using a simple JSON-like syntax, and services from different cloud providers, both public and private, can be combined to create advanced setups.

Terraform being provider agnostic, all kinds of services ranging from low-level resources like virtual machines and disk storage, to high level services like DNS and email can be managed. 

This presentation is packed with demos, showcasing most of the features found in Terraform.
sessions.title: Terraform - colonise the cloud!

speakers.name: Stefan Magnus Landrø
speakers.bio: I currently work with the Oslo-based IT consultancy Bekk Consulting. 15 years industry experience, creating and running business critical applications and services. Open source, cloud and bringing the industry forward, makes me tick. Frequent speaker at conferences.

sessions.intendedAudience: no code... well... probably not :)
sessions.abstract:
This is a talk on my experience learning Norwegian this year!   

Ken is an American man  that loves Norway.  He has traveled their way too often to excuse his ignorance of the language and is making every effort to fix that this year.   The lesson material that he picked up starts with "An American man meets a Norwegian woman".  Come see if Ken has any chance of getting lucky :)
sessions.title: An American Man moter en norsk kvinne

speakers.name: Ken Sipe
speakers.bio: An American man who has seen more of Norway than most norwegians and is learning the viking ways.

sessions.intendedAudience: Code examples in slides
sessions.abstract:
A code review is basically a technical discussion which should lead to improvements in the code and/or sharing knowledge in a team. As with any conversation, it should have substance and form. 

What’s involved in a good code review? What kind of problems do we want to spot and address? Trisha Gee will talk about things a reviewer may consider when looking at changes:  what potential issues to look for; why certain patterns may be harmful; and, of course, what NOT to look at.

But when it comes to commenting on someone’s work, it may be hard to find the right words to convey a useful message without offending the authors - after all, this is something that they worked hard on. Maria Khalusova will share some observations, thoughts and practical tricks on how to give and receive feedback without turning a code review into a battlefield.
sessions.title: Code Review Matters and Manners

speakers.name: Maria Khalusova
speakers.bio: Maria is a JetBrains’ veteran and has participated in various projects since 2006: IntelliJ IDEA, TeamCity, AppCode. Currently she is a Product Marketing Manager in Upsource team. Maria is passionate about productivity tools, sharing knowledge and improving conversations.

speakers.name: Trisha Gee
speakers.bio: Trisha has developed Java applications for a range of industries, including finance, manufacturing, software and non-profit, for companies of all sizes. She has expertise in Java high performance systems, is passionate about enabling developer productivity, and dabbles with Open Source development. Trisha is a leader of the Sevilla Java User Group and a Java Champion. She believes we shouldn't all have to make the same mistakes again and again. She’s a Developer Advocate for JetBrains so she can share all the cool stuff she's discovered so far.

sessions.intendedAudience: Developers. Some code in slides. Maps in slides. Slides in slides. Oh, well, you get the point.
sessions.abstract:
You just zoom into the map until you start to see an indoor floor plan of the building. Then you use the level switcher to move between available floors in the building. Isn't that cool? Well, obviously it is. But it is also really useful.

Have a look at what can be created when a map geek meets an Android geek. Oh, wait, you probably have seen the results already in the app. Well, come and see how we did it, and get a tour behind the scenes.
sessions.title: How We Built an Indoor Map For the JavaZone App. You Can Do That Too!

speakers.name: Khiem-Kim Ho Xuan
speakers.bio:
Khiem-Kim Ho Xuan is an IT consultant working for Computas AS. His interests are developing apps  and .NET applications.
Khiem-Kim is also a competency network coordinator for .NET at Computas and also a member of the Norwegian Java User Group - javaBin.

speakers.name: Rustam Mehmandarov
speakers.bio:
Rustam Mehmandarov holds a master's degree in Computer Science from the University of Oslo. He has been working as a developer and lead programmer for 10 years. In addition to being passionate about agile development, web development, architecture and geographical information systems, he is also a guru of both Linux and Windows worlds. On his spare time he enjoys working out, as well as coding in Python and Java [but not simultaneously].

Leader of the Norwegian Java User Group - javaBin, and of a professional network for databases and information management at work.

He is a frequent speaker at both national and international conferences and events such as JavaOne (USA), JavaZone (Norway), JavaLand (Germany), RigaDevDay (Latvia), NDC - Norwegian Developer Conference (Norway), Booster (Norway), Trondheim Developer Conference (Norway), Open Source Developers' Conference Nordic (Norway), and events at various Norwegian universities.

sessions.intendedAudience:
You should be familiar with JavaScript and best-case you already have some React.JS experience, as I won't make a deep-dive into React.

I'll have code in my slides as also some live demos.
sessions.abstract:
Isomorphic (greek: "isos" = equal, "morph" = shape) JavaScript apps are applications that can run the same code on both client-side and server-side. Isomorphism describes that if you look at the same entity in two different contexts, you should get the same thing. Here the contexts are server and client. Although the term has been mostly used in mathematics until now, it's an apt term to describe a web programing pattern where the code is shared by the front-end and back-end.
Just take an MVC-based Java framework, like the new Java EE 8 MVC 1.0, integrate it with Nashorn and use the famous JavaScript templating engine React.JS (developed by Facebook) as the "V"iew layer in MVC - that's it. Now you can render templates on the server- as also on the client side - or start rendering serverside, send them to the client and finish there! Nothing is impossible - even Netflix uses it!
sessions.title: Isomorphic JavaScript apps with Nashorn, React.JS and Java EE MVC

speakers.name: Niko Köbler
speakers.bio:
Doing stuff with computers, mostly hacking (functional) on the JVM.
Also consulting and training business. Co-Lead of a local Java User Group.
Author and Speaker at international tech conferences.
Tweeting at @dasniko.

sessions.intendedAudience: Lyntalen er ment for alle som ønsker å høre hvordan det offentlige i kan samarbeide om utvikling av felleskomponenter. Selve lyntalen vil være basert på erfaringer og utfallet av samarbeidet.
sessions.abstract: De offentlige har begynt å dele på github! I denne lyntalen skal vi se på hvordan Oslo kommune og Direktoratet for forvaltning of IKT (Difi)  samarbeider om å bygge felleskomponenter gjennom åpen kildekode. Lyntalen beskriver samarbeidet på et teknisk nivå med stikkord som: deling av åpen kildekode, verktøy for samarbeid i utviklingsprosessen, bruk av open source-modeller og litt om hvordan du også kan bidra for å gjøre nasjonale felleskomponenter enda bedre!
sessions.title: Hvordan Oslo Kommune og Difi samarbeider om åpen kildekode

speakers.name: Kennet Vuong
speakers.bio:
Kennet fullførte sin mastergrad i Informatikk våren 2015 og startet i Knowit august 2015 som konsulent. Kennet har raskt gått fra DevOps utvikler til en større rolle som utviklingsleder og teamleder i sitt nye prosjekt.
Kennet er en ivrig utvikler som stadig er på jakt etter nye utfordringer og teknologier. Han ser på seg selv som en full-stack utvikler som trives like godt på frontend og backend. Kennet har stor interesse for teknologi og er stadig på jakt etter nye og kule teknologier. I tillegg har Kennet sansen for funksjonell programmering og spesielt Clojure.

sessions.intendedAudience: G1 GC will be the default collector in JDK 9. Anyone that would like to get more details on the default garbage collector and wants to understand the internals as well as take home some tuning advice is welcome to attend. The slides will have lots of GC logs (using the new logging format introduced in JDK 9). The author will also include GCHisto and JFreeCharts to provide GC information to the attendees.
keywords: garbage collection, g1 gc, java 9 gc logging
sessions.abstract: This is a Garbage First Garbage Collector (G1 GC) readiness session. In this session, attendees will learn more about G1 pause (young and mixed) composition, G1's remembered sets and collection set and G1's concurrent marking phase. The speaker will also cover performance tuning advice for "taming" mixed collections and evacuation failures.
sessions.title: Java 9: The (G1) GC Awakens!

speakers.name: Monica Beckwith
speakers.bio: Monica Beckwith is an Independent Consultant specializing in optimizing the Java Virtual Machine and the Garbage Collectors for enterprise applications. She is a regular speaker at various conferences and has several published articles on topics including garbage collection, the Java memory model and others. Monica led Oracle's Garbage First Garbage Collector performance team, and was named a JavaOne 2013 Rock Star.

sessions.intendedAudience: Dette er en presentasjon for deg som ønsker å høre om praktiske erfaringer ved bruk av jwt i et bredt systemlandskap, hvor kanal til sluttbrukere er både web og intraweb. Dette involverer hvordan single sign-on løsninger samhandler både med applikasjoner og underliggende integrasjoner.  Code level: "Code in slides"
sessions.abstract:
I kategorien ikke-funksjonelle krav er sikkerhet og sporbarhet blant de viktigste, men ofte prioritert ned eller glemt i jakten på ny funksjonalitet. 

Når så sikkerhet kommer i fokus er det lett å bli paralysert av utfordringen. Det naturlige kravet er single sign-on og sporbarhet mellom alle applikasjoner og systemer. Finnes det et produkt som kan kjøpes? Vil et prosjekt kunne implementere det? 

Denne lyntalen handler om enkel teknologi og mekanismer for sikkerhet og sporbarhet mellom applikasjoner på web/intraweb og fagsystemer. JSON Web Token (jwt) brukes som underliggende standard, og det blir presentert bruk av både tredjeparts-biblioteker og skreddersydde løsninger for sikkert å spore en brukers handlinger i systemet.
sessions.title: Sikkerhet er ikke en one stop shop!

speakers.name: Per Otto Bergum Christensen
speakers.bio: Per Otto er fagansvarlig for Java og integrasjon i Eika og har jobbet med utvikling på Java-plattformen i over 16 år. I Eika jobber Per Otto i prosjekter og med behov som går på tvers. Han møter hele tiden utfordringer sammen med team på jakt etter løsninger som lar seg realisere effektivt i en fungerende første versjon, eller hvor det er behov for utvidelser av eksisterende løsninger.

sessions.intendedAudience: This session is for anyone who are curious about other languages on the JVM or about Haskell. No previous knowledge about Haskell or functional programming is assumed. There will be code in slides which will be explained as we go.
sessions.abstract:
This is your chance of being the ultimate JVM hipster and use a language “before it was cool”.

Frege is an implementation of the Haskell programming language on the JVM and was voted the most popular of the “upcoming languages” at last year's JavaOne conference. With Scala being the elephant in the functional programming room on planet JVM, can Frege be a serious contender? We'll have a look at what makes the language unique by walking through some simple code examples and then look at how Frege code can be called from Java and vice versa.
sessions.title: Off the Deep End: Haskell on the JVM

speakers.name: Erlend Hamberg
speakers.bio: Erlend Hamberg started a on computer engineering degree to learn about systems programming and hardware, but veered slightly off course and ended up with a degree in computer science with a specialization in artificial intelligence. He loves functional programming – especially in languages with strong type systems, but still has a weak spot in his heart for C. When not tinkering with programming or programming language theory he can be found kayaking in the Oslo fjord.

sessions.intendedAudience:
Dette er en presentasjon for JavaScript-utviklere som er nysgjerrige på alternative verktøy for å bli mer produktive.

Det vil vises kode i presentasjonen.
sessions.abstract:
Trenden i webutvikling går mot mer og mer avanserte klienter skrevet i JavaScript. Denne økte kompleksiteten forsøker vi å håndtere gjennom ting som ES2016,  bibliotek for funksjonell programmering, immutability, promises og en god dose disiplin. 

ClojureScript er et pragmatisk språk som hjelper deg til å lage enklere løsninger. 
Denne presentasjonen vil belyse flere grunner til at ClojureScript er verdt 
å vurdere til ditt neste prosjekt.

Kom for å se hvordan et språk kan tilby deg store fordeler og glede, hvis du bare er villig til å lære deg noe ganske annerledes enn det du er vant til.
sessions.title: 3 grunner til at ClojureScript gir deg superkrefter

speakers.name: Odin Standal
speakers.bio: Odin er en Kodemaker og sivilingeniør i datateknikk som liker å fylle verktøykassen. Etter å ha jobbet med ClojureScript i flere prosjekter med stor sukess er han nå overbevist om at funksjonell programmering ofte kan lede til mer robuste løsninger på en raskere måte.

sessions.intendedAudience:
The attendees should know JUnit and how to write tests with it. After the talk they will know why JUnit 5 was necessary, how to use and how it might improve testing on the JVM for all frameworks.

There will be code in slides.
sessions.abstract:
Java's most ubiquitous library is getting an update!
And this is the time to see what's new and weigh in on its course.

This talk will...

* show you how to write tests with JUnit 5
* walk you through the changes compared to JUnit 4
* present the new architecture
* discuss compatibility with previous JUnit versions, IDEs, and other testing tools

Be careful, though:
You might end up with an urge to start using it right away.
sessions.title: JUnit 5: Next Generation Testing on the JVM

speakers.name: Nicolai Parlog
speakers.bio:
I'm a thirty year old boy, as the narrator would put it, who has found his passion in software development. I constantly read, think, and write about it, and code for a living as well as for fun.

I work as at Disy, Germany's leading provider for spatial and environmental IT-solutions, where I improve the flagship product. I blog about software development on codefx.org and am a long-tail contributor to several open source projects.

I have supported the crowdfunding campaign and followed the project ever since. Back in 2015, I wrote about the prototype (http://blog.codefx.org/libraries/junit-lambda-prototype/),  after its release in February I started playing around (http://blog.disy.net/aarlaubstag-junit5-rust-graphml/) with the alpha version, and I have visited talks about the topic by members of the team. An article for InfoQ is in the making and an interview with the team is planned.

That being said, I am just a voracious consumer of publicly available information about the project but am not affiliated with the developer team.

sessions.intendedAudience: Coding, Javascript experience necessary.
sessions.abstract:
Chrome Developer Tools er tilgjengelig i alle Chrome installasjoner, men få kjenner til alle mulighetene. Å se på DOM elementer og lese console output er kjent for mange, men den kan også brukes som editor, analysere ytelse og finne minnelekasjer. Etterhvert som Javascript-applikasjoner blir mer komplekse blir avansert bruk av Chrome Developer Tools nødvendig for å skjønne hvordan applikasjonen fungerer.

I løpet av 2 timer skal vi blant annet se på hvordan åpne og endre lokale filer direkte i Chrome med sourcemaps og hvordan bruke CPU profile og flame chart for å finne kilden til ytelsesproblemer.
sessions.title: Alt du ikke visste om Chrome Developer Tools

speakers.name: Lars Barlindhaug
speakers.bio: Loves to solve problems. Consultant at Iterate.

sessions.intendedAudience: Alle som er interessert i og nysgjerrig på maskinlæring. "No code"
sessions.abstract:
John McCarthy innførte begrepet 'kunstig intelligens' i 1955 som en betegnelse på vitenskapen knyttet til det å lage intelligente maskiner. Fire år senere introduserte Arthur Samuel begrepet 'maskinlæring'.

Hvorfor har vi først nå begynt å snakke om disse tingene? Hva er egentlig maskinlæring og hva kan det gjøre for virksomheter? Alt dette, og mye mer, vil du få vite mer om i kontekst av dataanalyse.
sessions.title: Maskinlæring - Hva er det og hvorfor snakker vi om det?

speakers.name: Vegard Hartmann
speakers.bio: Vegard fullførte en master i kunstig intelligens i 2005. Etter det har han jobbet som IT-konsulent og er nå leder for IT-rådgivning i BEKK. Etter mange år som konsulent er studiet endelig relevant for jobben. Vegard kombinerer teknisk innsikt om kunstig intelligens og maskinlæring med kunnskap om hvordan det kan tas i bruk i virksomheter og hva det betyr for forretningssiden.

sessions.intendedAudience:
This is an introductory talk. I require no previous experience with any of the above techniques.
I will show some Java, Python, and JavaScript code in the slides. However, Java developers will be able to make sense of this code.
sessions.abstract:
Interactive visualizations of large sets of data allow for completely new ways of exploring it. They are no longer static images that can be used to tell a story, but rather allow to inspect the world at a macroscopic level. Putting those visualizations into a zero-install environment like the browser makes the data accessible to anyone who has the domain knowledge but not necessarily a very technical background.

Based on a real project I will lead you through the phases of data visualisation. Preparation using pandas and pyelasticsearch. Storing and providing the data using Elasticsearch. Eventually, displaying data in the most interactive way in the browser using D3.
sessions.title: Worlds, not Stories: Data Exploration in the browser using Elasticsearch, Pandas, and D3

speakers.name: Oliver Zeigermann
speakers.bio:
Oliver Zeigermann is a developer and consultant from Hamburg, Germany. He has developed software in many different languages and technologies over the past couple of decades, including C, C++, Java, Python, and JavaScript.

For the past few years he dived into the analysis of larger sizes of data using machine learning and/or data visualisation techniques. Among other things, he contributed to interactive visualisations to Graylog, an Elasticsearch based log management software.

sessions.intendedAudience:
Dette er en gøy workshop for alle utviklere, og det spiller ingen trille om du er superarkitekt eller er i din spede begynnelse på karrieren. Workshopen gir et innblikk i hvor enkelt man kan lage en 3D-opplevelse på mobil. Eneste forutsetningen er grunnleggende forståelse for Java. Android-kompetanse er et pluss.

Code in slides
sessions.abstract: Er du klar for en smakebit på fremtidens gaming? Mesan tar deg med på en reise inn i det noe uvanlige, hvor vi skal utforske Virtual Reality og hvordan man kan lage enkle spill i full 3D ved hjelp av enkle virkemidler som papp og en mobil. Her snakker vi workshop i Android-utvikling med Java og OpenGL, Google Cardboards, matematikk og en god dose fantasi. Dette blir gøy! Vi stiller med utstyr og info, du stiller med pågangsmot og kreativitet. Ta gjerne med din egen Android-telefon om du har. Vel møtt!
sessions.title: VR for alle!

speakers.name: Thomas Pettersen
speakers.bio: Tech Lead Mobil i Mesan. Har jobbet siden 2010 med utvikling av mobilapplikasjoner, med hovedvekt på Android og mobile backends. Er lidenskapelig interessert i tekniske duppedingser, molekylær gastronomi og jordbærfisk, og deler mer enn gjerne dette med omverden (om man ser bort fra jordbærfisken..!)

sessions.intendedAudience:
What we expect from you:
• Not afraid to use a shell, though commands will be served
• Hands-on
• Eager to learn a new technology
• Not afraid to ask questions

You will need to bring your own laptop with 5GB free disk space. A virtual machine for VirtualBox will be provided to get you started.

For setup instructions, follow this link:
https://github.com/mbertani/elk-workshop/tree/javazone2016
sessions.abstract:
The LAPD makes crime report data publicly available. In this workshop you will get your hands dirty and learn to use ELK to analyze these data. ELK consist of three open source projects — Elasticsearch, Logstash, and Kibana — designed to take data from any source and search, analyze, and visualize it in real time. The philosophy behind these tools is that getting immediate, actionable insight from data matters.

During this workshop we will teach you how to:
• Get ELK up and running
• Configure Logstash to process data on LAPD crime reports
• Configure Logstash to pass the processed data to Elasticsearch
• Define a mapping template in elasticsearch to shape our data, so that you can both search and aggregate.
• Visualize the data in Kibana. Create a dashboard with a map, graphcs and tables to get insights from the data.
 
If time allows, we will show you examples on how to parse HTTP access logs and/or Java stack trace logs.

For more information, take a look at https://www.elastic.co/
sessions.title: Law and Order in LA - To Process and Search with ELK

speakers.name: Sigmund Hansen
speakers.bio: Sigmund works at Computas and is the manager of test and dev environments, builds and releases of case management software used by Norwegian courts. He is also responsible for analysing error logs from the production environment, and uses ELK for these purposes, creating dashboards to quickly get a view of the state of affairs in production. Sigmund has been a Java hobbyist since 1998. At university he specialized in programming languages, language theory, data structures and algorithms. He has teaching and speaking experience from university, game jams, conferences and the Norwegian Lær Kidsa Koding (Teaching Children Code), and has taught semantic web, data structures and algorithms, ELK and object-oriented, game and microcontroller programming.

speakers.name: Marco Bertani-Økland
speakers.bio: Marco is a mathematician and software developer working at Computas. Marco has worked at several projects for Politiets IKT Tjenester (PIT). Among these, has Marco used ELK for data visualization and real-time analytics for Norways Police crime case management system. He has also held workshops for PIT's middelware unit, to help them define their logging architecture with ELK. He has a strong interest in machine learning, data visualization, predictive policing, functional programming and Mathematics.

sessions.intendedAudience: Front-end developers with passion to UX. Accessibility evangelists. Responsive and adaptive UIs heroes. Live coding.
sessions.abstract:
Our amazing web applications need high-quality UI components. So we have Angular 2 app on one hand and Material Design visual language on another. How to combine these without calling designer and spending days on struggling with CSS cross-platform issues and re-inventing client-side code for common UI scenarios? Right! Angular Material 2, set of reusable, well-tested, and accessible UI components, is going to solve this issue. It's still under active development but we can look behind the scenes and create our cross-platform, UI-rich app just in minutes. Let's go exploring and coding!
